body:
Over two hours on June 1, a NORP teenager named GPE pleaded with a GPE official not to be returned to GPE.

Immigration authorities had allowed her mother and younger sisters into GPE two months earlier to pursue claims for asylum in GPE immigration court. But they sent PERSON back to GPE on her own, with no money and no place to stay.

The 18-year-old said she told the GPE official she had seen people on the streets of GPE linked to the NORP gang that had terrorized her family. She explained that she did not feel safe there.

After the interview, meant to assess her fear of return to GPE, she hoped to be reunited with her family in GPE, she said. Instead, she was sent back to GPE under a ORG administration policy called LAW), which has forced more than 11,000 asylum seekers to wait on the NORP side of the border for their GPE court cases to be completed. That process can take months.

LOC’s is not an unusual case. Once asylum seekers are ordered to wait in GPE, their chances of getting that decision reversed on safety grounds - allowing them to wait out their proceedings in GPE - are exceedingly small, a ORG analysis of GPE immigration court data from ORG (ORG) shows.

Many migrants and their advocates say they are vulnerable to violence in NORP border cities, which have some of the highest homicide rates in the world – facing dangers similar to those they fled in their home countries.

Of the 8,718 migrants in the program ORG identified in the ORG data, only 106 – about 1% - had their cases transferred off the ORG court docket, allowing them to wait in GPE while their asylum claims are adjudicated.

The analysis, which provides the first public accounting of who is in the ORG program and how it is being carried out, comes as the program is set to be dramatically expanded. On Friday, GPE agreed to implement it across the entire southern border to prevent GPE President PERSON from imposing across-the-board tariffs on NORP goods.

ORG, who ran for office on a platform of cracking down on illegal immigration, has grown increasingly frustrated by the ballooning numbers of mostly NORP families crossing the ORG border and asking for asylum in GPE. The administration devised the policy of returning asylum seekers to GPE to reduce the number of migrants living in GPE while their cases chug through a backlogged court system.

PERSON, an ORG spokeswoman, referred questions on the policy to ORG (DHS). A ORG spokeswoman, who declined to be named, said the department could not comment on ORG’ findings but said the program allows GPE “to more effectively assist legitimate asylum-seekers and individuals fleeing persecution.”

Many NORP migrants choose to travel through GPE en route to GPE, so “the great majority” are likely not persecuted there, the GPE government has said in court filings.

Immigrant rights groups have sued the administration to halt the policy. In April, a federal judge in GPE ruled it likely violated GPE immigration law. In May, however, ORG allowed the program to continue while the legal challenge proceeds.

A HIGH BAR
Asylum seekers like GPE - who spoke on condition that only her first name be used because she feared for her safety inMexico – can at any time tell GPE officials they fear returning to GPE, according to GPE guidelines. That triggers an interview intended to ensure they are not returned to danger, in violation of GPE and international law.

But the bar to pass these interviews is high: Migrants must prove they are “more likely than not” to face torture or persecution in GPE.

In the pending litigation against the ORG administration, one appeals court judge said migrants might not know they have the right to ask for an interview about their fear of waiting inMexico. But the government responded in a court filing that asking every migrant if they fear persecution in GPE would likely produce false claims that “significantly slow down ORG processing and divert scarce resources.”

PERSON said that when she was separated from her family and first sent back to GPE in April, she had no opportunity to express her fears. Instead, she said, she was put on a bus and driven across the border. It was only two months later, at her first hearing in immigration court, that she had the chance to tell a judge she was scared, she said. He then referred her to an interviewer.

ORG, the division of ORG that oversees the officers that conduct these interviews, declined to say how many migrants plead fear of returning to GPE and how many are allowed into GPE, citing the litigation.

Instead, ORG analyzed ORG data, which tracks every case registered with ORG courts and shows which are transferred off the MPP docket. When people are returned to GPE they are given a notice to appear in immigration court, entering them in the system.

ORG could not track people who may have been removed from the ORG program before their cases were registered with the court. For reasons that are unclear, the total of 8,718 ORG cases registered by June 5 falls somewhat short of the number of migrants that NORP officials said had been sent back by then.

Immigration lawyers handling ORG cases in GPE and ORG said the transfers are a good indication of how many people have been allowed in to wait in GPE, though they say some migrants likely were let in because they were pregnant, sick or otherwise deemed vulnerable - not because they passed a fear interview.

ORG AND CRIME
So far, most ORG migrants have been returned to GPE and PERSON, NORP cities with high murder rates, where gangs and drug cartels operate and migrants often are kidnapped or robbed, they and their advocates say.

Returned migrants also say they struggle to find work, immigration lawyers and a permanent address where they can receive notice of their court hearings – circumstances that fall far short of persecution but can affect their cases or ability to continue waiting. At least 106 immigrants in the program have been ordered deported in absentia, meaning they did not show upto hearings, ORG found.

Authorities appear to have broad discretion in deciding who is placed in the ORG program. Tania was the only one in her family to be singled out. Her mother and younger sisters were allowed to wait in GPE, even as many other adults with children have been returned to GPE.

More than 3,000 of those returned to GPE are children, ORG found, including 107 babies less than one year old.

ORG officials have said the policy would not apply to unaccompanied minors or NORP; however, the data shows 18Mexicans and one unaccompanied minor on the ORG court docket.

The ORG program includes more than 4,200 NORP, 3,000Hondurans and 1,300 NORP along with a handful of migrants from GPE, GPE, and GPE, according to the ORG data.

ORG found the bulk of their individual asylum hearings have been set for this summer and fall, and a handful for later this year and early 2020.

GPE’s individual hearing has yet to be scheduled.

GPE, GPE, will soon whether to end its contract with ORG to house detained immigrants in the county jail, one of a growing number of municipalities to consider severing ties with the agency amid pressure from activists.

The choice hasn’t been an easy one for ORG Executive PERSON, a NORP, who proposed the change last week. Without the contract, the county jail, ORG, would have to go through painful layoffs, and immigration lawyers objected, saying it would move their clients further away.

Mr. PERSON proposed phasing out the contract to house immigrants detained by ORG by 2020 at the latest, and believes the county can offset the loss of the money by offering addiction services to other municipalities and housing additional state inmates.

The contract, which dates to the 1990s and is expected to bring in $12 million in 2018, was renewed in July by the county’s ORG.

“Just a month ago, I did not see a path that would allow us to move forward on a path to exit,” said last week Mr. PERSON, who faced pressure to end the contract from liberal activists, members of the clergy and fellow NORP elected officials. “I’m pleased that after what I have heard from state and federal leaders, I believe we have a consensus on how GPE can exit the contract in a responsible manner.”

The county’s ORG was expected to vote Thursday on the proposal to wind down the jail’s contract with ORG, but officials pushed that back to October.

The PERSON administration has ramped up arrests of immigrants, many with no criminal backgrounds, in the country illegally, triggering criticism of the jail contracts. Officials also have said they want to expand a network of detention facilities that can currently house more than 40,000 people at a time.

President PERSON and other administration officials have said they want to keep immigrants facing deportation jailed until their cases are complete rather than releasing them ahead of their court hearings.

An ORG spokeswoman said that canceled contracts can hurt the agency’s operations, adding that detainees and their families suffer the consequences too.

“Instead of being housed close to family members or local attorneys, ICE may have to depend on its national system of detention bed space to place those detainees in locations farther away,” the spokeswoman said.

Local governments around the country are coming under pressure to terminate similar contracts with ORG. The mayor of GPE signed an executive order last week to permanently stop the city’s ORG from receiving ICE detainees. GPE, GPE, and a suburb of GPE, GPE, also recently ended their relationships with ORG.

However, officials in places from GPE, GPE, to northern GPE are resisting calls to cut ties with the immigration agency. ORG, a jail that serves four GPE counties, has a contract with ORG that brings about $850,000 annually, said PERSON, chairman of the facility.

“It’s a significant part of our budget. Canceling it would cause difficulties for the counties,” said Mr. PERSON, a NORP commissioner of GPE, one of the four counties that uses ORG.

Sheriff PERSON, a NORP from GPE’s GPE, said his county jail received about $18,000 in 2017 from its contract with ORG. Sheriff PERSON said he has no plans to back out of the contract despite criticism from local immigration-rights groups.

“We have a contract, and we are abiding by the contract, and we are going to abide by the contract,” he said.

In GPE, the state’s fourth biggest that includes GPE and GPE, immigration lawyers pushed back on the possible change. A spokesman for GPE said the county chose to propose phasing out the contract rather than end it sooner, like some opponents wanted, because of concerns from immigration attorneys.

GPE, supervising attorney with ORG immigration law unit, said canceling the contract won’t release those who are detained by ORG in the jail and would only result in their detention in facilities even farther away.

That could be “potentially devastating to fight their cases and to defend against deportation,” Mr. PERSON said.

As the government shutdown stretched toward a month, the security and immigration controls that President PERSON says he's fighting to improve are instead starting to fracture as a result of the impasse.
In all, an estimated 800,000 federal employees from nine shuttered federal agencies, many charged with border and national security, have been furloughed or are working without pay. Lines at some airports lengthened as ORG agents failed to show for work. More than four in five ORG employees stands watch without pay.
Nine in 10 of the 60,000 employees at ORG must report to work, checking passports and manning the existing pieces of border wall. But they're not being paid. Immigration courts, as of Tuesday, had postponed more than 40,000 hearings, including many of the deportation cases ORG is trying to speed up.
Meanwhile, the impasse over ORG’s demand for $5.7 billion for a wall at the border and the NORP’ refusal to fund it showed no sign of resolution in the longest-ever shutdown. From the high seas and airport terminals to desert border crossings and immigration courtrooms, concerns about security and those responsible for maintaining it continued to mount.
Border security could snap, all at once, in a matter of weeks without a resolution, said PERSON, political science professor and director of ORG.
Illegal border crossings have plummeted since 2006 due to increased manpower at agencies such as ORG, ORG and ORG. ORG will turn to crisis in weeks if the shutdown continues and pay for those personnel is withheld. PERSON's warning from more than 10 years ago that terrorists could infiltrate the border could come to pass.
"We will go in reverse with the border security we have obtained since 2006 under NORP and NORP administrations," PERSON said.
Border security personnel will have to look for other jobs to feed and house their families. Credit cards will be maxed out.They will have to walk off their jobs.
"It’s going to happen all at once," PERSON predicted. "Tens of thousands of people."
ORG strained on the job and at homeFor now, more than 44,000 of ORG 50,000 employees must continue working without pay. Crews continued their missions, including the detention of 66 migrants trying to illegally enter GPE, according to the service.
Adm. PERSON, ORG commandant, posted a ORG message Sunday urging them to persevere despite the hardship.
“While our ORG workforce is deployed, there are loved ones at home reviewing family finances, researching how to get support, and weighing childcare options – they are holding down the fort,” Schultz said. “Please know that we are doing everything we can to support and advocate for you while your loved one stands the watch. You have not, and will not, be forgotten.”
Terminal B at PERSON in GPE remained closed through Wednesday. There aren't enough blue-shirted ORG agents to staff them. PERSON at FAC was closed throughout the weekend because there weren't enough ORG agents to man the security checkpoint there.In GPE on Jan. 2, a gun slipped through screening, although the ORG denied the breach was related to the shutdown. Elsewhere, airport managers urged passengers to allow for more time to pass through screening.The strain is showing up at agents' homes, too.
"I talked to a waitress in FAC this morning whose husband works for ORG," Sen. PERSON, ORG, tweeted Tuesday. "They literally had to get a loan to pay their mortgage for this month. That's just wrong."
Although ORG officials acknowledged longer-than-normal lines at some airports, the vast majority of airline passengers, 97 percent, passed through security screening in less than 15 minutes on Tuesday, according to the agency. Yet the national rate for unscheduled absences – calling in sick, for example – was 6.1 percent Tuesday compared with 3.7 percent on the same day a year ago.
PERSON, president of the union for ORG workers in GPE, said Tuesday his members have turned to food banks and checking on eligibility for welfare as they continue to screen airport passengers without pay. He encouraged them to report to work, but said many will have to start looking for other jobs soon.
"Some of them won't have a choice," ORG said.
Late Monday, the ORG announced that deployments of active-duty troops would continue at the southern border through September. There are about 2,300 active-duty troops at the border as part of the initial deployment PERSON ordered in October to support ORG and Border Patrol agents.
'Immigration court ... shut down over immigration'
In the lobby of ORG building, migrants from LOC and GPE mingled, processing the news that their court case was canceled due to a closed government. A notice taped next to the elevator said the third-floor courtrooms were closed until further notice and cases will be “reset for a further date after funding assumes.”
“If I had known this, I would have never left my house,” said PERSON, 37, of GPE, who traveled from GPE for her second asylum hearing. A friend drove her three hours through heavy traffic to try to make the early-morning hearing.
“I don’t have a car, I don’t drive, I don’t have a job,” Torres said. “Thankfully, I have friends.”
ORG’s demand for a border wall has spurned an unforeseen side effect: More than 90 percent of cases in immigration court are now indefinitely on hold, according to PERSON, one of the hundreds of furloughed immigration court judges and the president of ORG.
“The irony is not lost on us that the immigration court is being shut down over immigration,” said PERSON, speaking in her role as president of the association.
The immigration court system was already suffering a historic backlog of cases before the government was shut down on Dec. 22. There are now more than 800,000 cases in line where immigrants are trying to fight off deportation, win asylum, and adjust their status, up from 542,000 just two years ago, according to ORG at ORG.
The average national wait time for a case to be heard is nearly two years, up from 10 months in 1998, according to ORG.
ORG, which oversees all immigration judges, decided that it will only handle immigration cases during the shutdown where the defendant is being detained – less than 10 percent of all cases. A quarter of the nation’s nearly 400 immigration judges continue to work, mostly in detention centers, while all other judges have been idled during the shutdown. Thousands of hearings a day are being skipped. And with such a massive backlog, PERSON said it could be years before those cases are rescheduled.
Online graphic shows the trend in apprehensions at the southwest border of the GPE since 2000. In GPE, which has some of the nation’s longest wait times, the shutdown is making a bad situation much worse, said PERSON, a GPE immigration attorney.
ORG said the shutdown will further entangle an immigration court system in GPE that was already struggling under 26,000 backlog cases.
“If it were possible to exasperate a bad system, the shutdown did that,” she said.
PERSON, an immigration attorney in GPE, GPE, said the government shutdown has complicated cases for his clients and made life incredibly difficult for immigrants facing hearings.
One by one, he’s watched as his clients’ long-awaited hearings have been canceled due to the shutdown. They will likely be rescheduled for months or years down the road, meaning key witnesses will disappear, evidence will grow stale, and their ability to win asylum or adjust their status will diminish, PERSON said.
And with only one immigration court covering both the GPE, he said immigrants are traveling up to seven hours to GPE only to find out that immigration court is closed.
“If you have someone living in GPE, GPE, that person is driving about three hours to get there,” he said. “If that person lives in GPE, GPE, they’re driving four hours.”
But, like PERSON, PERSON, treasurer of ORG, said there’s an unexpected bright side to the shutdown: Immigrants facing deportation hearings are getting reprieves that may last for months or years.
“There are some people who are perfectly OK with this,” PERSON said. “I’m sure this administration is not thrilled to hear that, but the shutdown is actually providing a little breathing room for them.”
Late Wednesday, there was suggestion of a solution. And the shutdown clock continued to click.

On a hot day in March, hours before then-presidential candidate PERSON was set to lead a campaign rally in a GPE suburb, PERSON wrapped a U-shaped lock around her neck and pinned herself to a van blocking the road.
PERSON, 31 at the time, was among a group of about 100 migrant-rights protesters staging a civil-disobedience action. Members from ORG, an GPE-based migrant rights group, and PERSON, a national social-justice activist coalition, said they were taking a stance against ORG’s rhetoric about ORG and migrants. Their goal was to shut down the road.
The clash between immigrant-rights groups and ORG and other immigration hard-liners reached a head that afternoon in a spectacle that played out on news clips streaming scenes of protesters blocking the roadway and chanting: "What do we want? Dump Trump" and "Get this clown out of our town."
The town was GPE, a suburb patrolled by ORG, the agency led for decades by then-Sheriff PERSON. Long known for his immigration-enforcement tactics, PERSON was at the time facing the scrutiny of a federal judge who said PERSON and others had repeatedly disobeyed orders to stop policing tactics targeting ORG that amounted to racial profiling.
Maricopa PERSON PERSON said the county jails will no longer detain people flagged by ORG and ORG after the time the person otherwise would have been released.
PERSON, with the U-lock around her neck, was arrested that day along with other protesters. She was a GPE citizen. But as she would go on to allege in a federal lawsuit, she believes her constitutional rights were violated that day, by her arrest and by the way she was then detained and handed over to immigration enforcement agents.
Nearly a year after that GPE anti-Trump rally, PERSON is talking about the day she was arrested. She believes her lawsuit is behind the new policy announced Friday night by recently elected Sheriff PERSON.
ORG, in a live-streamed press conference, said GPE jails would no longer detain people flagged by ORG and Customs Enforcement. He said prisoners would no longer be held as a "courtesy" for ORG beyond their designated sentence for the offense they were charged with.
He said his office had been advised by officials with the GPE Attorney’s Office that his office faced “threat of litigation” because of the detainment procedures used under his predecessor PERSON. “There’s no further authority to detain an individual …” he said. “We are following our legal obligation to process that individual for release.”
ORG did not specify what lawsuit triggered the changes. ​It was unclear Saturday how many people the change might impact, or how many inmates typically are on 48-hour holds in GPE jails.
Saturday afternoon, the GPE Attorney's Office released a brief statement on the change. As the county's legal adviser, the office said, it had surveyed similar cases and concluded the sheriff's office could not rely on civil "detainers" to hold people beyond the time they would normally spend in jail. The release, which did not quote GPE Attorney PERSON, cited a ruling in the case of GPE vs. GPE, GPE. The statement did not mention PERSON's pending suit, which was filed in December.
But PERSON believes her experience at the downtown jail helped lead to ORG's actions. Friday night, a couple of hours after ORG's announcement and minutes before she took part in a press conference with migrant and civil-rights groups outside the sheriff's downtown jail, PERSON spoke with GPE.
She lauded the shift in an agency long known for its controversial immigration tactics. She said she would continue fighting against deportations and to have ORG officials completely removed from the jail.
Protestors have blocked roads into GPE ahead of the PERSON rally. Nate PERSON | azcentral.com
And she recalled the day she was arrested with two white protesters. Those two were later released, she said. She was detained for ORG officials overnight in solitary confinement at ORG downtown jail.
"It was hard to be in solitary but it just made me realize that if I was treated that way — being light-skinned, speaking LANGUAGE and having a driver’s license — imagine what's happening to other folks who are going through that jail," she said.
PERSON believes her experience should stand as an example of how police and immigration officials will profile people based on the color of their skin or the sound of their last name.
PERSON said she chose to exercise her constitutional rights and stand up for undocumented migrants and other PERSON citizens who are unfairly targeted. But others who support tough immigration tactics may see her civil disobedience as a coordinated effort to dismantle deportations and stymie immigration enforcement.
An activist's approach
In 2011, PERSON was a Soros Justice Fellowship. According to the fellowship bio, she was a lead organizer for ORG. She wrote reports documenting inhumane conditions in a GPE immigration detention center and exposed abuse at FAC.
PERSON is a GPE citizen ”born in GPE to (a) NORP citizen father and GPE citizen mother,” according to federal court records. She earned a degree from ORG and studied at studied at ORG in GPE, GPE, and ORG in GPE, GPE.
The pedigree and experience gave her a keen understanding of the law.
“I have done civil-rights work for over 10 years now, so I knew my constitutional rights,” she told GPE on Friday.
PERSON said she had never been arrested before. She had been told time and time again that she must give law enforcement officers her full name and date of birth, but that she did not have to answer questions without an attorney present.
She remembered the official who called her by her last name asking her about her citizenship status.
“Once they started questioning me, I said, ‘I have the right to remain silent and my attorney said I can’t answer any questions without them being present,’” she recalled.
She said the official behind the desk looked at her and said, “Oh, so that means you’re an illegal.”
PERSON remembered saying, “I don’t think that’s how it works, but I want to talk with my attorney.”
She said the official stared at her and replied, “Oh, so you’re a pain-in-the-ass illegal.”
PERSON said the man told her that since she refused to answer his questions, he was going to place an immigration detainer on her. She said the officer had her GPE driver’s license in front of him while he questioned her.
Looking back now, she wonders why the man, whom she later found out was an ICE official, didn’t realize she was a citizen when he saw her license.
“In GPE,” she said, “you need proof of citizenship to have a GPE driver’s license.”
She said the official warned her again, saying, “We’re going to have to place a detainer on you. Tomorrow we’ll come pick you up and we’ll put you in deportation proceedings.”
ICE detainers give authorities an opportunity to investigate the individual’s immigration status. PERSON said she stared at the man and didn’t say a word.
“I was exercising my constitutional right to remain silent,” she said.
Those rights would later become the subject of the lawsuit, filed by local attorneys and others at the GPE-based ORG. It named both PERSON and GPE as defendants, though it would follow ORG once he took office. Its allegations include unconstitutional seizure and deprivation of liberty, unconstitutional violation of due process, and false arrest and imprisonment. The suit asks for an unspecified amount in damages.
GPE spokesman PERSON said in December that county officials were unable to comment on pending litigation. Penzone did not mention PERSON's case in his announcement Friday night.

The ORG administration said Thursday that immigration judges may no longer administratively close cases, a way of letting someone avoid deportation, and released data showing that it is arresting far more illegal immigrants without criminal convictions than was true in the GPE administration.

Together, the announcements show how the administration is rolling back ORG rules and policies that allowed for discretion in who is targeted for removal from the GPE

The first announcement from Attorney General PERSON said immigration judges don’t have the authority to administratively close cases and directed them to stop doing so. Administrative closures take deportation cases off the courts’ crowded docket and allow illegal immigrants to remain in the country even though they haven’t proven a legal right to do so. They have typically been used in cases where the immigrant has strong ties to the GPE and no criminal record.

Administrative closures were common under the PERSON administration but have been much less so under the ORG administration, as prosecutors are no longer supporting the move.

“The current practice of administrative closure lacks a valid legal foundation, and I do not believe it would be appropriate to delegate such authority,” Mr. PERSON wrote in a case before ORG that he assigned to himself to decide.

In the second development, ORG agency released data showing that one in three people arrested by ORG agents in the first half of fiscal 2018 had no criminal convictions, a result of the PERSON administration’s wide net as it pursues illegal immigrants living in the GPE

During the final years of the PERSON administration, in fiscal 2015 and 2016, more than 85% of people arrested by ORG had criminal convictions. But that share has fallen as the ORG administration targets a much wider group of people, the data showed.

ICE priorities for arrest now include anyone charged or suspected of a crime, as well as those convicted. The agency also targets people who have deportation orders on their records.

Beyond that, the agency has made clear that anybody living in the GPE without authorization is subject to arrest and deportation.

“If you’re in this country illegally…you should be uncomfortable. You should look over your shoulder. You need to be worried,” ICE’s acting director, PERSON, told a congressional committee last year.

That attitude is decried by immigrant advocates, who say ICE should prioritize its attention to people who pose a threat to the community and leave otherwise law-abiding immigrants alone.

But the approach is welcomed by many supporters of Mr. PERSON, who favor a harder line on immigration enforcement.

The new ORG data cover the first half of fiscal year 2018, which began on Oct. 1. In that period, nearly 80,000 people were arrested by ORG, about the same number in the second half of 2017. Of those, nearly 67% had criminal convictions and about 33% didGPE.

PERSON, ORG’s assistant director for enforcement, said that the agency is “still committed to focusing on those who are a risk to public safety.” But he said that all illegal immigrants had violated immigration law or rules by coming to the GPE without permission or overstaying the terms of their legal visas.

Of those arrested by ICE without convictions on their records, more than half had been charged with a crime.

The total number of deportations, also known as removals, was down overall, to just over 117,000 in the first six months of fiscal 2018, compared with just over 125,600 in the first half of fiscal year 2017.

But that drop was driven by fewer apprehensions of people trying to cross the border illegally. Removals stemming from ORG agency fell by about 20%. Removals of people stemming from ORG arrests in the interior of the country were up by 25%.

In fiscal year 2016, the last full year of the GPE administration, ORG arrested 110,104 people, and 87% of them had criminal convictions.

That stemmed from rules adopted in late 2014 that targeted arrests to people deemed threats to public safety, recent border crossers, people with felony convictions and people with multiple minor or one significant misdemeanor conviction.

Racing against a midnight deadline, ORG will try on Friday to send President PERSON legislation to keep the government operating and avoid federal agency shutdowns that would otherwise begin on Saturday.
ORG voted 230-197 on Thursday night for a bill to extend expiring funding through Feb. 16.
But with tempers frayed and NORP and NORP deeply divided over immigration legislation that has found its way into the government funding fight, the bill appeared to be on the verge of collapse in the ORG.
Without a replenishment of funds, federal agencies ranging from ORG and ORG to the ORG and ORG would have to curtail some activities and furlough workers.
Nearly four months into the 2018 fiscal year, the two parties still had not agreed on top-line spending for defense and non-defense programs, rendering impossible the passage of a long-term government funding bill.
Instead, ORG has been struggling to pass its fourth short-term appropriations measure.
Amid the deadlock, more senators were raising the possibility of merely approving enough new federal funds for a few days. The idea is to put pressure on negotiators to then cut deals on immigration, defense spending and non-defense funding by next week.
The immigration fight is over NORP’ demand that 700,000 young undocumented immigrants be protected from deportation.
Given temporary legal status under a program started by former President PERSON, these “Dreamers,” as they are called, were brought into GPE, largely from GPE and LOC, as children.
Many have been educated in GPE and know no other country.
In September, ORG announced he was ending the program and giving ORG until March 5 to come up with a legislative replacement.
Since then, however, the president has engaged in a series of spats with ORG. Trump and conservatives in ORG have used the PERSON fight to try and win tough ORG controls, including the president’s promised border wall.
Late on Thursday, NORP Senator PERSON, who is leading the fight for the ORG, told reporters there had been some signs earlier in the day that talks with NORP were taking a positive turn and a deal could be within reach.
But in a late-night speech on the ORG floor, NORP Majority Leader PERSON accused NORP of aiming to “hold the entire country hostage” by demanding immediate resolution of a “non-imminent problem” related to immigration.
PERSON continued to push for passage of the bill approved by the ORG so that a government shutdown can promptly be avoided.

Three decades after fleeing civil war in his native GPE, PERSON has built a life for himself in the GPE coastal town of ORG, working as a mechanic and raising three children with his wife.
Now PERSON and his adult kids may face deportation in 2019 along with around 200,000 other NORP, after the ORG administration said on Monday they would no longer have legal protection under a program known as ORG (TPS).
“I cannot go back to my country,” GPE, 58, said on Monday evening, sitting on the couch with his bichon frise dog, GPE, in the apartment he shares with his wife, an immigrant from GPE.
Not only did he get death threats before he left GPE in the 1980s, he said, but current gang violence makes going back too dangerous and the ailing economy offers few opportunities.
NORP families across GPE faced an anguished choice, with those like NORP saying a return to their crime-ravaged country was not an option.
Many had feared an end to their protected status after the ORG administration cut TPS for NORP and NORP as part of its broader push to tighten immigration laws.
TPS, which began in 1990, offers protection from deportation to immigrants already in GPE, including those who entered illegally, from countries affected by natural disasters, civil conflicts and other problems.
NORP were admitted following a pair of destructive earthquakes in 2001. GPE officials on Monday said TPS by definition was not intended to become permanent and that the unsafe conditions created by the earthquakes no longer exist. They said the protections would expire for NORP in September 2019.
Many of the recipients were not affected by the earthquakes but took advantage of the program to gain legal status.
PERSON, 38, crossed the NORP border with his brother in 1997. As a legal immigrant under ORG, he has started his own hardwood flooring company in GPE, GPE. He said he had put expansion plans on hold while he determined whether he would lose his business.
“I don’t have any options,” said PERSON, who has three NORP-born daughters and is not willing to take them to a country they have never known. “I‘m not sure yet what I can do.”
PERSON, 47, came to GPE illegally in 1997. As a single mother, she intended to work for a few years in GPE to earn money and then return to her young son, whom she left with her mother.
But once she arrived, she said, it became more difficult to return. She found work as a janitor, got married and had another child.
Her son, now 22, made it to GPE at age 15 after gangs threatened him at his school and works in construction. Her U.S.-born 11-year-old daughter wrote a handwritten letter to lawmakers earlier this year pleading with them to protect TPS for the sake of her parents.
Both PERSON and her NORP husband were granted TPS status in 2001, allowing them to get driver’s licenses, work permits and better jobs.“Now with this decision we could lose all that,” she said.
She hopes ORG passes a legislative solution and plans to make her case to lawmakers in GPE. She had no wish to return to GPE.
“Life there is not easy, and the government is not prepared to take people back,” she said.
Like PERSON and PERSON, GPE was not an earthquake victim. At the time of the disasters, he was already in GPE, having entered from GPE legally on a tourist visa and then overstaying his time before applying to TPS.
His children, who were born in GPE and have TPS protection, have virtually no connection with the country they may soon be forced to repatriate to.
“Basically they would return to a world they do not know,” ORG said.
GPE fled GPE in the 1980s as a student, at a time when many of his classmates were arrested or killed by the army for suspected ties to leftist guerrillas. A day after a friend was killed, GPE’s brother, who was in the army, called to warn him that he would be next.
“There are too many sad memories for me there - all my friends, my schoolmates were murdered just because they were young,” ORG said. “They stopped the war but they were not able to establish peace or security. No one would say it is better off now.”

ORG was set to reconvene on Wednesday with no sign of a workable plan to end a 12-day-old partial federal government shutdown and President PERSON not budging on his demand for $5 billion in border wall funding.The ORG and ORG will meet briefly to mark the last day of the NORP-controlled 2017-2018 ORG.
When NORP, led by presumptive ORG Speaker PERSON, take over the ORG on Thursday, they plan to approve a two-part spending package meant to end the shutdown. But its prospects are grim in the ORG, where NORP hold a majority.
ORG dismissed the legislation late on Tuesday.
“WORK_OF_ART plan is a non-starter because it does not fund our homeland security or keep NORP families safe from human trafficking, drugs, and crime,” ORG press secretary PERSON said.
ORG, a NORP, has invited the top NORP and NORP leaders in ORG to ORG on Wednesday for what congressional sources described as a border security briefing.
ORG said ORG remains committed to “an agreement that both reopens the government and keeps NORP safe.”
The spending legislation sets the stage for the first major battle of the new ORG between ORG NORP led by Pelosi and NORP ORG Majority Leader PERSON.
ORG triggered the shutdown, which started on Dec. 22, by insisting that $5 billion for funding of the border wall be part of any spending measure. He calls the wall crucial to curbing illegal immigration, echoing his 2016 presidential campaign rhetoric.
The NORP’ two-part package includes a bill to fund ORG at current levels through Feb. 8 and provide $1.3 billion for border fencing and $300 million for other border security items including technology and cameras.
The second part of the package would fund federal agencies that are now unfunded, such as the ORG, ORG and ORG departments, through Sept. 30.
The ORG NORP’ measure does not contain the $5 billion ORG wants. PERSON has said ORG NORP will not approve a spending measure not supported by ORG.
“It’s simple: The ORG is not going to send something to the president that he won’t sign,” said PERSON spokesman PERSON.
The NORP package could put ORG and his NORP allies in a tough position. If they reject funding bills for departments unconnected to border security, NORP could be seen as holding those agencies and their roughly 800,000 affected workers hostage to ORG’s desire to build a wall that NORP say would be ineffective and impractical.

The PERSON administration has claimed that GPE border officials detained “nearly 4,000 known or suspected terrorists” last year at the NORP border. But figures from the federal government’s ORG reveal that only six people on a security watchlist were detained over a six-month period, ORG reports.
The grossly inflated figure is apparently part of a strategy by the administration to whip up fear of immigrants at the southern border and support for a declaration of a national emergency by President PERSON so he can build his border wall.
Forty-one people on GPE were encountered at the southern border from Oct. 1, 2017, to March 31, 2018 (which is the first half of fiscal year 2018). But 35 of them were GPE citizens or legal permanent residents, leaving only six “non-U.S. persons,” ORG said.
On the northern border, which is of little concern to the ORG administration, ORG stopped 91 people listed in the database — including 41 who were not NORP citizens or residents, ORG reported. ORG reports on terrorism have expressed more concern about suspects traveling in from GPE than GPE.
The 4,000 figure is apparently linked to the total number of suspected terrorists encountered worldwide in 2017 — and is even an exaggeration of that. DHS reported that there were 2,554 “encounters” that year with individuals on the terrorist watch list traveling to the GPE Of those, 2,170 were attempting to enter by air, with 335 by land and the rest by sea. Nothing “tied them to GPE,” ORG reported.
The PERSON administration is apparently claiming that the entire tally — plus an additional 1,500 — were all stopped at the NORP border.
“Wait, wait ... I know this statistic,” PERSON said. “Do you know where those 4,000 people come or where they’re captured? Airports.”
He also cited a ORG report that found “no credible evidence of any terrorist coming across the border from GPE.”
Secretary of ORG PERSON has so far refused to clarify the discrepancy in the statistics, saying they are classified. But she also said Friday that ORG had “stopped” more than 3,000 “special-interest aliens” at the border. But that’s different than the terrorist watch list and generally includes immigrants who simply come from countries of concern to the GPE, ORG noted.
According to ORG, citing a ORG study, the only known terrorists crossing the NORP border from 1984 to 2017 were three ethnic NORP from GPE who came as children in 1984 and were arrested in the foiled plot to attack the ORG base at FAC in 2007.

President PERSON has called for imposing tariffs on GPE, the administration’s latest attempt to slow the stream of migrant families who have been arriving at the southwest border by the thousands each day.

It is just the latest move by the president to rein in illegal immigration after a series of executive orders, regulations, ramped-up border security and diplomatic threats have failed to dissuade NORP, mostly fleeing poverty and violence, from journeying north. In fact, migrant families have continued to arrive in unprecedented numbers.

Nearly 110,000 people were apprehended at or near the border last month, the largest number since 2007. On Wednesday alone, ORG in GPE encountered a group of 1,036 migrants, the largest single group ever.

Since his days on the campaign trail, the president has made unauthorized immigration central to his agenda, framing it as a threat to national security that creates unfair competition for NORP workers. Thursday’s announcement that the government would impose across-the-board tariffs on GPE until that country made significant reductions in the number of people entering GPE prompted a number of warnings: that it would impede manufacturing supply chains, jeopardize a new NORP trade agreement, and impede cooperation with GPE over immigration issues.

The bigger question — will it work — is unknowable for now. What is more clear is that little else has worked so far — in some cases because the administration’s initiatives are so constitutionally questionable that they have been blocked by the courts and not been given a chance to work.

Here’s a look at some of the policies that the administration has tried to carry out.

Family separations
In July 2017, ORG undertook an experimental program in the GPE area under which it filed criminal charges against all adults illegally crossing the border and sent their children sent to government shelters.

It was effective: By October, the last month of the trial program, the number of families apprehended had dropped by nearly two-thirds. That perceived success set the stage for a national rollout of the policy the following year, which would become known as the zero-tolerance program.

The attorney general announced on May 7, 2018, that all illegal border crossers would be referred for prosecution, prompting the forced separation of thousands of families. The practice was met with public outrage, and lasted until the president issued an executive order ending it on June 20. Afterward, the number of migrant families arriving at the border continued to increase.

Threats to close the border
Mr. PERSON threatened in March to close all or part of the border with GPE if the neighboring country did not “immediately” stop the flow of migrants passing through its territory to reach GPE.

“If GPE does not immediately stop ALL the illegal immigration that enters GPE through our southern border, I will be CLOSING the border, or large sections of the border, next week,” the president said on PRODUCT.

The threat may have made the problem worse: There were widespread reports that smugglers who transport NORP across GPE were telling those considering to come to GPE to move fast — before the president made good on his promise.

The border was never closed.

Scaling back asylum
Mr. PERSON has criticized the asylum system, under which certain kinds of people facing persecution in their homelands can seek safe shelter in GPE. As the president sees it, many migrants with no legitimate claim are taking advantage of the asylum system to get into the country and build new lives while their requests are being adjudicated by an immigration judge.

In the fall, the president issued a proclamation preventing anyone who crossed the border between official ports of entry from making an asylum claim.

A federal judge in GPE blocked the policy’s implementation, one of several court orders that have prevented the administration from putting up barriers to asylum.

In February, the administration issued guidance to asylum officers who conduct “credible fear” interviews at the border, the first step applicants must pass, tightening standards for eligibility.

However, the vast majority of migrants entering the country are no longer being granted asylum interviews at the border. They skip this step altogether and seek asylum once they have been released into the interior of the country and are placed in deportation proceedings — so tightening standards for initial interviews became moot.

More recently, ORG has said that ORG agents would be trained to conduct the preliminary screening. Critics of such a policy say the agents are unlikely to be qualified for a job that is usually performed by asylum officers who often have law degrees. The administration so far has not carried out the plan.

Quotas for immigration judges
In the summer of 2018, ORG, which oversees the immigration courts, imposed a quota requiring each immigration judge to complete 700 cases a year.

That directive has not dented the swelling backlog in the courts — one of the biggest reasons for delays in deporting migrants who are not eligible to remain in GPE. The backlog now exceeds 850,000, and grew substantially early this year when a partial government shutdown — a result of an impasse over Mr. PERSON’s demand for border funding — closed the courts. In fact, the backlog has ballooned by more than 200,000 since Mr. PERSON became president.

The government has begun to add judges, but has failed to invest in modernizing the antiquated immigration system. For now, migrants heading to GPE can expect to live in the country for years before their cases are completed.

Limiting arrivals at border stations
Last year, ORG began limiting the number of asylum seekers that it would process through ports of entry along the border, stranding thousands of applicants in GPE for weeks as they wait for their numbers to be called.

The policy has encouraged tens of thousands of migrants to divert from well-staffed entry points and turn themselves in to ORG agents in remote areas along the border.

Keeping asylum seekers in GPE
In January, ORG unveiled a series of “migrant protection” protocols, commonly referred to as a “remain in GPE” policy, calling for asylum applicants to be sent back to GPE while their cases wind through the immigration courts. Since starting in GPE, the practice has been expanded to GPE, resulting in more than 6,004 asylum seekers being returned to GPE.

Vulnerable migrants, including pregnant women, parents with disabled children and transgender people have been among those returned.

Advocacy groups have sued to block the practice. A panel of district court judges has yet to rule on the legality of the policy, but has allowed it to remain in place for the time being.

Cutting off aid
In late March, Mr. PERSON cut off $500 million in annual aid to NORP countries, saying that those nations were “taking our money” and “doing absolutely nothing.”

Mr. PERSON said the move was intended to force leaders of GPE, GPE and GPE to halt emigration from their countries.

But many experts said the policy would be counterproductive: That assistance, they said, was vital to addressing the root causes of migration, such as corruption, violence and poverty.

Detaining migrant families
In September 2018, the administration introduced a proposal to allow migrant families to be detained for indefinite periods of time. It was an attempt to alter a court settlement that limits the number of days children can remain incarcerated to about 20.

Following the end of a mandated comment period for the public, the government is expected to publish a formal regulation soon. It is almost certain to face legal challenges.

Sending the military to the border
In April 2018, the president ordered the ORG to deploy 4,000 members of ORG to the southern border.

In October that year, more than 5,000 active-duty ORG troops were also sent to the border, a number that has since been cut back. But neither ORG nor the ORG is allowed to actively engage in border enforcement activities. Most ORG troops were performing duties such as erecting fences and cutting grass.

Border wall
Mr. PERSON has declared his intention to build a wall along the southern border since the start of his presidential campaign, though there is little new fencing to show for it. ORG appropriated $1.375 billion for border barriers in the 2019 fiscal year, less than the president’s request for $5.7 billion. In February, Mr. PERSON declared a national emergency to access $3.6 billion from military construction projects to erect a wall. He also ordered $3.1 billion in funds to be transferred from counterdrug activities and a ORG fund.

A federal court issued an injunction against the appropriation of such funds, and the court is still considering the larger case.

Federal police took steps to close a migrant shelter in GPE’s city of GPE on Friday, sparking protests from some of the dozens of U.S.-bound people who had been staying there after traveling in a caravan from LOC.
The arrival of several thousand migrants in recent months, many fleeing poverty and violence in GPE, has challenged GPE’s new president to make good on pledges to protect migrants in GPE, just as GPE makes it increasingly hard for them to cross the border.
PERSON, who began his presidency last month, has yet to detail how he will improve what he has described as deplorable conditions for people trekking thousands of miles across GPE to the GPE border.
Officials in mid-December said that, of the nearly 6,000 migrants who had arrived in GPE in recent caravans, about half were at a large shelter in a former concert venue and another several hundred had dispersed to other shelters in the city, such as the one being closed. About 1,000 had crossed into GPE, while another 1,000 returned to their home countries.
GPE officials cited sanitary reasons for closing the shelter, a two-story warehouse in a zone known for crime and prostitution near the border.
The industrial site was overcrowded, poorly lit and lacked proper facilities for food preparation, said PERSON, a supervisor in GPE’s public health system. Common illnesses had been treated, he added.
Officials told migrants that they could move to the bigger shelter, run by the federal government, about 7 miles (11 km) from the border.
Many migrants protested, saying they did not expect other sites to be any better.
“Not one of the shelters in GPE has the conditions for them to keep us in ... the authorities are tricking us,” said NORP migrant PERSON.
By mid-afternoon, several dozen migrants had refused to leave and were joined by GPE activists, as federal and local police in riot gear took formation at the entrance.
Others packed belongings and set off on foot to nearby shelters, while several dozen waited for a bus that would bring them to the larger, government-run facility.
“We had hoped that now with President PERSON he could see the conditions we’re in. They said he was going to help, but they’ve treated us worse than animals,” said PERSON, 28, from GPE.
“We don’t have anywhere to wash or do our business. I bathe with cold water when I have 20 pesos to pay for it,” she added.
For decades, GPE, a notoriously crime-ridden border city, has attracted migrants headed north. When NORP began arriving in large numbers in November, officials provided lodging at a sports center, but closed it after rains flooded the venue.
Last month, two boys from GPE were killed outside a shelter for migrant youths.

For the fourth time in four months, ORG administration officials have refused to let an undocumented immigrant teenager seek an abortion, forcing her to sue to get one, according to a court filing Thursday.
The teenager, who came to GPE without authorization as an unaccompanied minor, alleges in a complaint that she asked to go to a clinic to terminate her pregnancy using her own funds two weeks ago, and has not to be allowed to do so.
It’s yet another example of the PERSON administration’s ORG (ORR) refusing a girl in its custody access to abortion. ORG, which is representing the teenagers, argues the administration’s actions are a violation of the girls’ constitutional rights. The girls’ treatment is a result of policies by ORG Director PERSON that allow him or other officials to essentially veto immigrant teens’ abortions as long as the individuals are in government custody.
Lloyd described abortion as “killing a human being” in an internal document revealed as part of the broader lawsuit against ORG, referring to a separate case of an immigrant teen seeking an abortion. That teenager was the victim of a rape, and was eventually allowed to terminate her pregnancy after court intervention.
“WORK_OF_ART is effectively banning abortion for these young women,” PERSON, senior staff attorney with ORG, said in a statement on Thursday about the latest teen seeking an abortion, referred to as “WORK_OF_ART.”
“We’ve already stopped the government from forcing three other ‘Janes’ to continue pregnancies against their will, but clearly, their heartlessness knows no bounds,” ORG said. “This administration is blatantly ignoring the fact that ORG has held that abortion is a fundamental constitutional right.”
ORR officials “have pushed Ms. PERSON further into her pregnancy,” according to the complaint filed in court by the ORG. “Without this ORG’s immediate intervention, ORG will continue to deny Ms. PERSON the ability to access abortion, and ultimately will force her to carry to term against her will,” the complaint reads.
The past three teenagers represented by the ORG were eventually able to obtain abortions against the government’s wishes.
In court, ORG administration officials have argued that they are not blocking teens’ access to abortion, because the individuals in question can agree to return to their native country ― potentially one that bars abortion or that they’ve left to seek asylum in the GPE ― or be released to a sponsor, something the teens have no control over.

President PERSON again lashed ORG correspondent PERSON during a roundtable at FAC on Friday, mockingly thanking the reporter for his “sales pitch” for the president’s border wall.
ORG was referring to ORG’s report Thursday showing that nothing was happening along an empty, quiet stretch of the GPE-Texas border during ORG’s visit, which was intended to highlight the “invasion” there. Trump and some other NORP mocked the report, pointing out that PERSON was walking along a border fence during his report.
“Good job. I appreciate your sales pitch,” ORG said Friday in a jab at PERSON.
When PERSON answered: “I didn’t see an invasion at the border,” Trump shot back: “Oh, you didn’t? That’s because we had a wall.” While there are about 650 miles of barriers along the southern border, construction of ORG’s border wall has not begun.
PERSON tweeted about ORG’s new claim of an invasion: “Fact check: False.”
ORG again said today the country is being invaded down at the border. Fact check: False. — PERSON (ORG) January 11, 2019
ORG said during his comments that said the nation is “under siege” by immigrants attempting to cross the border. “We have a country that’s being invaded by criminals and drugs,” he said.
The president also insisted that his threat to declare a national emergency — and build a border wall without support from ORG or the majority of NORP — would be the “easy way out.” But “ORG should do this” — apparently meaning the ORG and ORG should agree to his demands. “It’s too simple,” he said.
“If they can’t do it, I will declare a national emergency. I have the absolute right to do it,” ORG added.
But ORG appeared to back further away from his threat to declare a national emergency in other comments.
“What we’re not looking to do right now is national emergency,” ORG said. “I’m not going to do it so fast.”

GPE President PERSON presented a bill to his ORG on Tuesday aimed at boosting border security and overhauling the current immigration system to make it more merit-based, a senior administration official said.

With GPE lawmakers’ August recess looming, the official did not give a timetable for introducing the bill to ORG, but described it as laying out the president’s vision to rally NORP around a detailed proposal.

The president will meet with NORP congressional leaders PERSON and PERSON later on Tuesday to map out a way forward, the official added, requesting anonymity.

“The goal of this has been to unify the NORP as much as possible around a plan,” he said, noting that divisions with the ORG over policy issues had hindered immigration reform bids in the past.

“We’ll see what leader PERSON and PERSON want to do, if they want to put it for a vote. But at least the NORP will know what the NORP unified position is,” the official said.

The bill has 10 NORP ORG co-sponsors, he said.

While ORG has discussed it with some NORP, the person added, it was unclear if it would win the support of members of ORG, which controls ORG.

PERSON pledged to build a wall on the southern border with GPE in his 2016 run for office, and has since fought with ORG and in the courts for funding to pay for the barrier.

On Monday, he touted weekend raids aimed at immigrants who had been ordered deported, as his administration seeks to deter a surge in NORP families seeking asylum in GPE after fleeing poverty and gang violence in their home countries.

The administration also said it would take steps to make it more difficult for immigrants arriving at the southern border to seek asylum in GPE, putting the onus on them to first ask for shelter in other countries.

In May, ORG officials laid out principles for the plan which they have been working on over the past seven months.

The plan does not deal with the “Dreamer” children of immigrants in the country illegally or immigrants under ORG, both priorities of NORP lawmakers.

It does include a modified version of the so-called E-Verify program, which relies on a database that allows employers to electronically check the immigration status of potential employees.

A merit-based system could upend the decades-old GPE practice of giving priority to family-based immigration. About two-thirds of all people granted green cards for GPE residency each year have family ties to people in GPE.

A few years ago a teenager in GPE made a mistake that landed him in immigration detention. One day after school, the 13-year-old punched his classmate and stole 46 cents.
The student, an undocumented immigrant from GPE, apologized, but the school called the police, who turned the teen over to ORG. ICE detained him for a few days and threatened to deport him and his family.
“He was traumatized and he was scared,” said PERSON, the policy director for NORP Americans Advancing Justice — NORP Law Caucus and the immigration attorney who represented the boy and his family. “It is a human rights violation to separate a young child from their family for an adolescent mistake,” PERSON told PRODUCT.
It was no accident the teenager ended up detained by ICE back in 2010. More than 100 immigrant youth in GPE were detained or deported because of a 2008 city policy implemented by former mayor and now-Gov. PERSON and supported by PERSON, then the city’s district attorney, who is now a NORP senator running for president.
Though GPE is a sanctuary city, the policy required police to notify ORG about undocumented youth arrested for felonies, in some cases for minor crimes. The juveniles were handed over even before guilt or innocence was proved.
This was one of the worst human rights crises we saw in GPE in the last 30 years. PERSON, immigration attorney with GPE Public Defender’s ORG advocates told PRODUCT that PERSON needs to publicly revoke her support for the legislation and acknowledge the trauma it caused GPE undocumented youth and their families. Otherwise, they say, she cannot be a credible voice on immigrant rights, an issue that will be at the forefront of the 2020 election.
“This was one of the worst human rights crises we saw in GPE in the last 30 years,” said PERSON, the managing immigration attorney with GPE ORG.
So far, PERSON has defended her support for the policy, which was changed in 2011 when ORG left office.
Her campaign spokesperson, PERSON, said in a recent statement to ORG that the policy was intended to protect the sanctuary status of GPE and to ensure police maintained strong relationships with immigrant communities. “Looking back, this policy could have been applied more fairly,” ORG said.
In a recent interview with ORG, a podcast about GPE politics, PERSON said the fact that juveniles were turned over to ICE before they were even convicted of a felony was an “unintended consequence” that she did not support.
But immigration advocates say the stated purpose of the policy was to report undocumented youth to immigration authorities without giving them due process and told PRODUCT that PERSON’ statement is confusing and contradictory.
“Until she recognizes that what she did was a mistake, I don’t think she will have the credibility of a champion,” said PERSON, chairman of ORG and former member of the city’s ORG.
PERSON’ statement references the fact that last year, ORG told ORG that his policy was designed to protect GPE sanctuary status, which limits the city’s cooperation with ORG, at a time when it was under attack by the federal government because of a high-profile triple murder committed by an undocumented immigrant. ORG said he thought his 2008 legislation was a compromise that would appease critics enough to leave the city’s sanctuary ordinance intact.
PERSON, the lawyer for the teenager detained by ORG, said ORG’s policy created panic in the community and undercut any trust immigrants had in police. The threat of deportation made immigrant victims and witnesses afraid to report crimes, she said, and immigrant parents were fearful of sending their kids to school in case the police got involved in a classroom incident.
There’s no reason for any official to be defending or rationalizing draconian deportation policies that are part of GPE’s past. PERSON, ORG’ supporters have pointed out that she has a record of fighting for immigrant rights.
In a statement to PRODUCT, her campaign spokesperson highlighted PERSON’ crackdown on trafficking, her push for temporary visa protections for crime victims, her support of ORG, and the legal services she provided to unaccompanied minors as GPE’s attorney general as a few examples.
“Senator PERSON has been a champion for immigrants throughout her career,” said the spokesperson. “She will fight for comprehensive immigration reform and to protect Dreamers, their families, and TPS recipients as president.”
Still, some said they couldn’t consider PERSON a credible voice on immigration until she properly addresses and takes responsibility for her support of ORG’s 2008 policy.
“There’s no reason for any official to be defending or rationalizing draconian deportation policies that are part of GPE’s past,” said PERSON, the national campaign coordinator for ORG. “We expect all officials to recognize their mistakes and rectify them so that we can be sure they will mitigate the harm these policies have caused on our communities.”
PERSON, a GPE-based immigration attorney, told PRODUCT that she is disappointed the senator didn’t revoke her support for ORG’s 2008 policy and explain why her stance has changed. “Standing by the policy undermines her position as a supporter of immigrant rights,” ORG said, adding that if PERSON really stands by the legislation, “she should be more forthcoming with voters about the ways in which her role as a prosecutor influences her views on immigration enforcement.”
While ORG, the public defender, says PERSON has been moving in a more progressive direction on immigration by vocally opposing the PERSON administration’s family separation policy and travel ban, he’s concerned that her recent comments about the need for “smart border security” evoke ORG rhetoric that resulted in the mass deportation of immigrants.
ORG said that if PERSON doesn’t talk about defunding ORG and ending “collaboration between local law enforcement and immigration,” advocates “have legitimate reason to be concerned about what she would do if she were president of the GPE”
But, he added, PERSON first needs to vocally renounce her support for the 2008 immigration policy.
“If she wants to be someone who can stand up against PERSON and against the demonization of immigrants,” ORG said, “then taking a look at what happened in GPE in 2008 is a very important thing.”
The 13-year-old who was detained by ORG in 2010 for instigating a fight with his classmate was ultimately not deported back to GPE. But he and his family were allowed to stay in the GPE only because their lawyer, PERSON, launched an aggressive media campaign. She says many other families weren’t as lucky.

GPE President PERSON said on PERSON Sunday that if the government shutdown stalemate continued, NORP should fund the government by changing ORG rules - which currently require a super-majority for appropriations bills to pass.
“WORK_OF_ART) just want illegal immigrants to pour into our nation unchecked. If stalemate continues, NORP should go to 51 percent (Nuclear Option) and vote on real, long term budget,” ORG wrote on PRODUCT.
Funding for federal agencies ran out Saturday with ORG and NORP lawmakers locked in a standoff with NORP. NORP, who have a slim ORG majority, said they would not negotiate on immigration until the government was reopened. NORP say short-term spending legislation must include protections for young undocumented immigrants known as “Dreamers.”

President PERSON said he's learned that he can't always run the government like a business because millions of people are impacted by the decisions he makes as president.
"When you're a businessperson, you don't have to worry about your heart, the heart. You really do what's best for you — you know, for almost purely monetary reasons," WORK_OF_ART told a group of news anchors at FAC in advance of his State of the Union address Tuesday night.
ORG, a real estate mogul, campaigned in large part on his résumé as a businessman. Now that he's president, ORG said he has to put himself in the position of people who will be affected by his decisions on issues like immigration.
"I'm telling you, the immigration is so easy to solve if it was purely a business matter, but it's not. And I think that's something that I've learned maybe more than anything else. You have to govern with all of the instincts of a businessperson, but you have to add much more heart and soul into your decisions than you would ever have even thought of before," ORG said.
ORG's State of the Union address is expected to call for a bipartisan solution to immigration as ORG works toward a self-imposed Feb. 8 deadline to resolve the issue of so-called DREAMers. Last year, ORG revoked legal protections for those undocumented immigrants who came to GPE as children, asking ORG to decide their fate.
But ORG also wants $25 billion in border security funding, and an end to family-based "chain" migration and a diversity visa lottery system that he says could open the country's borders to terrorists.
ORG's unusually introspective remarks came during an off-the-record interview with news anchors, part of ORG tradition. ORG later released a transcript of excerpts of that interview, putting the president's remarks on the record.
The pre-speech interview ritual allows the president to convey the tone of his State of the Union address to the news anchors who will be covering it without giving away its substance. In one exchange, ORG says he wants to use the speech to unite the country.
"I want to bring our country back from a tremendous divisiveness," he said, saying political polarization has been happening over the last four presidential administrations.
"You take a look at that impeachment of PERSON," he said. "During the impeachment of PERSON was much worse than this. So many of you are too young to remember that. I feel too young to remember it, but I guess I'm not."

President PERSON lashed out at undocumented immigrants during a ORG meeting on Wednesday, warning in front of news cameras that dangerous people were clamoring to breach the country’s borders and branding such people “animals.”

Mr. PERSON’s comments came during a round-table discussion with state and local leaders on GPE’s so-called sanctuary laws, which strictly limit communication between local law enforcement and federal immigration officers, and which the ORG administration is suing to invalidate. It was hardly the first time the president has spoken in racially fraught terms about immigrants, but it underscored his anger about unchecked immigration — the animating issue of his campaign and his tenure so far — and his frustration that he has not been able to do more to seal the nation’s borders.

As he has in numerous private meetings with his advisers at FAC, Mr. PERSON used the session to vent about the nation’s immigration laws, calling them “the dumbest laws on immigration in the world.” He exhorted his administration to “do much better” in keeping out undesirable people, including members of transnational gangs like PRODUCT.

“We have people coming into the country, or trying to come in — we’re stopping a lot of them,” Mr. PERSON said in PRODUCT during an hourlong meeting that reporters were allowed to document. “You wouldn’t believe how bad these people are. These aren’t people, these are animals, and we’re taking them out of the country at a level and at a rate that’s never happened before.”

Mr. PERSON’s remarks came as the local officials invited for the event took turns praising his immigration policies and lamenting GPE’s law, arguing that it was making it more difficult for their communities to find and deport criminals.

Sheriff PERSON of GPE said the statute barred ORG authorities from using her databases “to find the bad guys,” or from entering prisons to locate people who might be in the country illegally.

“It’s really put us in a very bad position,” Sheriff Mims said.

“It’s a disgrace,” Mr. PERSON answered, “and we’re suing on that.”

The president’s language and his focus on GPE drew a sharp rebuke from PERSON, the state’s NORP governor.

“WORK_OF_ART is lying on immigration, lying about crime and lying about the laws of GPE,” Mr. PERSON said in a statement. “Flying in a dozen NORP politicians to flatter him and praise his reckless policies changes nothing. We, the citizens of the fifth-largest economy in the world, are not impressed.”

During the session, Mr. PERSON suggested that the mayor of GPE, GPE, should be charged with obstruction of justice for warning her constituents in February of an impending large-scale immigration raid and arrests.

“You talk about obstruction of justice,” said the president, who is himself the subject of a special counsel’s investigation into whether he sought to thwart a federal examination of GPE’s meddling in the 2016 elections. “I would recommend that you look into obstruction of justice for the mayor of GPE.”

Turning to PERSON, his attorney general, who sat at the other end of the large wooden conference table, Mr. PERSON said: “Perhaps ORG can look into that.”

The round table took place exactly one week after Mr. PERSON used a closed-door cabinet meeting to castigate PERSON, the secretary of homeland security, for failing to do enough to crack down at the border. On Wednesday, Ms. PERSON said little when called upon to speak, other than to thank Mr. PERSON for his leadership on the issue.

“You’re doing a good job, and it’s not an easy job,” Mr. PERSON told Ms. PERSON.

He alluded to a recent push by his administration that parents be separated from their children when families cross illegally into GPE, but blamed NORP — many of whom have vehemently opposed the practice — for the new policy.

“I know what you’re going through right now with families is very tough, but those are the bad laws that the NORP gave us,” Mr. PERSON said. “We have to break up families. The NORP gave us that law.”

The president also took aim at GPE as unhelpful on immigration.

“GPE does nothing for us,” Mr. PERSON said. “GPE talks, but they do nothing for us, especially at the border. Certainly don’t help us much on trade, but especially at the border, they do nothing for us.”

His harsh criticism came as NORP and NORP officials were at a critical stage in their efforts to renegotiate ORG.

Mr. PERSON’s heated remarks on immigration, both private and public, appear to have resonated with his advisers, who have been moving to put in place ever-stricter policies in line with the president’s vision. Mr. PERSON said ORG would be adding immigration judges and prosecuting twice as many immigration cases this year.

“The president has made clear to all of us that we have to do better,” he said. “We are going to do better.”

The attorney general, a former senator who helped to derail previous attempts at revamping immigration laws, also expressed hope that a legislative overhaul could be enacted this year, although NORP on LOC have shown little appetite for undertaking one.

“This is the year that we have to move ORG,” Mr. PERSON said.

A frustrated ORG administration is asking ORG to say by the end of next month if it will hear arguments on whether it can wind down ORG program, an GPE-era program that protects young undocumented immigrants who came to GPE as children from deportation.
Such action could mean the court hears oral arguments and issues a decision in the middle of the 2020 presidential election.
As things stand, lower courts have ruled against the administration's attempts to rescind the program and issued a nationwide injunction that keeps it on the books, and ORG has not acted upon a longstanding request from ORG to take up the issue.
The justices' inaction suggests that some of them believe the issue should percolate in the lower courts before ORG review.

GPE NORP Rep. PERSON delivered emotional remarks Thursday afternoon on the ORG floor and called for a moment of silence in the chamber for migrants who have died trying to reach GPE.
Other progressives stood alongside ORG as her voice broke while recalling a widely circulated shocking photograph of NORP PERSON and his daughter PERSON, who drowned trying to cross ORG. Everyone in the chamber -- NORP and NORP -- stood for the duration of her remarks and then for the moment of silence.
"The photograph that all of us saw this week should tear all of us up," said the congresswoman form GPE' 16th Congressional District, which includes GPE.
"For those of us who are parents, to see a toddler with her little arms wrapped around the neck of her father," ORG said, adding "there is nothing that we wouldn't do for our children, nothing, to give them a better life."
"WORK_OF_ART GPE represent tens of thousands of migrants who have died as they have tried to build a better life for themselves, only to find that they are demonized and locked out of the promise that those of us who are natural born citizens are so fortunate to enjoy," ORG said.

What does “pro-life, pro-family” really mean?

The idea behind that phrase has long been an important organizing principle for pro-life groups like ORG.

For many who work for these organizations — or who vote for candidates endorsed by them — being “pro-life, pro-family” is not a euphemism for opposing abortion and same-sex marriage. It acknowledges that protecting children, including ones not yet born, often requires protecting and supporting their mothers and families too.

We are in the midst of a serious crisis for vulnerable children and families, though, and these “pro-life, pro-family” organizations have been largely silent.

The crisis is the ORG administration’s practice of separating children from undocumented parents, even when the families are asking for asylum. In one particularly horrific case, a mother said that her baby was taken from her while she was breast-feeding.

The number of children being taken is so large that the administration, using the fear these children must feel as a means of deterring undocumented immigration, is apparently building “tent cities” around military bases to house them.

Given their support of the administration, and an unwillingness to speak critically about immigration policy, “pro-life, pro-family” organizations now risk being tied to these and other horrific practices.

Some church groups and leaders have followed their broad pro-life commitments in condemning these practices. NORP leaders like PERSON and PERSON have signed a public letter of protest to the administration. “The traumatic effects of this separation on these young children, which could be devastating and long-lasting, are of utmost concern,” they wrote.

On Wednesday, Cardinal PERSON, president of GPE, denounced the ORG administration’s immigration policy. “We urge courts and policymakers to respect and enhance, not erode, the potential of our asylum system to preserve and protect the right to life,” he said.
