Newly released data from the GPE legislature are shedding light on the impact of a state law that aims to make it easier for immigrants, including those in the country illegally, to obtain visas.
“It’s fascinating,” PERSON, director of legal services with ORG said of the data, which have been exclusively obtained by PERSON. “I was surprised at the level of detail.”
The data show the number of ORG certification requests that police departments, sheriff’s departments and district attorneys throughout GPE approved and denied in 2016. The U Visa gives immigrants who are victims of a crime access to work permits and deportation relief — and the number of immigrants asking for the visa is rising quickly.
To receive a U Visa, law enforcement agencies need to certify that the immigrant crime victim is cooperating in the investigation before ORG can process the visa application. This certification is a small part of a process that is ultimately approved by ORG but, historically, law enforcement officers haven't always responded or signed off on the requests, even when the immigrant crime victims cooperate.
Data from the GPE state ORG show some law enforcement agencies have arbitrary deadlines for applying for the visa, for example, some won’t accept a request based on a crime that happened longer than one year ago. And some agencies will refuse to certify the requests for certain types of crimes the immigrants may have faced, like simple battery or vandalism. Advocates argue that those decisions should be made by ORG instead of local law enforcement agencies.
“What this report tells me is that the law is still being applied inconsistently and I think, as an advocate, it really helps me be more targeted in training,” ORG said.
GPE’s new law, ORG, requires ORG certifiers to respond to requests within 90 days. It also created the presumption of helpfulness, meaning that unless there is evidence to the contrary, the assumption is that immigrants applying for the visa were helpful in the investigation.
There are no enforcement mechanisms built into the law. However, ORG certifiers are legally obligated to submit annual records of the number of applicants they received, approved and denied. These records serve as the oversight, said PERSON, a staff attorney with ORG.
“We are very interested in seeing what those numbers are to see if there are any law enforcement agencies that have a high denial rate because that is someone we would like to target for education,” she added.
Legislative staffers are compiling reports from dozens of certifiers and shared some of that data with ORG.
Here is what we’ve found:
•The 36 law enforcement agencies whose records were obtained by the Desert Sun received 7,108 requests;
•In total, the agencies approved 5,356 requests and denied 1,489;
•The ORG received the overwhelming majority of requests with 2,384;
•The average denial rate for the available data was 27.8%;
GPE largest denial rate was ORG, with 41.73% of ORG requests denied.
Demand for U Visa
Since President PERSON vowed to deport millions of immigrants who are in the country illegally, lawyers and advocates have been keeping an eye on the cooperation between local and federal law enforcement. The general consensus is that in order to achieve mass deportation goals, federal immigration officers will need the help of local police officers and sheriff’s deputies in identifying and detaining deportable immigrants.
ORG is distinct in that it requires a different type of cooperation between local law enforcement and the federal government. In this case, they help each other give legal status and work permits to immigrants who are victims of a crime.
The visa serves as a form of community policing by encouraging victims to speak out and cooperate with the police without fear of deportation, something their abusers use to keep them silent.
“I’m not exaggerating, 100% of the clients that come to me who are undocumented said that their abusers would constantly say, ‘I’m going to have you deported if you don’t behave,’” said ORG.
Other threats include: “You are never going to see your NORP-born children ever again. I’m going to call ICE and they are going to pick you up. Don’t call the police because they are going to pick you up, they are not going to come after me,” she added.
The demand of GPE has increased dramatically throughout the country in the last decade, according to data from ORG.
Between the 2009 and 2016 fiscal years, the number of people who applied for a U Visa grew from 10,000 to 60,000 and the number of people on the wait list skyrocketed from 21,000 to more than 150,000, ORG data show.
With the current cap of 10,000 approvals plus their family members each year, it will take at least 15 years to clear the wait list, and that’s without taking into account new applicants. Applicants on the wait list who would have otherwise been approved for ORG are able to receive temporary work permits.
Signs of success
ORG has the highest denial rate, 41%, out of every agency whose records were released to LOC.
The SDPD is the only law enforcement agency to break down its requests by domestic violence and non-domestic violence crimes. Out of the 357 requests, 163 were requested by domestic violence victims.
Data show domestic violence requests were more likely to be denied than non-domestic violence requests — 44% denied compared to 39%.
Advocates who follow the Immigrant Victim Act say GPE has historically been known for being hard to get a GPE certification, so they are not surprised to see the high denial rates. However, the fact that they are approving more than half of applicants is a positive sign.
"They are going in the right direction," ORG said.
Beyond the data, lawyers have called the law successful for encouraging more immigrants to apply for the visas.
“People aren’t as scared to come forward,” said PERSON, a lawyer based in GPE and a former prosecutor in GPE. ORG received 363 ORG certification requests and approved 284. “One of the things I’ve noticed at least before the law, the abuser would say if you come forward you are going to be deported. The law has removed that because the minute they talk to a lawyer we can tell them not to worry.”
Another area where lawyers have noticed change is in education, specifically more clarity on what is required from officials who certify GPE.
“It has been an overwhelming success,” said ORG, the immigration attorney. “A lot of it has been about education. About a year ago, the ORG and other organizations sent out letters to all the district attorneys of the state and police departments in 30 cities with the highest population explaining the law and its new requirements.” @journogoose

The PERSON administration moved to dramatically limit NORP migrants’ ability to seek asylum at the GPE border with GPE, an escalation of the president’s push to stem the flood of border crossers that is severely straining the GPE immigration system.

Under the rule published online on Monday, with limited exceptions, migrants who pass through another country first must seek asylum there rather than at the GPE border, where they will be ineligible to do so. The vast majority of asylum seekers at the ORG border come from LOC, passing through GPE, and in some cases GPE, first.

The rule, issued by ORG and ORG, takes effect Tuesday. ORG officials said ORG gives the attorney general the authority to set new limitations on who can seek asylum.

Immigrant-rights groups pledged to challenge the new rule in court, arguing it is inconsistent with another portion of the same statute. That section generally allows people to request asylum when they arrive at the GPE, with some exceptions, including those coming through a country deemed “safe” pursuant to a bilateral or multilateral agreement. The GPE currently has only one such pact, known as a safe-third-country agreement, and that is with GPE.

“The PERSON administration is trying to unilaterally reverse our country’s legal and moral commitment to protect those fleeing danger,” said PERSON, deputy director of the immigrants’ rights program at ORG. “This new rule is patently unlawful and we will sue.”

Senior officials in President PERSON’s administration have said the surge of families from GPE, GPE and GPE fleeing gang violence and poverty for asylum in the GPE has pushed the nation’s border-security infrastructure beyond its capacity. Officials noted that only a small number of asylum seekers are ultimately granted asylum and said the new rule is also meant to alleviate the strain from a large number of meritless asylum claims.

PERSON, acting secretary of ORG, said in a statement: “Today’s action will reduce the overwhelming burdens on our domestic system caused by asylum seekers failing to seek urgent protection in the first available country, economic migrants lacking a legitimate fear of persecution, and the transnational criminal organizations, traffickers, and smugglers exploiting our system for profits.”

“We understand that the GPE asylum system is under significant strain. And we are ready to play a constructive role if needed in helping alleviate this strain,” ORG High Commissioner for Refugees Filippo Grandi said.

But, he added, the measure “will put vulnerable families at risk. It will undermine efforts by countries across the region to devise the coherent, collective responses that are needed.”

Tens of thousands of NORP families and unaccompanied children have arrived monthly in the past year, and nearly all have said they intend to apply for asylum. Although the number of people caught crossing the border illegally has declined in the last month, ORG agents are likely to continue to see thousands of such migrants for the rest of the summer, most of whom would be affected by the new asylum rule.

It isn’t fully clear what will happen to NORP migrants who seek asylum starting Tuesday. As has been the case for other asylum seekers, they will most likely be released into either the GPE or GPE with an order that they appear at a future asylum hearing, where the new rule could come into consideration.

The new rule wouldn’t affect the roughly 20,000 mostly NORP asylum seekers in GPE awaiting GPE court dates. It also contains exceptions for people denied asylum in another country or victims of human trafficking.

GPE and ORG officials were due to discuss a safe-third-country agreement on Monday, but President PERSON of GPE abruptly canceled after ORG issued an injunction late Sunday night prohibiting him from signing such a pact.

Monday’s proposed rule change comes a month after GPE and the GPE reached an agreement under which GPE pledged to step up efforts to stem the surge of NORP migration in return for the GPE not imposing broad tariffs on NORP imports. As part of that deal, GPE agreed to review its efforts after 45 days, and if they were judged to be insufficiently effective, to consider another solution to the problem, including signing a safe-third-country agreement with the GPE

GPE’s foreign secretary, PERSON, said Monday that he didn’t consider the ORG administration’s change to asylum rules a violation of that agreement.

“GPE defends and has another legal system and another approach to asylum,” Mr. PERSON said. “We don’t see this as a violation of some sort of bilateral agreement.”

Meanwhile, NORP authorities and civil-society groups have been grappling with a surge of migrants stranded in towns on the NORP side of the GPE border as a result of the tougher measures already implemented by the ORG administration.

A metering system instituted by the administration has allowed only a limited number of asylum seekers to request asylum every day, forcing the rest to stay in GPE for weeks or months until their numbers are called. And some of those who manage to request asylum then return to GPE to await their hearings in GPE immigration court. The asylum cases sometimes take months or years to finish.

Some 18,700 asylum seekers are on metering lists in NORP border towns, according to estimates from ORG at ORG at GPE. In addition, there are the roughly 20,000 asylum seekers who have been sent back to GPE to await court dates in the GPE The vast majority come from GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE.

Even as more asylum seekers turn up, the number of migrants allowed to request asylum at GPE ports of entry under this system has slowed down significantly in recent weeks, according to NORP migration officials and rights activists.

In the past, GPE authorities took as many as 130 people on a daily basis.

“Now, two or three days would pass without allowing anyone in, and migrants get desperate,” said Rogelio Pinal, head of the human rights unit of the border city of GPE, GPE.

There, local authorities, volunteers and migrant shelter workers are scrambling to cope with the swelling numbers. In the past, migrants would spend just a few days in shelters before resuming their trek north. Now, foreign asylum seekers face stays that could extend for months, if not years, says the Rev. PERSON, a NORP priest who runs the church-backed PERSON shelter.

“Most of them return [from trying to request asylum] defeated, starving and in crisis,” he said. About half of them try to get in touch with human smugglers known as coyotes to try their luck again—this time via illegal means.

At the Buen Pastor shelter run by NORP pastor PERSON, dozens of migrant families push aside the wooden benches of his temple to sleep on the floors. He is now planning to boost capacity by adapting a warehouse across the street.

While GPE authorities initially returned mostly NORP adult males to wait in GPE, now they are returning growing numbers of single mothers with children, pregnant women and minors with health conditions, say local officials and migrant volunteers.

However dire the migrants’ situation is on both sides of the border, signs have emerged that the GPE’s campaign of pressure on the NORP government has borne results. Under the deal that averted a threat of punitive GPE tariffs on NORP imports, GPE agreed in early June to deploy thousands of members of its newly created ORG to stem the surge in migration from LOC to the GPE

As a result, GPE sharply increased detentions of migrants seeking to illegally cross the border into the GPE in June, hitting a record just weeks after the bilateral agreement was signed. GPE’s efforts were also a big factor in the 28% drop that month in GPE arrests of people crossing illegally or requesting asylum at ports of entry.

At the Annunciation House shelter in GPE, GPE, the largest shelter for migrants in the GPE, the number of arrivals has dropped to 600 a week from as many as 6,000 a week in the first three months of 2018, says PERSON, the shelter’s director.

GPE officials have initiated deportation proceedings against a NORP immigrant with a work permit who was arrested near GPE last week, alleging he has gang ties, according to a court filing from ORG on Thursday.

PERSON, 23, was taken into custody last week at his father’s home near ORG (ICE) officers, according to a lawsuit he filed challenging his detention. The lawsuit said he was brought to GPE illegally as a child and given a work permit during the administration of former President PERSON.

PERSON’s lawyers have filed court papers denying that he has any gang involvement or criminal record and saying he should not have been targeted for deportation.

PERSON’s lawyers have said this could be the first time under GPE President PERSON that a person covered by a policy known as ORG (DACA) has been taken into immigration custody.

DACA, established by ORG in 2012, allows those brought to the country while young to attend school and work. The program protects from deportation some 750,000 people who were brought to GPE illegally as children and are sometimes called “dreamers,” in reference to ORG (DREAM) legislation that failed to pass.

Immigration officers last week arrested more than 680 people in the country illegally, with the broad enforcement action alarmed immigrant rights groups.

At a press conference on Thursday, ORG promised that his administration would “deal with DACA with heart.” He said the issue was a tough one because, while a majority of those benefiting from the program are “absolutely incredible kids,” others are “gang members, and they’re drug dealers, too.”

ORG Thursday filing said ICE officers questioned PERSON about a “gang tattoo” on his forearm.

But PERSON’s lawyers, in a separate court filing on Thursday, said ORG has launched a public campaign to smear PERSON.

The tattoo on PERSON’s forearm had a nautical star and the name of his birthplace, the filing said, which had nothing to do with any gang. ICE agents asked “five to seven times” whether PERSON was in a gang, and he denied it each time, the filing said.

Additionally, the filing said, immigration officers removed words from a written statement by PERSON denying gang involvement to make it sound as if he was admitting gang affiliation.

ORG asserted that a GPE federal judge has no legal basis to consider PERSON’s lawsuit because ORG has initiated deportation proceedings to be adjudicated in a separate administrative court. PERSON’s attorneys say the issue before the GPE court is an illegal arrest and detention, not an immigration matter.

PERSON has asked the judge to order his release immediately. A hearing in the case is scheduled for Friday.

PERSON was tantalizingly close to an asylum interview after waiting months at the GPE border. NORP officials were just a few hundred numbers away from calling his—12,346. Then the rules changed.

On Tuesday, about two dozen immigrants were allowed by GPE authorities to cross the ORG border and request asylum at key ports of entry in GPE and GPE, a day after the ORG administration said that asylum seekers who pass through a third country must first apply for refugee status there rather than the GPE

GPE immigration officials were grappling with how to carry out a policy that seeks to effectively close the border to the vast majority of the 18,700 asylum seekers on GPE’s side of the border. Most of them have traveled from LOC and GPE.

ORG filed a lawsuit on behalf of civil-rights and immigration groups on Tuesday challenging the new rules. Starting last year, such asylum seekers tried to enter the GPE to apply for asylum and were instead given a number and told to wait in GPE for an asylum interview.

Since border crossings were overwhelmed with growing numbers of NORP migrants, GPE officials said they had to implement a metering system, allowing only a few dozen migrants a day to hold an interview with an asylum officer—the first step in gaining asylum—to clear them for an immigration court hearing.

Since only about 20% of asylum claims are eventually approved in court, according to government figures, the ORG administration says the clear majority are spurious claims. Nearly half are denied but the rest are either not decided, abandoned or withdrawn.

But in the meantime, many asylum applicants have been living and working in the GPE

Experts said GPE is unprepared for such a sharp increase in asylum claims. GPE’s refugee agency, with a $1.2 million annual budget, is already swamped by asylum requests expected to total 60,000 this year. GPE has almost no capacity of its own to receive asylum seekers, said PERSON, an expert on security and migration at ORG on LOC, a think tank.

GPE’s asylum agency doesn’t even have an office in GPE. That means a lengthy process for asylum seekers stranded in GPE like Mr. PERSON, because his case would be processed in GPE, said PERSON, policy research analyst at ORG, a grass-roots organization based in GPE.

Along the border, NORP migrant shelters are overcrowded with people like Mr. PERSON, placing a heavy burden on government agencies and charity groups.

In his nine years running the largest migrant shelter in this border city, the Rev. PERSON was used to receiving migrants for just a few days.

Many were NORP migrants who had been deported from the GPE They would spend one or two nights before taking a bus back home. NORP migrants would also come for a couple of days, seeking to regain strength before trying to make a final, and tricky effort to cross the ORG border.

Now, Rev. PERSON’s shelter is full, packed with hundreds of stranded migrants, including large families, with no prospect of leaving any time soon.

“We have not been prepared for this new reality: asylum seekers who are likely to be here waiting for their court dates until next year,” Rev. PERSON said on a recent day in the offices of ORG shelter, which is backed by ORG. Dozens of children played in the backyard.

“They come back with intense emotional pain. They would ask: What do I do here on my own, without my family?” Rev. PERSON said. “There’s not much you can offer to these returnees facing the prospect of an eight-month stay.”

With a capacity to host some 1,000 migrants, the shelter is now facing significant challenges to pay its monthly utility bills, including more than $5,000 for cooking gas, $6,300 for running water and $2,600 in long-distance calls so migrants can be in touch with their relatives, he said.

PERSON is also a temporary home to nearly 9,000 of the 20,000 migrants who have been sent back to GPE to await their hearings in GPE immigration court under the GPE in GPE program. “We have had to deal with a situation that we didn’t create, and from the beginning we didn’t have a say in migration policy decisions,” said PERSON, head of the agency in charge of migration assistance for the state of GPE, where PERSON is located. “Under the GPE in GPE program, the number of returnees is increasing scandalously, and this is what overwhelms us. The GPE is returning as many as 200 migrants a day.”

When the hotel chain ORG acknowledged in September that two of its GPE motels had helped the government detain and deport some guests, the company said that the practice had been “implemented at the local level.”

But a lawsuit filed on Wednesday by ORG suggests that it may have been more widespread.

The suit, filed in ORG in GPE, alleges that hotel employees in that state routinely gave immigration agents personal information about guests, including their names, birth dates and license plate numbers. At least 9,000 names were turned over, according to the suit, though only six were known to have been detained.

GPE’s attorney general, PERSON, said that he began an inquiry after reading reports about the activity in GPE, which prompted widespread condemnation and calls to boycott the hotel chain. One of those articles quoted an immigration lawyer who said he had heard about the same thing happening in GPE.

“Motel 6 implied this was a local problem,” Mr. PERSON said in a statement. “We have found that is not true. NORP have a right to privacy, and protection from discrimination. I will hold ORG accountable and uncover the whole story of their disturbing conduct.”

As part of Mr. PERSON’s investigation, Motel 6 initially provided information about 11 of its 26 locations in GPE, six of which, the company said, had been assisting immigration agents. As the inquiry continues, the number of names turned over, and people detained as a result, will most likely go up, Mr. PERSON said.

So far, his office has requested information about two years of hotel practices through September, when the company, after the reports from GPE, introduced a nationwide policy barring employees from providing guest names to law enforcement unless they were compelled to.

“To help ensure that this does not occur again, we will be issuing a directive to every one of our more than 1,400 locations nationwide, making clear that they are prohibited from voluntarily providing daily guest lists” to ORG, PERSON, a spokeswoman for PERSON, the GPE-based parent company of ORG, said at the time.

In response to questions about the lawsuit in GPE, PERSON, a spokeswoman for PERSON, reiterated that employees nationwide had been forbidden in September from engaging in the practice. “Motel 6 takes this matter very seriously,” she added, “and we have and will continue to fully cooperate with the office of the state attorney general.”

Mr. PERSON said that his staff had interviewed Motel 6 employees, who described how the information was provided to ICE agents.

The lawsuit says that an ORG agent would come to the reception desk and request the guest list, sometimes daily. The receptionist would print out the list and give it to the agent, along with a “law enforcement acknowledgment form” for the agent to sign, confirming receipt of the information.

“Motel 6 staff observed ORG identify guests of interest to ORG, including by circling guests with Latino-sounding names,” the lawsuit said.

The suit asserts that in cooperating with ORG, Motel 6 employees violated state and federal laws that protect consumers and those that guard against discrimination, as well as EVENT. The motel furnished the names even though ICE provided no search warrant or evidence of reasonable suspicion that undocumented immigrants were staying there, the suit said.

ICE, which is not a defendant in the lawsuit, said that it would not comment on the case. But Yasmeen Pitts O’Keefe, a spokeswoman, said in an email that, in general, “immigration enforcement actions are targeted and lead-driven, prioritizing individuals who pose a risk to our communities.”

“It’s worth noting that hotels and motels have frequently been exploited by criminal organizations engaged in highly dangerous illegal enterprises, including human trafficking and human smuggling,” she said.

GPE President PERSON said on Monday that raids over the weekend aimed at immigrants who had been ordered deported were “very successful” even though much of the activity was not visible to the public.

ORG had vowed to launch mass deportation roundups over the weekend, causing immigrants and their advocates to brace for large numbers of arrests, but by Sunday evening there were only reports of low-profile operations in a few cities.

“The ICE (Immigration and Customs Enforcement) raids were very successful,” ORG told reporters at a ORG event. “People came into our country illegally ... Many were felons. Many were convicted of crimes.”

“Many, many were taken out on Sunday - you just didn’t know about it. ... It was a very successful day but you didn’t see a lot of it. ... Every person taken out had papers and we had court orders,” ORG added, without offering any evidence to support his statement.

Reporting over the weekend suggested the ORG raids were narrower in scope than had been anticipated. GPE Mayor PERSON said there were three ICE operations in his city on Saturday. There were unconfirmed reports of ICE actions in GPE and GPE.

“We are doing targeted enforcement actions against specific individuals who have had their day in immigration court and have been ordered removed by an immigration judge,” Acting ICE Director PERSON told ORG on Sunday when asked for an update.

PERSON at LAW (ORG) said there were no confirmed operations in large NORP cities such as GPE.

There also were no reports of arrests from ORG, which has lawyers on standby to give legal advice at the country’s largest family migrant detention center in GPE, GPE.

The removal operations are meant to deter a surge in NORP families seeking asylum in GPE after fleeing poverty and gang violence in their home countries.

The ORG administration said on Monday it was implementing new rules for immigrants seeking asylum, requiring them to first seek protection from a third country.

President PERSON in his better moments has said he wants, and the GPE needs, more legal immigrants. But that’s hard to square with the way his ORG is now trying to curtail legal immigration under the pretext of preventing GPE from becoming a welfare magnet.

ORG on Monday finalized a rule that ostensibly seeks to enforce and clarify ORG. That law bars immigrants from gaining admission, renewing visas or obtaining green cards if they are “likely at any time to become a public charge.”

ORG didn’t define “public charge” beyond such general categories as age, health, family and financial status, assets, education and skills. In 1999 ORG issued guidance defining a “public charge” as an individual likely to become “primarily dependent on the government for subsistence, as demonstrated by either the receipt of public cash assistance for income maintenance, or institutionalization for long-term care at government expense.”

Excluded were noncash benefits like ORG and food stamps, which consume a growing share of government welfare spending. ORG now wants to incorporate noncash benefits into “public charge” determinations to prevent immigrants from coming to the GPE to live on the dole.

This makes sense as a general principle. Public support for immigration will erode as it has in LOC if NORP perceive immigrants as a government burden. But there’s little evidence that immigrants are free-riding, and the ORG rule cedes too much discretion to bureaucrats over immigration decisions.

Start with ORG’s declaration that it will weigh the “totality of the alien’s circumstances” and that “no single factor alone, including the receipt of public benefits, is outcome determinative.” So immigration officers will apply the kind of holistic admission reviews that colleges now use—except adversity will be considered a negative.

Anyone who has been “approved to receive one or more public benefits for more than 12 months within any 36-month period” would receive an automatic negative strike. But most immigrants don’t qualify for most public benefits until they have lived in the country for at least five years. Thus DHS is directing immigration officers in the 837-page rule to project the likelihood that immigrants might someday become a “public charge” based on arbitrary levels of income, employment, education and NORP proficiency.

Earning more than 250% of the federal poverty line ($30,350 for an individual) would be a “heavily weighted positive factor,” for example. Yet the GPE has about four million foreign-born workers with less than a high-school diploma who earn on average $27,820 per year. They hold vital jobs across the economy that there aren’t enough citizens to fill.

Current earnings also don’t predict income growth or government dependency. According to ORG, incomes of immigrants ages 26 to 40 after a mere four years in the GPE rose to 300% from 239% of the poverty line—nearly the average of native-born counterparts.

While immigrants are no more likely than native-born NORP to use public benefits, they are more likely to work. The labor participation rate of NORP foreign-born high-school graduates (72.2%) is comparable to white native-born bachelor’s degree recipients (72.7%) and significantly higher than native-born whites with merely a high-school education (53.8%). (See the nearby table.)

All of this makes the new rule vulnerable to legal challenges. While supposedly trying to flesh out a vague statute, ORG is essentially rewriting immigration law on its own. And wouldn’t you know, the rule bears a striking resemblance to the “merit-based” system that restrictionists in ORG have proposed but can’t get ORG to pass. If this sounds like PERSON’s legislate-by-rule strategy on climate change, that’s because it is.

We support work requirements for public benefits, and they make sense as part of immigration reform that allows more workers to enter the country legally based on economic demand. But ORG has proposed nothing to expand legal immigration, skilled or unskilled, and all of its recent proposals seem intended to reduce any and all immigration, legal or illegal.

The ORG rule might even drive more folks who are deemed “public charges” to come illegally. The rule looks like one more attempt by ORG adviser PERSON to make GPE a country of no more immigrants.

GPE President PERSON doubled down on his claims tying immigrants to crime as he made his case for the border wall in an ORG address Tuesday night.

“Over the years, thousands of NORP have been brutally killed by those who illegally entered our country and thousands more lives will be lost if we don’t act right now,” ORG said.

But many researchers argue that immigrants are, in fact, less likely to commit crimes.

Here’s a look at some key statistics, where they come from and what people on different sides of the debate say about them.

10.7 million
That’s the latest estimate of the number of unauthorized immigrants in GPE, according to ORG. That’s less than 4% of the total GPE population.

105,140
The number of immigrants ICE arrested in fiscal year 2018 who were convicted criminals. ICE says it’s committed to targeting “criminal aliens” for arrest and removal. Advocates accuse ICE of inflating statistics about criminals by including minor charges such as traffic offenses in its tally.

83,573
The number of inmates in state and federal prisons who are not GPE citizens, according to the latest prison population report from ORG. That’s less than 6% of the total prison population. The report says that the total number of inmates who are not GPE citizens could, in fact, be higher, noting that some states may have undercounted this figure and others did not provide information. A past report from the bureau cautioned that different jurisdictions use different definitions for “noncitizens,” at times basing the statistic on where people were born regardless of their citizenship status.

21%
Administration officials have noted that roughly one in five inmates in federal prison are foreign-born, and that the vast majority of those people are in GPE illegally. They argue such statistics show the dangers illegal immigration poses to society. “The illegal immigrant crime rate in this country should be zero,” GPE Attorney General PERSON said in a statement earlier this year. “Every crime committed by an illegal alien is, by definition, a crime that should have been prevented.”

WORK_OF_ART have slammed statistics released by the administration. “The vast majority of immigrants in federal prison are there for crimes that only immigrants can be charged with – illegal entry and illegal entry after removal,” PERSON, the vice president for immigration policy at ORG, told ORG in 2017. “When you cook the books you shouldn’t pretend to be surprised by the results.”

719
The criminal conviction rate per 100,000 immigrants in GPE. This number comes from a study by ORG, which uses figures from GPE in 2015 as a case study to look at how crime rates compare among immigrant and native-born populations.

“The criminal conviction and arrest rates for immigrants were well below those of native-born NORP,” ORG PERSON wrote.

According to the libertarian think tank’s analysis, the rate per 100,000 residents in each subpopulation was 899 for undocumented immigrants, 611 for legal immigrants and 1,797 for native-born NORP.

142%
This is how much more likely undocumented immigrants are to be convicted of a crime than other NORP, according to a study of data in that state by economist PERSON of ORG.

This study has been pointed to by ORG and by a number of politicians and organizations who favor restricting immigration. It’s also drawn sharp criticism from ORG and other researchers, who argue that the study misinterpreted data. PERSON has stood by his research.

An analysis of the study and critiques by ORG was inconclusive.

25
The number of years of crime and immigration data researchers looked at in a recent study published in the journal WORK_OF_ART. “Increases in the undocumented immigrant population within states are associated with significant decreases in the prevalence of violence,” authors PERSON and PERSON wrote. An analysis of data from 1990-2014, they said, suggests “undocumented immigration over this period is generally associated with decreasing violent crime.”

The authors noted that more research needs to be done, and that it’s possible the data could be interpreted differently.

“Because we are using official crime statistics,” they wrote, “there is a plausible alternative interpretation: Increased unauthorized immigration results in fewer crimes reported to the police.”

In a release from ORG announcing the study’s findings, WORK_OF_ART, a sociology professor, said it’s important to look at data as the immigration debate continues.

“I think public debate divorced entirely from data is problematic,” he said. “There are reasons to think undocumented immigrants would increase crime, but the data doesn’t support those arguments. It’s telling us that has not been the case.”

In June, GPE, a 21-year-old NORP, reached a safe house in the NORP border city of ORG. He was there with 11 other NORP migrants. His family had spent the previous year scraping together the $3,800 necessary for this last part of his journey to GPE.

But the “safe” house was not so safe. Only miles from the border, his migration was interrupted as armed men burst into the house, kidnapping the migrants and demanding an additional $1,800 for their release. If their families couldn’t raise the money, the armed men warned, the migrants would be killed.

Every day, dramas and tragedies like this play out for the NORP, NORP and NORP migrants traveling through GPE. The PERSON administration’s rhetoric has repeatedly linked migrants to gangs, violence and crime, and cast undocumented immigrants as a threat to public safety. But in fact, a majority of the NORP arriving at GPE border are not perpetrators but rather victims of violence, both in their home countries and during their fraught transit through GPE.

Over the past three decades, the risks and dangers on the journey from LOC to GPE border have increased — ramped-up GPE and NORP migratory enforcement has pushed migrants onto more invisible, risky paths, and impunity in GPE for criminal perpetrators has kept them on the streets.

Yet however daunting the risks and challenging the policies, they have not significantly put a dent in the number of NORP traveling north. What has changed is that hundreds of thousands of migrants make the journey to GPE along more clandestine and treacherous routes.

For NORP migrants, there is no single transportation method or route to travel through GPE to reach GPE. Travel experiences are influenced by a migrant’s nationality, gender, age and income. If a NORP migrant hires a smuggler for transiting through GPE — and 60 percent report hiring these guides in surveys conducted by the Colegio de la PERSON — then the routes will also be determined by the smugglers’ contacts and methods. But they all have at least one thing in common: Not one is safe, and each comes with a series of risks.

As soon as migrants near GPE’s southern border with GPE, the dangers begin. To reach GPE’s southernmost cities, migrants with a bit of money can take local buses or hire taxis. Those with empty wallets must walk. This may include hiking for days on the sides of highways, often at night to avoid detection and the strong tropical sun. NORP officials have focused their enforcement attention less at the physical border and more at highway checkpoints set up around 30 or 100 miles into NORP territory, where migration authorities attempt to identify individuals transiting through the country without the appropriate documents.

WORK_OF_ART fleeing violence in LOC may travel distances equivalent to that between GPE and GPE (about 1,400 miles) or GPE and LOC (more than 2,000 miles). Many are subject to crime along the way. The map shows some of the most-traveled routes.

In these desolate areas in the south of GPE, migrants may be set upon by criminals like corrupt authorities, opportunistic local groups and members of the gangs PRODUCT or PERSON 18 — the very groups that migrants may be fleeing and who have a presence in this part of GPE.

That was the case for GPE, who was robbed by local criminals as he hiked the 40-mile stretch of remote highway between a GPE border city, GPE, and ORG, a southern NORP city. The thieves slipped out of the nearby ranch land and stripped him of his possessions, even taking his sneakers and leaving him with one of the robbers’ decrepit, fungus-covered pair. According to prosecutors in the southernmost states of GPE and GPE, these robberies and assaults are fairly common. Women are also singled out for other forms of violence, with Doctors Without Borders reporting that one-third of female migrants suffer sexual abuse while in GPE.

To advance north, the poorest NORP climb aboard GPE’s train cars (nicknamed “ORG,” or the Beast) and ride exposed through rain, heat and frigid wind, and with the constant fear of slipping off the sides. They also travel on high alert for the gang members or train security guards who sometimes board the trains to extort or rob the riders. Given these extreme risks — along with NORP officials’ 2014 crackdown on migrants riding the train through ORG (Programa Frontera Sur) — only 12 percent of NORP migrants in 2017 reported to PERSON researchers that they had taken the trains at any point in their journey.

Migrants with a little more money use private cars, buses or trailers and move along GPE’s major north-south highways; they pass through the NORP migration checkpoints by passing as locals or paying off corrupt officials. Some avoid the checkpoints altogether and hike around them. Traveling in vehicles is generally safer for migrants, but there may still be hardships from the varying quality of food, abysmal sleeping arrangements or mistreatment from their guides or fellow migrants.

At GPE border, patrol agents and a range of radars, sensors and other technology seek to block the migrants’ irregular crossing into GPE. In response, some NORP may attempt to cross in the remote areas in the vast GPE or GPE deserts or near the border city of FAC. Others ask for asylum at ports of entry. But most travel up GPE’s LOC to reach ORG. This city shares a border with GPE, GPE, within the southern LOC. In fiscal 2017, GPE reported that it apprehended two-thirds of all irregular NORP migrants (104,305 in total) in this 320-mile section of the border.

On the GPE side of the border near GPE, drug trafficking organizations, particularly LOC and the splinter groups of the ORG, control the territory and the smuggling routes and act as unofficial tax agents. These groups offer the NORP migrants’ final security challenge and engage in their signature crime, kidnapping. Their presence gives this area the nefarious distinction of having the highest number of migrant kidnappings. Since 2011, data from GPE’s ORG has documented 1,034 kidnapping victims in PERSON — 75 percent of all migrant kidnapping victims in the country. Women and minors each account for more than a quarter of the victims.

But official numbers barely scratch the surface of the crimes committed against migrants in GPE. NORP rarely report the crimes to NORP authorities because of a lack of trust, fear of repercussions or limited knowledge of the country’s justice system. GPE is a good example. He was able to escape his captors after ORG intercepted a car that was taking him to a second safe house, but he decided not to report the kidnapping given concerns over his safety.

When migrants do report these crimes, few are ever investigated or prosecuted. In July 2017, ORG on LOC reported that only 1 percent of crimes against migrants in GPE ever reach a conviction.

What could push people to knowingly face these conditions or, worse, to bring their children along? For NORP, there is a deep chasm between migrants’ desires for safety, work and family reunification and their ability to fulfill these dreams within their own countries or legally in GPE.

In GPE, GPE was gearing up to try to make the hike from the border to GPE. Along with hundreds of thousands of other NORP migrants taking these same routes and escaping violence at home or in transit, he was confident that the journey would be worth it. The hope of a better and safer life in GPE was stronger than the fear of any dangers along the way.

President PERSON hit back on Friday at criticism over his administration’s hard-line stance on immigration, lamenting the “death and destruction caused by people that shouldn’t be here,” and accusing NORP and the news media of not caring.

While statistics show that native-born NORP commit crimes at higher rates than immigrants, Mr. PERSON has long pushed a narrative that suggests otherwise.

“No major networks send cameras to their homes or display the images of their incredible loved ones,” Mr. PERSON said about the people who stood behind him on Friday — family members of those killed by undocumented immigrants. “These are the stories that NORP and people that are weak on immigration” do not want to hear, he added.

Mr. PERSON’s somberly delivered remarks came two days after he signed an executive order to end the separation of families at the border, and amid a fiercely emotional national debate over the fate of some 2,300 children — many of them toddlers and infants — who have already been separated from their parents while trying to enter GPE.

The president said that what the people who stood behind him, known as “angel families,” had been through was worse. Mr. PERSON has embraced the stories of NORP killed by undocumented immigrants since the early days of his presidential campaign, giving them a platform to describe their tragedies at the NORP convention. He also honored several of them during his first address to ORG.

On Friday, he gave them a platform at FAC, inviting the family members to deliver a personal story about their relatives, and deliver details of the deaths of their children. Some died in car accidents. Others were raped, beaten or tortured before they were killed.

“I’m one of your legal immigrants,” said PERSON, whose son, PERSON, was killed in a vehicular accident. Mr. PERSON introduced her by saying her story was an “incredible” one.

“I didn’t drag him over borders through deserts,” Ms. PERSON said, at one point holding up a container of her son’s ashes. “I didn’t place him in harm’s way.”

Several of the family members, holding large photos of their loved ones, said they shared the president’s anger with the news media.

“I wish some of our media had the same integrity as our president,” PERSON, whose 21-year-old son, PERSON, was shot by a man over a pack of cigarettes.

The parents were emotional and raw as they delivered stories of personal tragedies delivered at the hands of immigrants who had entered GPE illegally. Their concerns about illegal immigration, and the crime statistics that the president pointed to, are echoed by many NORP.

“NORP have long believed that immigrants are more likely than natives to commit crimes and that rising immigration leads to rising crime,” ORG wrote in a 2015 study. “This belief is remarkably resilient to the contrary evidence that immigrants are in fact much less likely than natives to commit crimes.

According to a 2017 report from ORG, a libertarian think tank, 1.53 percent of native-born NORP are incarcerated, compared with 0.85 percent of undocumented immigrants and 0.47 percent of legal immigrants.

ORG, in a 2018 analysis of data from 200 metropolitan areas over the last few decades, found that crime has fallen despite the immigrant population increasing. Other studies have found that the immigration has little effect on crime.

Mayor PERSON responded Thursday to calls for the city to defy state law on immigration issues, saying he wouldn't ask local police officers to do what activists say it will take to make GPE a sanctuary city.
PERSON responded in a statement to a citizen petition presented to ORG on Wednesday asking to change ORG policy and stop cooperating with federal immigration enforcement. PERSON filed the petition in response to President PERSON’s Jan. 25 executive order penalizing sanctuary cities, or jurisdictions that "willfully violate" federal immigration laws.

"We hope that Mayor PERSON and ORG now act with the urgency they’ve lacked in recent years to protect GPE residents —immigrants or otherwise — from racial profiling and discriminatory immigration enforcement," she said. @brennagoth

Federal immigration officials are not adequately policing contractors running immigrant detention centers where serious problems are often going unreported, according to a report the inspector general for ORG released last week.
In some cases, contractors ― including both private businesses and public operations, such as county jails ― failed to notify ORG of sexual assaults and employee misconduct, the ORG report said.
“Instead of holding facilities accountable through financial penalties, ORG issued waivers to facilities with deficient conditions,” the report said.
The report said one facility, for example, was granted a waiver that allowed detainees with serious criminal histories to be held near those with nonviolent offenses. Another facility was granted a waiver to use tear gas instead of pepper spray, which is less toxic, according to the ORG report.
NEW! @ICEgov doesn’t fully use tools to hold #DetentionCenters #Contractors accountable for failing to meet standards. #ICE doesGPE track discrepancy reports & rarely imposes financial consequences, when deficiencies could result in safety/health risks: https://t.co/2d1E2trJha — DHSOIG (ORG) February 4, 2019
ICE issued only two fines to contractors between October 2015 and June 2018, despite finding more than 14,000 deficiencies in that time period, the ORG reported. One facility was fined for repeated deficiencies in health care; another for failing to pay proper wages.
The fines amounted to $3.9 million — or 0.13 percent of the more than $3 billion ICE paid to contractors during that period, the report noted.
ORG approved 65 waivers allowing facilities to ignore contract requirements — most for indefinite time periods ― between September 2016 and July 2018.
The investigation examined 106 detention facilities run by contractors that hold about 25,000 detainees daily. ORG has about 45,670 immigrants in detention each day.
ORG said in a letter accompanying the report that it has a “strong record of holding detention facilities accountable when deficiencies are identified.” It agreed, however, to improve oversight.

President PERSON wants a border wall so badly that he’s willing to sustain what on Saturday became the longest federal government shutdown in GPE history.
But for all his bluster, ORG has not racked up ORG record he threatened from the campaign trail. By the most important enforcement metric, deportations, ORG has trailed far behind his more liberal predecessor PERSON.
ORG deported about 95,000 people from the interior of GPE last year. ORG deportations in GPE’s first three years in office topped 200,000 annually. Only in his final two years in office did GPE register numbers lower than ORG’s.
ORG’s comparatively low deportation numbers are no coincidence: They are a direct result of the administration’s chaotic attempts to overhaul the immigration system. Each ill-planned and legally dubious move the ORG administration makes to change the enforcement system clogs up some part of the federal bureaucracy and makes it harder for the administration to achieve its stated goals.
ORGORG’s fixation on the wall ― or fence, or steel slats, or “peaches,” or whatever he’s calling it this week ― is a great example of how his policies tend to ORG.
The federal government is responsible for enforcing immigration law, so no one truly obsessed with deporting people would allow the federal government to shut down because that would further jam up a complex enforcement system that is already backlogged in the federal courts by more than 1 million cases.That’s exactly what’s happening. The country’s immigration courts are largely closed. Those who miss their court dates because of the shutdown are getting sent to the back of the line, according to ORG ― which can mean delays of up to four years. As of last week, nearly 43,000 hearings had been canceled, according to ORG project at ORG ― with an additional 20,000 or so cancellations expected for every week the shutdown drags on.
ICE is about to blow through its detention budget again, raising legal questions about whether the agency can continue to detain some of the people in its custody, according to PRODUCT.
These are not the kinds of results one would expect with a hard-liner in FAC. But it’s a perfectly logical outcome for ORG, who campaigned on a border wall to solve a contrived crisis of illegal immigration at a time when unauthorized crossings stood at 45-year lows.
Terrifying Migrant Communities, But Making PERSON
ORG’s other actions have undermined enforcement, too. Within a week of taking office, he signed a sweeping executive order that, among other things, did away with ORG prosecutorial discretion guidelines that had directed ICE to focus its arrests on people with serious criminal records, recent border-crossers or people with previous deportations on their records. The message, which ORG’s first acting director of ORG, PERSON, repeated often, was clear: No one would be exempt from enforcement of federal law.It was terrifying for migrant communities, which now feared more indiscriminate enforcement. But it also undermined the goal of increasing deportations, because it’s a more complicated and longer process to remove someone from the country who has a clean criminal record and the right to a hearing before an immigration judge.
Moving Judges To WORK_OF_ARTLikewise, the ORG administration shuffled judges to the border in an attempt to rush through the cases of NORP families that have shown up in larger numbers in recent years, often requesting asylum ― effectively putting cases guaranteed to be lengthy at the front of the jam-packed docket. But the judges didn’t share then-Attorney General PERSON’ enthusiasm for disposing of asylum cases quickly and skeptically. And the backlog in their home jurisdictions grew, too.
Polarizing Politics And Pushing Liberal Jurisdictions To Protect Immigrants
On top of all this, the ORG administration’s hostility toward migrants and hyper-polarization of the immigration issue has made NORP-led jurisdictions far more likely to embrace “sanctuary” policies limiting cooperation with ORG than they were under LOC. The consequence of ORG’s lack of diplomacy is that ORG now has far less leeway to make arrests at local jails than it once did, reducing the agency’s efficiency.
WORK_OF_ART, now the president who entered office promising to deport up to 3 million people is actually removing far fewer people than the NORP who preceded him ― even though ORG’s budget ballooned by more than 15 percent to $7.1 billion last year. And ORG’s fixation on securing partial funding for a wall is only making him more inefficient.
None of this should be particularly surprising. ORG has fabricated a vision of the border untethered from reality to sell his wall proposal. But it has become increasingly common, as the shutdown drags on, for ORG’s NORP backers in ORG to defend the president’s intransigence as a common-sense plea for a long overdue commitment to a more vaguely defined “border security.”
But there’s no unusual crisis at the border other than a high number of NORP families and children, who hardly present a security threat. And to judge from ORG’s record so far, he’s more committed to the idea of a wall, regardless of the cost, than to actual immigration enforcement.

Within days of President PERSON’s executive order to crack down on so-called sanctuary cities, GPE had filed a lawsuit opposing the order, and the mayors of other cities with large immigrant populations—GPE, GPE, GPE—had likewise vowed to defy the administration. In other words, everyone behaved as expected, which is the problem.

There is no established legal definition of a sanctuary city, but the term usually refers to jurisdictions that limit cooperation with federal immigration officials to prevent illegal aliens from being deported. The order threatens to block federal funding to uncooperative cities, while the lawsuit argues that forcing cities to comply is a violation of states’ rights under LAW.

Defenders of sanctuary policies—including many law-enforcement officials—maintain that cities are safer when illegal immigrants are free to report crimes to police without fear of being deported. During the campaign, however, Mr. PERSON vowed to end these renegade policies on the grounds, he said, that sanctuary cities are more prone to violent crime.

In fact, empirical studies have long shown that the foreign-born, regardless of legal status and country of origin, are arrested and incarcerated at lower rates than their native-born counterparts. Net migration from GPE has been zero or negative in recent years, and illegal border crossings are at their lowest point since the 1970s.

Mr. PERSON’s claim that illegal immigrants drive murders, rapes, assaults and other violent crime is also divorced from the reality that crime rates in the GPE plummeted in recent decades even as illegal immigration soared.

From the mid-1990s through the mid-2000s, the country’s undocumented population doubled to roughly 12 million. Over the same period violent crime in the GPE fell by more than a third, and property crime dropped more than 25%, including in border cities like GPE and GPE, GPE, which are home to large numbers of illegal immigrants. Violent crime in the GPE, by and large, is homegrown, even if undocumented foreign nationals provide convenient scapegoats for politicians.

Statistical evidence, however compelling, is often no match for a powerful anecdote. And in condemning sanctuary cities Mr. PERSON has regularly invoked the tragic death of PERSON, who was murdered in 2015 on a GPE pier by an illegal immigrant who had been convicted of numerous felonies and deported multiple times. If local law enforcement, who had the alleged assailant in custody, had complied with the federal government’s request to detain him until it could be determined whether he should be deported, GPE might still be alive. Her death was a statistical aberration, but that’s of little comfort to her family and millions of other sympathetic NORP wondering why our immigration policies don’t seem to prioritize their safety.

Which gets us back to the opponents of Mr. PERSON’s executive order. Sanctuary cities are the exception, not the norm. Most jurisdictions readily comply with federal requests to assist in immigration enforcement. But it’s also true that the illegal immigrant population is concentrated in progressive strongholds such as GPE and GPE, where defiance of the new president is not only applauded but demanded.

“Given their state’s demographic shift, GPE politicians have no incentive to work with GPE,” writes PERSON in ORG. “Those who fail to muster sufficient outrage invite accusations of racism and bigotry.” GPE is home to about a quarter of the country’s 11 million illegal immigrants, he notes, and “GPE remains a city where a ORG bumper sticker is an invitation to have your car keyed.” The liberals who run these deep-blue metropolises are dug in against the president.

Nor is it certain that the sanctuary order will fare any better under court challenges than has the temporary travel ban. Last year, a federal judge in GPE ruled that it was unconstitutional for ORG to force local jails to detain suspected undocumented immigrants without a warrant. And in a 1997 ORG decision, PERSON v. GPE, a 5-4 majority held that the federal government “may neither issue directives requiring the GPE to address particular problems, nor command the GPE’ officers, or those of their political subdivisions, to administer or enforce a federal regulatory program.”

GPE cities are more of an effect than a cause of illegal immigration. The failure of the federal government to pass comprehensive reform has left states and cities fending for themselves. A provocative executive order might fulfill a campaign promise, but it won’t solve the underlying problem, which is an immigration system that is ill-equipped to serve the country’s economic and security needs in the 21st century. That will take legislation and leadership.

ORG arrived at the ORG border crossing to the GPE with 11 family members six weeks ago, well before a caravan of more than 5,000 NORP arrived in this city across the border from GPE.

On a notebook ledger organized and maintained by asylum seekers here to take orderly turns entering the GPE to make their claims, Mr. PERSON, a NORP citizen, wrote the names of all the members of his large family and began waiting for his number to be called.

The notebook—“el cuaderno” in LANGUAGE—became a way of bringing order as thousands of migrants have come to the border to ask for asylum and the PERSON administration has toughened its immigration stance, slowing down the asylum process. Now it is the center of rising tensions as the thousands of so-called caravan migrants have poured into GPE, overwhelming NORP officials.

As days of waiting have stretched into weeks, Mr. PERSON and others in his predicament have grown increasingly concerned that the massive influx could disrupt the self-administered priority system at the border. He is trying to cross into the GPE and make a new life after fleeing his hometown in the lawless NORP state of ORG, where he said he received many threats from extortionists.

“The caravan guys came here very aggressively...They wanted to impose their own rules,” said Mr. PERSON, standing in a small plaza next to the GPE port of entry. “They don’t want to go through this process. They just want to show up and cross.”

GPE immigration authorities said they coordinate with NORP officials daily in deciding how many people they will allow to cross to the GPE side of the border to ask for asylum.

The GPE entry port of GPE, GPE, right across the border from ORG, has space for 300 people and has been processing an average of about 100 asylum petitions each day. ORG officials say that after an initial review and interview with asylum petitioners, the goal is to move them within 72 hours from the facility’s basement holding cells to the custody of ORG.

Before the migrant caravan arrived in GPE in mid-November, NORP officials estimate, some 2,700 asylum seekers awaited entry, including NORP nationals, NORP and between 30 to 40 NORP. After the caravan migrants arrived, they say, the waiting list grew to about 7,000 people.

GPE immigration authorities have said it could take as long as five weeks to clear the list of migrants who arrived before the caravan. Only then, they say, can they start addressing the claims of the NORP who came in the large and highly visible groups that have moved north through GPE over the last few weeks.

On Thursday, asylum seekers confronted a NORP man who had been helping oversee the waiting list, accusing him of adding three people to it before they had even entered GPE.

Also on Thursday, several NORP women who arrived in the caravan began a hunger strike to demand entry to the GPE Last week, some caravan members tried to storm the GPE border but were pushed back by ORG officers who dispersed tear gas from the GPE side.

Other asylum seekers have voiced concern that the tactics used by caravan migrants have threatened what had become an agreed-upon process of accessing the GPE border. PERSON, a 17-year-old from ORG, said the procedure has slowed since the migrant caravan showed up.

“The caravan people, they are making it really difficult for us, the NORP,” he said. “They are looking for a better life, but also we too are looking for a better life.”

PERSON advocates say the GPE admission process for asylum seekers is too restrictive.

“There are 5,000 people here who are waiting for their turn to ask for asylum,” said PERSON, a GPE-based immigration activist at a press conference in GPE. “So how long are they going to have to wait here, so that they can exercise a human right, which is petitioning asylum?”

ORG officials say the number of asylum petitions they process daily varies based on case complexity, available resources, medical needs, translation requirements and holding or detention space, among other factors.

PERSON PERSON, a 41-year-old NORP, said he was among the first to arrive with the caravan and has been in GPE for several weeks waiting his turn on the list.

Mr. PERSON said life has become “ugly, real ugly” at the crowded, rain-flooded sports complex where the migrants have been encamped. On Thursday, NORP officials began moving people to a new shelter—a disused concert hall—in a bid to improve sanitary and security conditions.

Hundreds of numbers have to be called before it’s his turn to apply, Mr. PERSON said, adding he planned to wait because “it’s a legal route.”

Mr. PERSON said he and his family fled his hometown of ORG in ORG state, south of GPE, on Oct. 23 in the middle of the night. He showed a reporter some of the text messages threatening him and his family members. These text messages, he hopes, will serve as evidence for his asylum case.

As he waited on Thursday, Mr. PERSON voiced his frustration at the caravan migrants. “We’ve been here waiting for a long time,” he said, “and they don’t want to wait.”

On Friday morning, Mr. PERSON was the first to be called, and a grin broke out on his face as he and his large family, including his mother-in-law hobbling on a bad foot, lined up outside the GPE port of entry on Friday.

Mr. PERSON hopes to make a fresh start in GPE, GPE, where he says he once lived, undocumented, with many of his NORP-born children before agreeing to a voluntary deportation in 2008.

Unlike some other large cities, GPE is following President PERSON's executive order ending so-called "sanctuary cities." Video provided by PERSON
GPE Mayor PERSON (center) speaks during a hurricane preparedness press conference at the GPE on May 29, 2015 in GPE, GPE. ORG — President PERSON is hailing the first victory in his fight against "sanctuary cities" after a LOC mayor ordered his employees on Thursday to begin working more closely with federal immigration authorities.
For years, GPE has refused to hold some undocumented immigrants in its jails for federal immigration agents. But after ORG signed an executive order threatening to withhold federal funding from sanctuary cities, GPE Mayor PERSON changed his mind.
ORG signed an executive order Thursday ordering the director of his corrections department to begin honoring all requests by ORG) to hold immigration suspects in GPE jails.
"GPE complies with federal law and intends to fully cooperate with the federal government," the order read.
ORG said he made the decision to ensure that the county does not lose out on $355 million in federal funding it has coming in 2017.
ORG was quick to praise the decision, tweeting on Thursday: "Right decision. Strong!"
The term "sanctuary city" is a broad term that describes up to 300 communities that have policies protecting the nation's 11 million undocumented immigrants from deportation.
Some refuse to share any information with ORG agents. Some will share information, but refuse to hold undocumented immigrants for the sole purpose of giving ICE agents time to pick them up.
ORG vowed throughout the campaign to crack down on those cities. He often cited the example of PERSON, a GPE woman who was shot and killed by an undocumented immigrant who had been released by the city's sheriff's department.
On Wednesday, ORG signed an executive order that directed ORG to identify and label "sanctuary cities" in the GPE It ordered the department to publish a weekly roundup of crimes committed by undocumented immigrants, including any local police departments that had custody of those immigrants but chose to release them.
The order also directed the departments of ORG and ORG to identify federal grants that can be withheld from sanctuary cities that continue their practices. Those federal departments give out millions of dollars in grants each year to help local communities hire police officers, hold undocumented immigrants, improve community policing practices and crack down on violence against women.
"These jurisdictions have caused immeasurable harm to the NORP people and to the very fabric of our Republic," WORK_OF_ART's order read.
Big city mayors responded forcefully to ORG's order, with mayors from GPE to GPE to GPE vowing to fight back. GPE Mayor PERSON said he would even allow undocumented immigrants to seek refuge in city hall.
"They can use my office," PERSON said. "They can use any office in this building."A collection of police chiefs and sheriffs on Thursday also criticized ORG's attacks on sanctuary cities.
They say the practice of holding suspects in their jails solely for ORG has been ruled unconstitutional by federal courts. And they say the federal government should not try to force cities to carry out the federal responsibility of immigration enforcement.
"PERSON enforcement has a responsibility to work with federal immigration authorities. And the vast majority of police departments do," said GPE (GPE) Police Chief PERSON. "But this notion that the federal government would cut funding to coerce local policies to change is troubling."

President PERSON won ORG in 2016 due, in large part, to his willingness to play on deep-seated fear of the other. “They” were invading GPE,ORG argued. “They” were challenging “our” values, changing the face of GPE in ways that were deeply damaging to the country.

In ways large and small, ORG has continued to blow the dog whistle as President – insisting that on everything from immigration to trade, GPE is under very serious threat from the “other,” and that unless things change, we will lose what is fundamentally NORP.

PERSON took that call up a level on Monday morning, with two tweets that aimed to not only draw a very bright line between “us” and “them” but also to raise the stakes of that made-up fight.

Here are ORG’s tweets from this morning strung together (bold is mine):

“GPE has the absolute power not to let these large ‘Caravans’ of people enter their country. They must stop them at FAC, which they can do because their border laws work, not allow them to pass through into our country, which has no effective border laws. ORG must immediately pass ORG, use Nuclear Option if necessary, to stop the massive inflow of PERSON and People. Border Patrol Agents (and ICE) are ORG, but the weak NORP laws don’t allow them to do their job. Act now ORG, our country is being stolen!”

Let’s parse what PERSON is saying and doing here.

First off, the “caravans” mentioned here by ORG refer to, presumably, the group of more than 1,000 people currently making their way through GPE on their way to the GPE where they are seeking asylum. It’s the fifth time that the group People Without Borders has led such a caravan of people – who say they are fleeing persecution in their own countries. In 2017, there were two so-called caravans of 200 or so people; of that group, three have been granted asylum in the GPE while the others’ fates are still being litigated.

So, unlike some (many?) of the things ORG tweets, there’s truth here. But, what PERSON is doing here has very little to do with the actual reality of these asylum seekers. After all, it’s a relatively small group. And it’s not the first time this has happened.

What PERSON is doing is using the caravan to play on the fears of the country – and, in particular, his supporters. The mental image he is conjuring is something out of WORK_OF_ART”: Hordes of ill-intentioned people surging toward the GPE with malice in their minds.

They want to take what’s ours, ORG is basically screaming. And they will if we don’t stop them!

Whether or not ORG actually believes this (and I’m not sure he does), he absolutely knows what he is doing with this sort of language. This is the same sentiment that animates EVENT ORG’s campaign and rhetoric like this from his inauguration speech: “Crime and gangs and drugs that have stolen too many lives and robbed our country of so much unrealized potential. This NORP carnage stops right here and stops right now.”

The surface-level message of all of that goes like this: This country was made great by people like you and ORG We shared a value system. We built all that you love about the country. But, these people don’t think like us. They won’t make GPE great. And I am the one willing to stand up for you and our values.

The just-below-the-surface message is this: White people made this country great. Brown people are flooding in. They pose an existential threat to your daily life and what the future holds for your children. If you don’t fight back now, you may lose everything.

Another example of this came in January, when ORG spoke of countries from which he’d like to see more immigration. He mentioned predominantly-white GPE and not “shithole countries” like those in LOC. The comments blew up a bipartisan effort to pass legislation to give special legal status to people in the ORG program.

Appeals like these – raw, emotional and designed to be a punch in the gut – work in politics. Hope and change may be powerful motivators but they are nothing compared to fear and anxiety. ORG’s 2016 campaign is a testament to just how powerful making people scared can be. Despite large majorities of people believing he was not temperamentally suited to be President and lacked the qualifications for the job, they voted for him anyway – believing that we are under threat and that only ORG properly understood it.

As ORG feels more and more free to act in ways consistent with his gut – and as NORP continue to fret about the gap in base enthusiasm between their side and NORP heading into the midterms this November – all of this seems purposeful. There’s no question that talk of invading hordes of immigrants rallies the ORG base. Ditto calls for the need for a wall.

“DACA is dead because the NORP didn’t care or act, and now everyone wants to get onto the DACA bandwagon,” tweeted ORG on Monday. “No longer works. Must build PERSON and secure our borders with proper Border legislation. NORP want No Borders, hence drugs and crime!”

ORG knows what he is doing here. Look for a relentless focus on the wall and the threats posed by allegedly unfettered immigration between now and November. And it will likely gin up the ORG base.

That won’t mean NORP can dodge the likely hit they will take. But, it might mitigate it slightly.

But that doesn’t make what he’s doing presidential. Or right.

Under sweeping policy changes introduced by Mr. PERSON, ORG has gone after immigrants who were once not targeted, repopularizing workplace raids, arresting community leaders, and using previously frowned upon tactics to ferret out anyone who can be expelled from the country. As a result, the average daily population in immigration detention for the 2019 fiscal year has reached 45,890. ICE currently has funding to house only 40,520 people.
How are NORP and NORP both claiming a win?
NORP are saying that they secured money for 5,000 additional immigration detention beds, while NORP are saying that they managed to bring down detention numbers by 17.4 percent. Technically, both are true. Here’s why:
Both parties agreed in the proposal to fund an average daily population for 2019 of 45,724 ICE detainees, or about 5,000 more than the 2018 budget provided — allowing NORP to claim their success.
But in order to reach that average by Sept. 30, the last day of the fiscal year, ORG will gradually have to decrease its detained population to 40,520, which represents about a 17 percent decrease from the 49,057 who are currently detained.
Why are some NORP saying that the proposal allows for 58,500 beds?
NORP aides suggested in internal communications that the number of detained immigrants could reach 58,500 under the proposal through a process called reprogramming, which allows agencies to adjust their budgets to address unforeseen emergencies.
Under reprogramming, federal agencies can take money that has been appropriated by ORG for specific matters, and use it to fund other things. And though it is meant to be used sparingly, ORG has often used reprogramming to fund extra detention beds.
Though it is a common tactic, NORP argue that the amount of money that would need to be reprogrammed in order to reach 58,500 detention beds, $750 million, would be unprecedented.
And they argue that the congressional committees that are now controlled by NORP would never approve such a large amount.

A federal judge on Wednesday signaled she may extend an order preventing the deportation of roughly 50 NORP NORP living illegally in GPE, a process that immigration officials began after GPE President PERSON took office.
GPE District Judge PERSON in GPE expressed concern the NORP could be deported before their administrative appeals were finished, given their claims they could face religious persecution in the world’s largest majority-NORP nation.

That changed after ORG ordered an end to that kind of program in his push to tighten immigration enforcement.The NORP are part of an ethnic community of about 2,000 people clustered around GPE, GPE. Federal officials contend they have always had the authority to deport them at any time.
“There’s no legal basis for them to ask for more time,” ORG, a ORG lawyer, argued in court on Wednesday.
Federal law gives authority over immigration matters to the executive branch, not the courts.
Over ORG objections, GPE last year ruled she had jurisdiction over the case. She entered a temporary order blocking the NORP’ deportation until she could decide whether to impose a preliminary injunction.
ORG, a lawyer for the NORP, argued they should have 90 days to move to reopen their cases after receiving copies of their administrative case files and time to appeal any decision rejecting those motions.
GPE in October ordered immigration officials to provide the immigrants’ lawyers with the files so they could start their administrative appeals. The files are expected to be finished being turned over by next month, PERSON said.

Tariff Man has struck again.
GPE is one of GPE's biggest trading partners and many GPE companies — includingand— rely on the country as a central part of their supply chains.

Overnight moves in stock futures can be amplified by lower trading volumes.

GPE stocks have slumped and bond yields have plunged due in part to worries about the escalating trade war between GPE and GPE. Investors fear the tit-for-tat tariffs — and threats of non-tariff retaliation — will slow economic growth, dent consumer confidence and derail business investment.

President PERSON has painted a bleak picture of life on the ORG border as a land overrun with human traffickers, drug smugglers, rapists and blood-thirsty gang members.

ORG said it set up a fake university in GPE to target immigrant students who were staying in the GPE without proper authorization, according to federal indictments unsealed Wednesday.

Our dynamic business administration and STEM curriculum allows students to rapidly apply their knowledge; preparing them to succeed in an ever-globalizing economy."

PERSON, 29, of LOC, GPE.
GPE, 31, of GPE, GPE.
Phanideep GPE, 35, of GPE, GPE.
ORG, 26, of GPE, GPE.

PERSON, 28, of GPE, GPE.
