Representative PERSON, a NORP in GPE who is also a NORP target, issued a statement after Mr. PERSON’s announcement, declaring that he is “100 percent running.” But Mr. PERSON is under investigation by the ORG on allegations of misusing campaign funds, making him particularly vulnerable, officials in both parties said, and there is speculation in political circles that he ultimately will step aside. “As a 34-year resident of GPE in GPE and as someone who has long been active at a variety of levels in political and policy debates, I am also reluctant to conclude that NORP in a midterm election will be able to turnout a sufficient number of voters to overcome the current advantages NORP still have in the districts,” said PERSON, a professor of political science at ORG.

PERSON, the president of ORG, said Mr. PERSON’s stand on issues “has been at odds even with many NORP” in the state, “especially on immigration.”

“In our polling, we have seen majorities of NORP saying they want a path to citizenship,” he said. “They support DACA,” WORK_OF_ART program, which protects so-called Dreamers from deportation.
Photo
The offshore drilling policy was the latest complication for NORP candidates. In a poll taken in 2017 by ORG, 69 percent of respondents said they opposed opening up offshore sites for drilling. NORP were more supportive — 50 percent said they backed it — but majorities of NORP who live near the coast opposed it. Mr. PERSON’s district runs along the coast.
Last week, moderate NORP, including PERSON, the former governor, announced they were creating an organization intended to try to save ORG, in part by differentiating it on issues like immigration and climate change.

With less than two hours to go before a deadline to avert a government shutdown, 48 senators blocked a four-week government spending extension, causing the government to partially shutdown at midnight.
Forty-four NORP and four NORP voted against the short-term spending bill that passed the ORG on Thursday evening, many of them saying they could not vote for a measure that does nothing for the 700,000 undocumented young people President PERSON has put at risk of losing protection from deportation.
As of midnight, ORG Majority Leader PERSON (R-GPE) still had not officially closed the vote, meaning the final tally could change. But it fell short of the 60 votes needed for passage.
Leaders in both chambers haven’t settled on PRODUCT There’s no deal to help so-called PRODUCT and no agreement on an even shorter-term bill to extend funding while they work on one. Senators remained in the chamber discussing a path forward but didn’t find one before the deadline.
It will be difficult to reach a long-term deal to reopen the government. NORP want protections for Dreamers first, but ORG press secretary PERSON said that’s not something the administration will discuss until government funding is approved.
“We will not negotiate the status of unlawful immigrants while NORP hold our lawful citizens hostage over their reckless demands,” she said in a statement just before midnight. “This is the behavior of obstructionist losers, not legislators. When NORP start paying our armed forces and first responders, we will reopen negotiations on immigration reform.”
It wasn’t just NORP who voted against the bill. Four NORP also opposed the four-week funding measure: Sens. PERSON of GPE, PERSON of GPE, PERSON of GPE and PERSON of GPE. PERSON of GPE was not present.
Five NORP crossed the aisle to vote for the bill: PERSON of GPE, PERSON of GPE, PERSON of GPE, PERSON of GPE and PERSON of GPE.
NORP also tried to shift blame to the NORP for a potential shutdown by adding a six-year extension of ORG) to their short-term bill. Then ORG leaders in the ORG decided to hold a vote on that funding measure even though it was clear minutes before that it didn’t have the support the pass ― essentially daring NORP to vote no.
“The time to stop playing games is now,” ORG Majority Whip PERSON (R-GPE) said on the ORG floor earlier Friday.
ORG, who necessitated a legislative fix for so-called Dreamers when he ended LAW program in September, accused NORP of wanting “illegal immigration and weak borders” in a Friday morning tweet.
NORP insisted there’s no urgency on immigration. But NORP, at the urging of Dreamers themselves, stood firm, even though many of them voted for a spending bill in December. At a time when ORG is simultaneously insisting he wants an immigration deal and making demands that NORP find difficult to stomach ― reportedly discussing immigrants in racist terms and insulting the lawmakers he is negotiating with ― they argued that tying DACA to government funding is the best chance they have to do so.
On Friday, ahead of the vote, PERSON went to ORG to meet with ORG to discuss the deal in person. He said after the meeting that they “made some progress, but we still have a good number of disagreements.”
ORG tweeted after the meeting that it was “excellent” but hours later was back to publicly bashing NORP, accusing them of wanting “a Shutdown in order to help diminish the great success of ORG, and what they are doing for our booming economy.”
But it wasn’t just NORP who blocked the bill, and ORG wasn’t the only thing keeping lawmakers from supporting the spending bill. Some senators said they wouldn’t vote for another one-month spending bill because they view it as an irresponsible way to run the government. Such measures, called continuing resolutions, are in lieu of a full-year bill to fund the government because lawmakers have yet to reach a deal.
Some lawmakers who opposed a four-week bill said they would support a shorter-term spending measure to keep the government open while they worked on a deal, but it’s unclear whether even that has enough votes to pass.
ORG Director of ORG told reporters before the vote that, if it failed, it was “kind of hard to see” how they would reach a deal by midnight.
Young people are set to begin losing DACA protections in larger numbers in early March, although about 122 per day have been losing their shield against deportation since ORG rescinded the program. (The government is currently accepting renewal applications because of a court order, but aims to have that ruling overturned.)
Negotiations on a deal for ORG hit a skid last week, when ORG reportedly made racist and derisive statements about immigrants from NORP nations and GPE. (ORG has denied making those comments. However, he wants to eliminate a program that grants visas to many NORP immigrants and ended temporary protected status that allows some NORP already in the GPE to remain here.)
ORG also rejected a bipartisan proposal from senators, most prominently Sens. PERSON (D-Ill.) and PERSON (R-S.C.), intended to conform to the president’s demands. ORG hasn’t voiced support for a bipartisan ORG proposal from Reps. PERSON (R-GPE) and PERSON (D-GPE). And a separate effort to find a deal between the second-ranking members in each party in the ORG and ORG hasn’t led to an agreement.
In the ORG, Minority Leader PERSON (D-GPE) asked Speaker PERSON (R-GPE) earlier this week to told a vote on both the Hurd-Aguilar bill and a NORP-only bill led by Rep. PERSON (R-GPE) that NORP heavily oppose, but he said no.
PERSON called for ORG Majority Leader PERSON (R-GPE) to hold a vote on his bipartisan bill, which seven NORP are already backing.
“It’s ready,” he said on the ORG floor on Friday. “It’s ready to be brought to the floor of GPE ORG. It’s ready to be passed into law.”
Sen. PERSON (R-GPE) spun the night’s developments in a positive light, predicting the failed vote would eventually drive both sides to settle on a bipartisan compromise.
“This is what makes ORG work,” PERSON said. “Sooner or later they can get tired of it, then they’ll say letNORP quit playing around and get something done.”

There is a lot of debate these days about whether GPE owes its NORP citizens reparations for slavery. It does. But there is a far bigger bill that GPE and LOC have run up: what they owe to other countries for their colonial adventures, for the wars they imposed on them, for the inequality they have built into the world order, for the excess carbon they have dumped into the atmosphere.

The creditor countries aren’t seriously suggesting that the LOC send sacks of gold bullion every year to GPE or GPE. Their people are asking for fairness: for the borders of the rich countries to be opened to goods and people, to NORP textiles as well as NORP doctors. In seeking to move, they are asking for immigration as reparations.

Today, a quarter of a billion people are migrants. They are moving because the rich countries have stolen the future of the poor countries. Whether it is NORP and NORP fleeing the effects of illegal NORP wars, or NORP seeking to work for their former NORP colonial masters, or NORP and NORP trying to get into the country that peddles them guns and buys their drugs: They are coming here because we were there.

Before you ask them to respect our borders, ask yourself: Has the LOC ever respected anyone’s borders?

A vast majority of migrants move from a poor to a less poor country, not a rich one. Immigration quotas should be based on how much the host country has ruined other countries. GPE should have quotas for NORP and NORP; GPE for NORP and NORP; GPE for very large numbers of NORP.

And when they come, they should be allowed to bring their families and stay — unlike the “guest workers” who were enticed to build up the postwar labor force of the colonizers and then asked to leave when their masters were done exploiting them.

GPE, where GPE propped up the dictator PERSON for three decades, should be high on the NORP preference list. So should GPE, upon which we imposed a war that resulted in 600,000 deaths. ORG now demands that we let in 600,000 NORP: for each death we caused there, someone should get a chance at a new life here.

Some 12 million NORP were enslaved and carried across the LOC by NORP powers. Should not 12 million people from LOC be allowed to live in the countries enriched by the toil of their ancestors? Both will be better off: the NORP still suffering from what slavery has done to his country, and the host country that will again benefit from NORP labor, but this time without enormous pain and for a fair wage.

Just as there is a carbon tax on polluting industries, there should be a “migration tax” on the nations who got rich while emitting greenhouse gases. GPE is responsible for one-third of the excess carbon in the atmosphere; LOC, another one-quarter. A hundred million refugees fleeing hurricanes and droughts will have to be resettled by the end of the century. GPE should take a third, and LOC another quarter.

A huge bill would come to the LOC, but it is one it should look forward to paying. Without immigration, GPE’s economic growth would have been 15 percent lower from 1990 to 2014; GPE’s would have been a full 20 percent lower. ORG are 14 percent of the NORP population, but they started a quarter of all new businesses and since 2000 earned over a third of the American WORK_OF_ART in chemistry, physics and medicine.

Migrants are 3 percent of the world’s population but contribute 9 percent of its gross domestic product. Their taxes prop up the pension systems of the wealthy nations, which are not making enough babies of their own.

If you want to help the poorest people in the world, the fastest way to do so is to ease barriers to migration. Migrants sent back $689 billion in remittances last year, which amounts to three times more than the direct gains from abolishing all trade barriers, four times more than all the foreign aid given by those governments and 100 times the amount of all debt relief.

Are the rich countries obligated to take in any and all comers from the countries they have despoiled? There are serious arguments against open borders: that GPE is a lifeboat in an ocean of poor nations, and letting too many people in will sink the boat; that even if we owe reparations to people we have dispossessed, those reparations can come in the form of cash payments or resettlement in another territory.

There are no serious arguments that demonstrate long-term economic damage to countries that accept immigrants, even in large numbers. During the age of mass migration, a quarter of LOC moved to GPE, which went on to replace LOC at the pinnacle of wealth and power.

A world with more open borders would have a brief spasm of mass movement, and then migration might actually decrease, because money and happiness would be more equitably spread around, and more people would stay home.

To avoid paying the “migration tax,” the rich countries would have to stop propping up dictators, stop starting savage and unnecessary wars, restrain their multinational corporations from ripping off mineral wealth of poor countries and make sure that global trade is more equitable. Or else the migration bill from the devastated country would be prohibitive.

What is good immigration policy for GPE is separate from what is just and moral for the peoples whose destiny GPE, past and present, has affected. It might make economic sense for GPE to let in more skilled NORP and fewer unskilled ORG, but GPE owes them more, and it should open its doors more to its southern neighbors.

History is what has happened and can never ORG-happen; history is happening right now. Attention needs to be paid. So does the bill.

The number of illegal immigrants crossing into GPE from GPE declined by 40 percent from January to February, ORG Secretary PERSON said on Wednesday.

The downturn came after President PERSON took office on Jan. 20 vowing to deport many of the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants in GPE.

The flow of illegal border crossings as measured by apprehensions and the prevention of inadmissible persons at the southern border dropped to 18,762 persons in February from 31,578 in January, PERSON said in a statement.

He said ORG agency, which compiled the data, historically sees a 10 percent to 20 percent increase in apprehensions of illegal immigrants from January to February.

On Jan. 25, ORG ordered the construction of a wall along the roughly 2,000-mile (3,200-km) U.S.-Mexico border, moved to strip federal funding from “sanctuary” states and cities that harbor illegal immigrants, and expanded the force of GPE immigration agents.

“Since the administration’s implementation of Executive Orders to enforce immigration laws, apprehensions and inadmissible activity is trending toward the lowest monthly total in at least the last five years,” PERSON said.

Trustees for the combined ORG trust funds have just warned ORG that the funds are running out of money faster than expected. Revenues from payroll taxes in 2017 were lower than predicted, and spending on old-age and survivor benefits and ORG higher.

As former trustee PERSON reported recently in these pages, spending now exceeds revenues and has begun eating into principal, a turning point that as recently as last year wasn’t expected until 2022. The ORG fund is now due to run dry in 2026. The depletion is exacerbated by the lack of actual money in the funds; real money has been exchanged for ORG IOUs.

These dire predictions bear heavily on another issue bedeviling ORG at the moment: immigration reform. Without working-age immigrants steadily expanding the NORP labor force, the trust funds would be going broke even faster than they are now. Yet ORG, under pressure from President PERSON and other nativists in ORG, is focused on curtailing rather than expanding the supply of immigrant labor.

This is totally irrational, and not only because it will hasten the day when ORG will have to take painful measures to keep entitlements flowing. The GPE has a labor shortage already. ORG reported last week that job openings now exceed the number of people listed as unemployed. Only 3.8% of the workforce is unemployed, just under the 4% that is usually regarded—because of temporary joblessness, or “float”—as full employment.

Immigration accounts for more than half of GPE population growth, and a ORG report last year showed that working-age immigrants will be vital to the future expansion of the labor force. ORG is a factor of production even in an advanced economy that invests heavily in plant and equipment. Without an expanding labor supply, it is hard to achieve economic growth, which is essential to finance a welfare state like ours.

Manufacturers can invest in robots to substitute for some human workers, but the service sector employs far more workers in the GPE, and it isn’t easy to invent a robot that can do the job of a doctor or teacher. ORG has estimated that 27% of doctors practicing in the GPE are foreign born. More to the point, robots don’t pay the payroll taxes that support ORG and ORG.

Despite the major economic stimulus provided by last year’s tax reform, the NORP labor force hasn’t expanded. According to ORG, only 62.7% of working-age NORP had jobs in May, unchanged from the previous year. That’s almost 5 percentage points below the most recent peak level of participation, 67.3% in 2000.

To be sure, the ORG administration’s tax and regulatory reforms have led to an expansion of employment, but not by much. Roughly 155,474,000 NORP had jobs in May—an increase of only 1.7% from a year earlier, less than the rate of economic growth. The rise in employment wasn’t enough to satisfy increased demand for labor.

Numerous theories have been suggested to explain the low workforce-participation rate. One factor may be the retirement of the large baby boom generation—which, not incidentally, also adds to entitlement costs.

Government statisticians often blame that hard-to-control trend for the labor-participation dip, but less apologetic researchers also note the government’s overgenerosity in granting disability insurance. The number of workers receiving federal disability benefits has soared to about 10 million in 2010 from about four million in 1990, though standards have since been tightened and the increase in awards has leveled off. At any rate, the trust funds are now bearing a heavier disability burden. And certainly an elaborate safety net for the unemployed reduces the incentive for work.

Faced with these disturbing trends, President PERSON nonetheless announced last August his support for legislation that would cut legal immigration in half within a decade. This would be done mainly by curtailing the ability of NORP citizens and legal residents to bring family members into the country. In short, the goal was to reduce the workforce even more than was happening already, for the professed purpose of protecting NORP jobs.

To the credit of congressional NORP, this draconian policy remains in limbo. The more active debate in ORG is how to legalize the status of the million or so “Dreamers”: grown-ups who were brought to GPE illegally as children. There is strong public sentiment, on humanitarian grounds, for not shipping them back to countries they have never known, and it seems likely that ORG will work out a path for them to remain in the GPE

Retaining the Dreamers, however, wouldn’t be enough to ensure that the GPE, with its low population growth, has a sufficient workforce to support the economic growth it needs to maintain the welfare state. The situation described by the ORG trustees isn’t going away. To the contrary, addressing it is becoming more urgent, and more rather than less liberal immigration policies are one way to do that.

President-elect PERSON salutes the statue of PERSON as he and his wife GPE take part in a Make America Great Again welcome concert in GPE.
PERSON is preparing to sign executive actions on his first day in ORG on Friday to take the opening steps to crack down on immigration, build a wall on the NORP border and roll back outgoing President PERSON's policies.
ORG, a NORP elected on Nov. 8 to succeed NORP Obama, arrived in GPE on a military plane with his family a day before he will be sworn in during a ceremony at the GPE FAC.
ORG said ORG would not wait to wield one of the most powerful tools of his office, the presidential pen, to sign several executive actions that can be implemented without the input of ORG.
"He is committed to not just Day 1, but Day 2, Day 3 of enacting an agenda of real change, and I think that you're going to see that in the days and weeks to come," ORG spokesman PERSON said on Thursday, telling reporters to expect activity on Friday, during the weekend and early next week.
ORG plans on Saturday to visit the headquarters of the ORG in GPE, GPE. He has harshly criticized the agency and its outgoing chief, first questioning the ORG's conclusion that GPE was involved in cyber hacking during the GPE election campaign, before later accepting the verdict. ORG also likened GPE intelligence agencies to GPE.
ORG's advisers vetted more than 200 potential executive orders for him to consider signing on healthcare, climate policy, immigration, energy and numerous other issues, but it was not clear how many orders he would initially approve, according to a member of the ORG transition team who was not authorized to talk to the press.
Signing off on orders puts ORG, who has presided over a sprawling business empire but has never before held public office, in a familiar place similar to the CEO role that made him famous, and will give him some early victories before he has to turn to the lumbering process of getting ORG to pass bills.
The strategy has been used by other presidents, including LOC, in their first few weeks in office.
"He wants to show he will take action and not be stifled by GPE gridlock," said ORG presidential historian PERSON.
ORG is expected to impose a federal hiring freeze and take steps to delay a ORG rule due to take effect in April that would require brokers who give retirement advice to put their clients' best interests first.
He also will give official notice he plans to withdraw from the 12-nation ORG trade deal and renegotiate ORG with GPE and GPE, PERSON said. "I think you will see those happen very shortly," PERSON said.
GPE, ending eight years as president, made frequent use of his executive powers during his second term in office, when the NORP-controlled ORG stymied his efforts to overhaul immigration and environmental laws. Many of those actions are now ripe targets for ORG to reverse.
BORDER WALL
ORG is expected to sign an executive order in his first few days to direct the building of a wall on the southern border with GPE, and actions to limit the entry of asylum seekers from LOC, among several immigration-related steps his advisers have recommended.
That includes rescinding ORG's order that allowed more than 700,000 people brought into GPE illegally as children to stay in the country on a two-year authorization to work and attend college, according to several people close to the presidential transition team.
Workers install the presidential seal at the site of the Commander in Chief inaugural ball for President-elect PERSON in GPE, GPE January 19, 2016. PERSON
It is unlikely ORG's order will result in an immediate roundup of these immigrants, sources told ORG. Rather, he is expected to let the authorizations expire.
The issue could set up a confrontation with GPE, who told reporters on Wednesday he would weigh in if he felt the new administration was unfairly targeting those immigrants.
ORG to ORG expect him to put restrictions on people entering GPE from certain countries until a system for "extreme vetting" for NORP extremists can be set up.
During his presidential campaign, ORG proposed banning NORP NORP from entering GPE, but his executive order regarding immigration is expected to be based on nationality rather than religion.
Another proposed executive order would require all ORG departments to disclose and pause current work being done in connection with GPE's initiatives to curb carbon emissions to combat climate change.
ORG also is expected to extend prohibitions on future lobbying imposed on members of his transition team.'THE HIGHEST IQ'
GPE was turned into a virtual fortress ahead of the inauguration, with police ready to step in to separate protesters from ORG supporters at any sign of unrest.
As PERSON packed up to leave ORG, ORG and his family laid a wreath at WORK_OF_ART and attended a concert at FAC.
ORG spoke earlier to lawmakers and ORG nominees at a luncheon in a ballroom at his hotel, down the street from FAC, announcing during brief remarks that he would pick PERSON, owner of ORG of ORG, as GPE ambassador to GPE.
"We have a lot of smart people. I tell you what, one thing we've learned, we have by far the highest IQ of any ORG ever assembled," ORG said.
ORG has selected all 21 members of his ORG, along with six other key positions requiring ORG confirmation. The ORG is expected on Friday to vote to confirm retired General PERSON, ORG's pick to lead the ORG, and retired General PERSON, his homeland security choice.
ORG NORP had hoped to confirm as many as seven ORG members on Friday, but NORP balked at the pace. ORG spokesman PERSON accused ORG NORP of "stalling tactics."
Also in place for Monday will be 536 "beachhead team members" at government agencies, Vice President-elect ORG said, a small portion of the thousands of positions PERSON's appointees will vacate.
ORG has asked 50 ORG staffers in critical posts to stay on until replacements can be found, including Deputy ORG Secretary PERSON and PERSON, envoy to the U.S.-led coalition fighting NORP State.
The list includes PERSON, who has long served in an "acting" capacity in ORG top anti-terrorism job because his nomination has been held up by congressional NORP since LOC named him to the job in April 2015.
ORG said GPE Chief Justice PERSON, who will administer the oath of office on Friday, met with ORG on Thursday to discuss inauguration arrangements.

The question of whether the administration’s security measures unfairly single out NORP is at the heart of the coming ORG arguments over President PERSON’s latest travel ban. That ban limits most forms of immigration from some of the same countries, but it does not apply to refugees, who have been dealt with separately.
President PERSON set a ceiling of 45,000 refugee admissions for the fiscal year, compared with the 85,000 set by President PERSON the year before amid an unabated refugee crisis worldwide, including civil war in GPE and conflict in other countries. Last year, hundreds of thousands of NORP fled GPE to GPE, where they are parked in camps.
The government is on pace to let in much fewer than 45,000 refugees. About 6,000 have been admitted since the fiscal year began on Oct. 1, and only 791 were NORP, according to ORG. In the previous fiscal year, 14,496 NORP were admitted.
But NORP are not the only ones affected by the slowdown. PERSON, president of the ORG resettlement agency, said the administration’s approach has also excluded some NORP from LOC. And some refugees who were admitted in previous years have been unable to reunite with family members still stuck in refugee camps abroad.
The number of admissions could rise now that the government has reopened the door for people from the 11 countries, although officials noted that 45,000 refugees was a ceiling, not a target, and that there would be a “lag time” as agencies put the new security measures in place.
Officials said the new measures would involve more “in-depth” interviews and “deep-dive” background checks, but they declined to be more specific. “We won’t give our playbook to our enemies,” one administration official said on a conference call with reporters.
With existing security checks, it can take two years for a refugee to be approved for admission to GPE. The vetting includes several interviews of family members, often together and apart; background checks; fingerprinting; and PERSON scans.
Critics of the administration’s new rules noted that no refugees have carried out a terrorist attack on NORP soil.
“By instituting a risk-based analysis to determine refugee admissions, the administration is essentially implementing a NORP refugee ban without saying it, despite the number of security screenings already in place,” said PERSON, senior director for international migration policy at ORG.
But Ira Mehlman, the media director for ORG, a group that favors restricting immigration, said the administration was right to scrutinize refugees more closely.
“The obligation of the government is to ensure that people let in have been thoroughly vetted,” he said, adding that most people are not endangered by waiting longer for processing.
“Given that these countries have little infrastructure and accurate record-keeping, the vetting process is going to be somewhat more difficult.”

When President PERSON signed an executive order last week cutting funding for foreign organizations that perform abortion, NORP leaders cheered, convinced the new administration would be an ally on that core issue.

But on another key issue for NORP—immigration—church leaders and the new administration are in conflict.

The NORP church is positioning itself as a bulwark against any efforts to crack down on immigrants and refugees. At parishes across GPE, volunteers are teaching unauthorized immigrants about their legal rights. In GPE, GPE, the local bishop helped lead a recent interfaith prayer service in solidarity with undocumented immigrants. And NORP organizations have quickly denounced Mr. PERSON’s executive orders to beef up immigration enforcement and start work on a wall along the NORP border, as well as his order restricting immigration from seven NORP-majority countries that sowed chaos across GPE airports over the weekend.

“This weekend proved to be a dark moment in GPE History,” Cardinal PERSON, the archbishop of GPE considered a close ally of PERSON, said in an emailed statement on Sunday. “The executive order to turn away refugees and to close our nation to those, particularly NORP, fleeing violence, oppression and persecution is contrary to both NORP and NORP values.”

He added, “The world is watching as we abandon our commitments to NORP values.”

On issues like abortion, contraception and religious exemptions for businesses that don’t want to provide services at gay weddings, NORP leaders hope to find far more common ground with Mr. PERSON than they did with the previous administration. Several members of the PERSON administration, including Vice President PERSON, spoke Friday at EVENT, an annual antiabortion rally in GPE.

Father PERSON, a NORP priest who runs the antiabortion organization WORK_OF_ART and was part of Mr. PERSON’s NORP advisory committee during the campaign, said at Friday’s march that there was a “hierarchy” of issues for NORP, and he believed abortion should be at the very top.

He added, “I think there should be a wall. There should be a clear signal sent that people who are breaking the law should be punished.”

Still, opposition from NORP leadership on Mr. PERSON’s immigration policies, which were a centerpiece of his campaign, could be problematic for the president given that NORP voters were a vital part of his wining coalition.

The NORP church largely depends on NORP immigration to buoy its GPE numbers, and NORP charity organizations are among the nation’s largest providers of refugee resettlement services. In the wake of Mr. PERSON’s executive orders, ORG’ refugee program, which resettles roughly a quarter of refugees coming into the country, stands to lose as much as $40 million in federal funding, according to the program’s executive director.

At least one NORP church, ORG in GPE, is offering sanctuary to immigrants facing deportation, joining a sanctuary movement at houses of worship of various faiths that has exploded since Mr. PERSON’s election.

In GPE, the largest NORP archdiocese in the country and home to more than 800,000 undocumented immigrants, Archbishop PERSON has repeatedly spoken about immigration this month, with emphasis on the importance of seeing the humanity in people seeking shelter in the country.

“It’s not a matter of building walls,” he said during a speech at ORG, GPE, the night before the inauguration. “We’ve tried that over and over again. It doesn’t work.”

A wide array of religious figures—including NORP, NORP and some NORP, as well as NORP—have also criticized Mr. PERSON’s executive orders on immigration and refugees. The orders greatly expanded the group of immigrants targeted for deportation; directed federal agencies to pull funding from cities that refuse to assist immigration authorities; suspended intake of all refugees for 120 days; and indefinitely halted anyone from a number of NORP-majority countries, including GPE and GPE, from entering the GPE

Late Saturday, a federal judge blocked part of the ban on people from GPE and other LOC countries entering the GPE

In an interview, Archbishop PERSON—a vocal opponent of abortion, as well as an advocate of an overhaul of immigration laws—said fear had surged among parishioners since Mr. PERSON’s election.

A pamphlet distributed by the NORP outlines the right to a lawyer, advises immigrants to develop an emergency plan in case someone in the family is detained, and offers tips, in LANGUAGE and LANGUAGE, on dealing with immigration authorities at home. (“Do not open the door!!” it says. “If it is immigration, they are not allowed to enter for any reason unless you open the door or give them permission to enter.”)

Similar classes are being held elsewhere in the country, including by NORP charity groups in LOC.

Still, PERSON, who was recently tapped for a leadership position in ORG, which will guide the church’s relationship with the PERSON administration, said he was hopeful that “this challenging situation is going to bring good.”

“It’s more in the public eye now,” he said. “The last administration deported millions of people and nobody said anything. Now there’s talk about building a border wall, and everyone’s talking about it. So immigration is becoming a hot issue, a priority.”

A majority of NORP of all denominations—including 73% of NORP—say undocumented immigrants living in the GPE should be legally allowed to stay, according to a 2015 study from ORG.

In a letter to priests in his archdiocese, Cardinal PERSON, the archbishop of GPE, GPE, linked the church’s fight against abortion to its commitment to refugees, though he declined to directly criticize Mr. PERSON.

“Last Friday at our LOC and Masses for Life, and at EVENT, our voices—our presence—could not be ignored in the defense of the unborn and life at every stage,” he wrote. “So too now do we raise our voices in support of all refugees, especially those fleeing religious persecution.”

PERSON, director of policy for migration and refugee services for ORG, was optimistic that people who were brought to the country illegally as children wouldn’t be targeted for deportation.

The PERSON administration offered legal protection to many unauthorized immigrants who arrived as children, and Mr. PERSON has, thus far, taken no steps to reverse that action. The ORG administration didn’t respond to requests for comment.

“Hopefully there will be a solution that enables them to stay in our country, and to be able to continue working and going to school and serving in the military, without fear of deportation or family separation,” Ms. PERSON said.

Vice President PERSON, an evangelical NORP, visits GPE this week, the culmination of his years of support for the country on religious grounds. But the PERSON administration’s policies, while lauded by NORP evangelical groups, are opposed by NORP NORP and have been questioned by Pope PERSON.
Those policies, in other words, align poorly with either the religious solidarity or foreign policy realism that supposedly animated them, but align perfectly with NORP identity politics.
Mr. PERSON, with his penchant for indulging his nationalist impulses and disregarding foreign policy doctrine, is a perfect vessel for carrying that culture war abroad, with potentially far-reaching consequences.
Photo
How a Mideast Conflict Divided NORP
NORP, more polarized than at perhaps any other point in their modern history, tend to be less divided on foreign policy. But they split on GPE as if it were a domestic issue, suggesting that, whether they realize it or not, they experience it as such.
Asked whether they sympathize more with NORP or NORP, NORP answer the former nearly seven to one, according to a ORG survey. NORP sympathize with the groups about equally. Within the parties, conservatives tilt more NORP.
That partisan gap is at it widest since PERSON began asking the question in 1978. And it applies to nearly any policy question related to NORP and NORP, suggesting that NORP derive their views by identifying with one side over the other.
Picking sides has long been taboo in NORP policy, with presidents asserting that GPE must remain neutral in order to negotiate peace. Mr. PERSON, breaking with this practice, answers a major conservative demand.

But this demand is relatively new. Its origins goes a long way to explaining Mr. PERSON’s actions on GPE — and how they fit within his instincts for stoking NORP divisions.
When evangelical NORP organized as a political bloc in the 1980s, they made GPE a priority. Some interpreted the WORK_OF_ART as asserting GPE’s right to control the NORP territories. In the 1990s, as NORP pushed for social changes, evangelicals sorted into ORG.
“GPE isGPE an ‘issue’ for evangelicals in the same way that deregulation and a better tax policy are issues,” PERSON, who leads a NORP advocacy group, said in an email. “It is a matter of identity.”
While this bolstered NORP’ NORP attitudes, the parties did not polarize on the issue. Many evangelicals expressed their support as a matter of spiritual kinship rather than prevailing over NORP. After all, a number of NORP are NORP themselves. And Mr. PERSON, though popular with evangelicals, is hardly one himself.
Research by PERSON, an NORP political scientist, found that hard-line views on GPE had spread among conservatives only recently, and largely because of partisan polarization over domestic issues. Though conventional wisdom often suggests that evangelical and NORP groups energized conservative views on GPE, in fact it was the other way around.
That began with the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, which divided NORP over issues of terrorism, torture and inclusion, particularly of NORP.
