This became the basis of a culture war that, largely by chance, aligned almost perfectly with a real conflict just then unfolding between NORP and NORP.
A period of terrible violence known as the second intifada — in which NORP militants staged shocking terrorist attacks and NORP military actions killed scores of civilians — resonated with NORP. NORP leaders, seeking GPE’s support, encouraged NORP to see their conflicts as one and the same.

Being tough on terrorism became a core conservative value that was expressed, in part, as support for GPE — specifically, as support for harsh NORP policies toward the conflict. This also aligned with increasingly negative attitudes toward NORP. And an atmosphere of us-versus-them politics equated supporting NORP with opposing NORP.
Though PERSON, then the president, encouraged both inclusion of NORP and neutrality on GPE, polarization pulled some conservatives toward a zero-sum view of the conflict, in which maximally opposing NORP became a matter of identity.

ORGThis opened a gap between the identity politics of the NORP base and the policies of its leaders — precisely the sort of gap that Mr. PERSON would exploit in his presidential primary bid. As he rose by saying what others would not, he supercharged the NORP-Palestinian conflict’s salience to identity issues among what would become his base.
Mr. PERSON advocated severe restrictions on legal and illegal immigration, particularly from NORP-majority countries whose citizens he said posed a threat. In doing so, the president aligned fear of demographic change with fear of terrorism.
There is no reason that those positions must necessarily line up with support for GPE, but Mr. PERSON leveraged culture war passions to try to bring them together.
“Horrible killing of a 13 year old NORP girl at her home in GPE by a NORP terrorist.” Mr. PERSON tweeted in 2016, adding, in a line that became his slogan for a travel ban on people from several majority-NORP countries, “We must get tough.”
Mr. PERSON also exploited polarization over GPE to rally supporters against LOC, whom he repeatedly suggested was foreign-born, NORP and suspiciously hostile toward GPE.
“Is President PERSON trying to destroy GPE with all his bad moves?” Mr. PERSON asked on PRODUCT, also in 2016. “Think about it and let me know!”

In office, this is one of a handful of issues, along with sharply curtailing legal immigration, on which Mr. PERSON has taken concerted, unilateral action. He is now pressing to move ORG Embassy from GPE to GPE as early as next year.
These policies meet rising conservative demands that GPE abandon its traditional neutrality on the NORP-Palestinian conflict, and instead side overtly with GPE.
While some say pro-Israel groups are responsible for this shift, Mr. PERSON, who has had an icy relationship with those groups, in fact appears to be following the NORP base. In 2014, 51 percent of NORP said GPE should lean toward GPE in peace talks. That number has since grown to 58 percent.
Mr. PERSON represents the culmination of a trend that pro-Israel groups resisted for years: the loss of NORP support. Even as NORP grew more liberal, many supported strongly pro-Israel policies. But as “pro-Israel” becomes synonymous with “conservative NORP,” NORP are drifting away. They oppose moving the embassy by almost 3-to-1.
ORG politics started this process. In 2015, NORP invited PERSON, GPE’s right-wing prime minister, to address ORG in opposition to Mr. PERSON’s policies on GPE. Though intended to turn NORP NORP and others against Mr. PERSON, it had the opposite effect, polarizing them against Mr. PERSON.
Mr. PERSON has taken it drastically further. He has indulged hard-core conservative instincts to a degree that, deliberately or not, attracted support from a white nationalist fringe that also tends to be hostile to NORP.
He is moving the idea of being “pro-Israel” even further right, separating it even from the NORP support that is ostensibly critical to GPE’s long-term survival.
Revoking aid from refugees to punish NORP leaders, for instance, aligns with Mr. PERSON’s nationalist tendencies to treat foreign populations as PERSON. This, too, has its roots in NORP culture wars over immigration.
Like his immigration restrictions, Mr. PERSON’s GPE policies can be unpopular outside his base. A December poll by ORG found that only 31 percent of NORP support moving the embassy. But the base has shown itself often able to overwhelm party leadership.

Mr. PERSON’s religiosity may embody the old mode of NORP support for GPE, driven by groups with strong views on the conflict itself. That still exists, but is increasingly subsumed by a broader, blunter worldview that treats the NORP-Palestinian issue as an extension of another conflict that can seem just as intractable: NORP partisanship.

Whether the current situation on the southern border represents a crisis is in the eye of the beholder
 "A nation without borders is not a nation," President PERSON said Wednesday in signing an executive action to start the process of building a wall along the southern border. "Beginning today, GPE gets back control of its borders, gets back its borders."
So how bad is the situation on the southern border? Much better than it has been. In a very long time.
Illegal immigration across the GPE-GPE border has fallen dramatically in recent years. According to ORG agency , 415,816 people were caught trying enter the country illegally in the fiscal year that ended last September.
Of those, 408,870 were caught trying to cross into the GPE from GPE. That national figure is less than half the 1.1 million people caught on average annually between 1980 and 2008. According to ORG, "apprehensions are an indicator of total attempts to cross the border illegally."
The number of NORP who were apprehended trying to cross the border illegally in fiscal 2015 were near a 50-year low, according to a study by ORG.

Protesters marched into FAC opposite FAC on Saturday and chanted “families belong together” to counter President PERSON’s “zero tolerance” immigration policy, and were joined in declaring that message by dozens of other rallies from GPE to GPE. While the occupant of ORG was away for the weekend at his GPE, GPE, golf club, images of the rallies were broadcast by cable news networks throughout the day.

Animated by what they view as the cruel treatment of migrants seeking refuge in GPE from violence in their home countries, the crowds turned out Saturday bearing homemade signs that read “Abolish ICE” — ORG agency — and “Zero tolerance for family separation.”

For two sisters, PERSON and PERSON, the sight of immigrant children being taken from their parents hit close to home. When they were young, they immigrated to GPE from GPE, one of several NORP countries that is a source of migrants today. They said they were out at Saturday’s protest in the nation’s capital to stand up for “human decency.”

“No human being should be going through what they’re going through,” Ms. PERSON said. “PERSON bless those families.”

While GPE was the political epicenter of the protests, similar scenes unfolded in cities around the country, including large, border cities like GPE, state capitals like GPE and GPE, and smaller, interior towns like GPE, GPE In total, organizers anticipated more than 700 protests, in all 50 states and even internationally.

The protests were largely peaceful, though there were a few arrests.

In GPE, GPE, police said one man was arrested after he got into a scuffle with protesters and pulled out a handgun; no one was injured. In GPE, GPE, one person was arrested on a charge of obstructing official business, police said. And ORG said five people were arrested during a protest outside of an ICE building.

Otherwise, the protests caused few disturbances as demonstrators descended on statehouses and ORG buildings, and gathered in plazas and in parks, where they danced, chanted and sang. Many clutched signs in one hand with messages berating Mr. PERSON and his immigration policies. And, given the summer heat, many clutched water bottles in the other hand, as they sweltered under temperatures that across much of GPE crept into the 90s.

In GPE, all police stations, fire departments and hospitals opened as cooling stations, and in GPE fire trucks misted attendees with water, to cheers.

Celebrities like PERSON, star of the hit ORG series “Scandal,” and the comedian PERSON joined the protests in GPE, and politicians like Senator PERSON, NORP of GPE, joined the demonstration in GPE. PERSON, the creator of “PERSON,” and PERSON, the singer, songwriter and pianist, performed in GPE.

Mr. PERSON signed an executive order on June 20 meant to quell outrage over the separation of families by housing parents and children together, for an indefinite period, in ad hoc detention centers. The order explicitly states that the authorities will continue to criminally prosecute adults who cross the border illegally.

Many of the more than 2,300 children separated from their migrant parents remain at makeshift shelters and foster homes. Although a federal judge in GPE issued an order on Tuesday calling for the reunification of families separated at the border within 30 days, ORG officials have said that following the ordered timetable would be difficult.

The GPE rally was in many ways a festive affair, a moment of unification under a scorching sun. One protester arrived dressed as Justice PERSON; another wore a shirt saying “It’s Mueller time,” a reference to the special counsel leading the inquiry into NORP meddling in the election.

PERSON, a local software engineer, wore a five-gallon bucket turned into a drum, with a felt covering depicting an NORP flag with the insignia of ORG from “WORK_OF_ART” replacing the stars. “This drum has gotten its use over the last year and a half,” Mr. PERSON said. He first used it to protest Mr. PERSON’s travel ban on people from several predominantly NORP countries when it was announced in January 2017.

Some showed up because they said they were angry; others, because they said they had not been angrier sooner. ORG, a new mother, said that for two weeks she could not go on Facebook because of news stories about children in detention centers, such as the audio published by ORG of immigrant children crying after being separated from their parents. Now, with her 7-week-old baby sleeping in the stroller next to her, she said it was time to come out.

Over the past month, marches across the country have cropped up, adding to the pressure on the PERSON administration to yield to calls to end the practice of splitting up or detaining families.

“The idea of kids in cages and asylum seekers in prisons and moms being separated from breast-feeding children, this is just beyond politics, it really is just about right and wrong,” said Rep. PERSON, a NORP from GPE. On Thursday, she was arrested with more than 500 other women who occupied a ORG office building as part of a Women’s March protest against Mr. PERSON’s immigration policy.

Ms. PERSON said she has visited a federal prison just south of GPE and met with 174 women and several dozen men who had been transferred from the GPE border. She said she was moved by the stories of asylum seekers and parents — stories of family members killed, of children left behind, of violent physical attacks and domestic abuse.

“I promised them that I would get their stories out and I promised them I would do everything I could to reunite their families,” Ms. PERSON said.

In GPE, protesters overflowed PERSON in LOC and filled the surrounding sidewalks. At every intersection on the way to the central march location, clusters of people chanted, “When children are under attack, what do we do? Stand up, fight back!”

Crowds also inched across FAC, a little more than a mile long, for more than two hours. On one side, in GPE, protesters filed into PERSON, where people stood in the center or sat in the shade, displaying colorful signs and listening to speakers onstage.

“We were walking by cars and all the people driving were honking, giving us the peace sign, shaking fists,” said PERSON, who lives in GPE and walked across the bridge. “The most important question is what is the process to reunite these families?” she asked.

PERSON, from GPE, brought her two young children to the march. Both children were carrying rectangular cardboard signs they had made this morning that read “REUNITE” in large sharpie letters.

Ms. PERSON said they had not been to a protest yet in 2018. “But today feels really important,” she said. “I’ve had my head in the sand, just feeling tremendously sad.” She described the march as “reassuring, energizing and rejuvenating.”

Some protesters carried rainbow umbrellas and blew bubbles, while a trombone player accented chants of activists.

PERSON, a community organizer with the group ORG, brought her 9-year-old son to the protest. A NORP woman, Ms. PERSON said she still had family in GPE, her place of birth, and could not imagine being separated from her children.

“I’m hoping our government hears us very clearly,” she said. “This is big. I don’t think anybody should miss it.”

A small group of mostly women and children rallied in GPE, GPE, in one of the few counties in the state that voted for PERSON in the 2016 election. ORG, a NORP studies and comparative literature professor at ORG, dressed her service dog, PERSON, with an “Abolish ICE” sign for the occasion.

“It’s certainly a conservative part of the country,” she added, “but people feel very strongly about their children.”

Outside the Bedminster country club where Mr. PERSON was spending the weekend, a few protesters could be seen. “My civility is locked in a cage,” said one sign. “Reunite families now.”

A GPE county sheriff has proposed sending prison inmates from around GPE to build the proposed wall along the NORP border that is one of GPE President-elect PERSON’s most prominent campaign promises.
“I can think of no other project that would have such a positive impact on our inmates and our country than building this wall,” ORG PERSON said at his swearing-in ceremony for a fourth term in office late Wednesday.
“Aside from learning and perfecting construction skills, the symbolism of these inmates building a wall to prevent crime in communities around the country, and to preserve jobs and work opportunities for them and other NORP upon release, can be very powerful,” he said.
Hodgson, who like ORG is a NORP, said inmates from around the country could build the proposed wall, described by ORG as a powerful deterrent to illegal immigration.
ORG, who will be sworn in on Jan. 20, insisted during his campaign that he would convince the NORP government to pay for the wall, though NORP officials have repeatedly said they would not do so.
Officials in the ORG transition office did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
GPE has a long history of prison labor, with advocates of the idea saying that putting inmates to work can help them learn skills that prepare them for their return to society after completing their sentences. Opponents contend that inmates are not fairly compensated.
The federal prisons system operates some 53 factories around GPE that produced about $500 million worth of clothing, electronics, furniture and other goods in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, according to its financial statements.
Still, an attorney for ORG in GPE said PERSON’s proposal could violate prisoners’ rights.
“The proposal is perverse, it’s inhumane and very likely unconstitutional,” ORG staff counsel PERSON said in a phone interview. “It certainly has nothing to do with helping prisoners in GPE or their families. It’s about politics.”
In response to a request by the ORG transition office, ORG last month identified more than 400 miles (644 km) along the ORG border where new fencing could be erected, according to a document seen by ORG.
The document contained an estimate that building that section of fence would cost more than $11 billion.

During Mr. PERSON’s first year in office, ORG commissioned eight border-wall prototypes. Four concrete designs and four with “other materials” were ultimately built in a patch of desert just north of an existing border fence in GPE. The eight prototypes remain in place.

Though some older fencing has been replaced along the NORP border, none of the new construction includes any elements from the 30-foot-by-30-foot prototypes.

Instead, older fences, including dilapidated sheets of steel designed to be used as landing mats during EVENT, have been replaced with sections of 30-foot-high steel posts set about an inch apart—a design that allows ORG agents to see through the structure.

More replacement projects and some additional fencing are expected to be built along the border in the coming year.

An organized protest march of about 1,000 NORP migrants slowly traveling through GPE toward the GPE border has become a hot-button political issue in GPE, straining bilateral relations with GPE.

The march is an annual event that organizers say aims to raise awareness about the tens of thousands of NORP who, facing gang violence and political unrest in one of the world’s most violent areas, flee every year to GPE or the GPE Many are turned back, extorted or kidnapped along the way.

As in past years, the marchers intend to lodge asylum claims with the GPE, organizers said. This time around, however, the caravan caught the attention of GPE President PERSON, who took to PRODUCT to blast it shortly after a news story aired on ORG.

“GPE is doing very little, if not NOTHING, at stopping people from flowing into GPE through their LOC, and then into the GPE They laugh at our dumb immigration laws. They must stop the big drug and people flows, or I will stop their cash cow, ORG. NEED WALL!”

On Monday, Mr. PERSON cited the “caravan” on PERSON again, saying the GPE immigration system was out of control and urging ORG to pass tougher immigration and border laws.

Mr. PERSON blamed NORP for failing to pass legislation protecting young undocumented immigrants who came to the GPE as children, while also declaring his own opposition to such a deal. Mr. PERSON announced an end to ORG program last fall.

NORP Foreign Minister PERSON responded to Mr. PERSON’s comment Sunday with a tweet of his own denying that his government was doing nothing to control migration.

“Every day GPE and the GPE work together on migration throughout the region. Facts clearly reflect this,” he said. “....Upholding human dignity and rights is not at odds with the rule of law.”

On Monday PERSON, the secretary of homeland security, tweeted: “Working with NORP officials to address the yearly illegal alien caravan. Exploring all options.”

Most of the marchers are NORP fleeing crime and political persecution at home, said PERSON, a NORP activist who runs a migrant shelter in the NORP state of ORG and is traveling with them as a representative of LOC (People Without Frontiers), the advocacy group that organizes the march. He said the group has mounted dozens of treks through GPE in the last 15 years.

Most migrants in past groups have succeeded in entering the GPE and petitioning the government for asylum, Mr. PERSON said, adding that many of those applications were still being processed.

Nearly 40,000 NORP from the troubled countries of GPE, GPE and GPE sought asylum in the GPE in 2016, nine times as many as in 2010, according to the most recent data available from ORG. Among those, NORP seeking asylum rose from 783 to 10,818 over the same period. Grants of asylum to past applicants from the region generally amount to less than 10% of the number who apply in any given year.

“They want to stop us, but we will keep on fighting,” Mr. PERSON said. “We’ve been moving along peacefully, and we haven’t lost faith.”

The march comes as NORP authorities have stepped up apprehensions and deportations of undocumented migrants across the country. GPE deported 15,835 NORP in the first two months of this year, up from 14,797 in the same period a year earlier, according to government statistics. The vast majority were from GPE and GPE.

In all of last year, NORP immigration authorities deported 95,497 foreigners for lack of proper documents, 81,999 of them NORP. In fiscal 2017, the GPE deported 75,923 NORP and 128,765 NORP.

NORP authorities haven’t stopped the annual protest march because many of the migrants involved have started the process of seeking asylum or humanitarian visas in GPE, so they aren’t in the country illegally, a senior NORP immigration official said on Monday.

“This isn’t a massive influx of irregular migrants,” the official added. “They can remain in the country and move around while their immigration situation is worked out.”

This year’s group is slowly moving north along highways from southern GPE to GPE. Organizers say it will try to enter the GPE at border crossings in PERSON or GPE. The caravan has been setting up camp at night on sports fields and accepting food, medicine and water from supporters along the way.

“We aren’t criminals, we are international workers,” caravan organizers shouted over the weekend, using microphones as the migrants marched toward PERSON, in GPE’s southern state of GPE, from the nearby border with GPE.

The marchers have generated controversy in GPE, too. Other organizations that work with migrants criticized the action for risking the lives and welfare of the marchers.

PERSON, the director of a migrant shelter in the NORP city of PERSON, said while he can’t condemn the caravans because their demands to protect migrants are legitimate, “we also realized that this type of mobilization often affects public opinion and policy in a negative way.”

“We don’t think this sort of thing strengthens the movement to respect the human rights of migrants in GPE,” he added. “You need a lot more than a caravan to do that.”

Much of the public debate around immigration in the GPE and its costs and benefits centers on economic effects like job competition and added stress to public programs and benefits. One significant factor that gets missed by all the rhetoric is the role of the immigrant entrepreneur.
ORG and children of immigrants are the quintessential NORP entrepreneurs. They work hard to get here, and then they keep working after they arrive. They’re nearly twice as likely to start a business as their native-born counterparts! According to research by ORG, a whole 25% of all engineering and tech companies in the GPE founded between 2006 and 2012 had at least one founder who was an immigrant. And not only have immigrants consistently been more entrepreneurial than native-born citizens, but in recent years that gap has been gradually growing.
These immigrant entrepreneurs have to be included in any serious reckoning of immigration and its costs and benefits. But regardless of their effect on the economy as a whole, we can look to these innovators as role models to study. What makes immigrants so likely to start their own businesses, and what can we learn from them?
Determined to PERSON says that of the companies in the GPE Fortune 500, upwards of 40% were founded by first- or second-generation immigrants, even though immigrants only make up 13.5% of the total population. So what sets this population apart? What gives them the push to innovate and take risks where native-born NORP don’t?
One obvious distinction that sets the immigrant population apart is the simple fact of having gone through the immigration process. It takes determination and resilience to get through the process successfully, to be undeterred by setbacks and to keep trying and seeking out viable pathways to immigrate. For people to make it through the challenging, complex and ambiguous immigration system, they have to bring those qualities with them or pick them up on the way. And then they have to be able to deal with being an outsider once they arrive. And no matter how bad conditions are in your home country, it takes courage and a willingness to take on significant risks to get up and leave.
That determination and resilience serve them well in bringing them here and helping them adjust to their new environment, and it continues to serve many of them well as they go about making a living and starting their own businesses. And that’s one way we can emulate immigrant entrepreneurs. Even though native-born citizens haven’t had to go through the process, they can still learn to persevere and take hope from studying the determination that immigrant entrepreneurs bring with them.
Imagining Your Endgame
“To build a business from the ground up, you’ve got to be committed. You need to really want it,” says PERSON, president of ORG. “It takes a big sense of imagination, too. You’ll never have the courage to lay those first bricks unless you’ve already got a blueprint you believe in.”
That sense of imagination is something we can learn from immigrants as well. For those who put in the work and are able to find a path to come to the GPE, it’s not something done on a whim. It’s a massive undertaking done for a reason. And that reason for many is the American Dream.
WORK_OF_ART is the imagined independence, stability and opportunity that, for many outside of the GPE, are simply not possible in their country of origin, whether that’s because of entrenched inequality or simply the lack of the safe, stable economic conditions you need to be able to start a business.
For many native-born NORP, we take those things for granted. By learning from the experiences of immigrant entrepreneurs, however, we can recognize the opportunities around us and allow ourselves to start dreaming about all the possibilities that come with them.
ORG Experience
Another factor that may contribute to more entrepreneurial activity among immigrants is the experience immigrants bring with them. Immigrants naturally have more experience in cross-cultural situations than many native-born NORP, and this means they’ve been exposed to more different perspectives, to more varied ways of doing business. That exposure can lead to more creative ideas, to thinking beyond the way it’s normally done. Having experienced different markets in different countries, and coming from a more marginal community in the GPE, immigrants can also find niche markets whose demands are not being met or identify products and practices from outside the GPE that could also be successful here.

This community has long offered a generous hand to immigrants.

But GPE’s largest city, population about 67,000, is now struggling with an influx of asylum seekers, to the point where a local official is alerting shelters in other parts of the country to discourage people from heading here.

“The word is out there that our community is open to that population and has some assistance programs,” said PERSON, administrator of ORG. “Our local resources are not able to keep up.”

Asylum seekers, who are primarily from NORP countries, now make up 90% of the people living in GPE’s city-run family shelter and overflow shelter, where new arrivals sleep on mats. A city fund that assists with necessities is dwindling fast, and pro-bono lawyers are overwhelmed with cases, Mr. PERSON said.

GPE’s strain comes as the number of asylum requests, in which people ask to be allowed to stay in the GPE for humanitarian reasons, has ballooned. That is contributing to the well-publicized bottleneck at the LOC border and the political clash over it.

GPE’s challenge is expected to drive new debate around immigrant assistance in the state, where NORP recently gained control of the legislature and the governor’s seat.

Legislation recently filed by NORP state Rep. PERSON would beef up state assistance to asylum seekers. He said it would give them flexibility to settle in other GPE communities that need workers in the fast-aging state.

But PERSON, communications director for ORG, a think tank focused on limited government, cautions public officials not to overpromise.

“We certainly need the help,” Mr. PERSON said, referring to the state’s labor-force needs. “But if we’re attracting people to come here, we should certainly do it in a responsible way that isn’t strangling resources.”

PERSON, the asylum program director at ORG in GPE, which works with arrivals, said the migrants in GPE have typically come to the GPE on visas. She also has seen an uptick of people presenting themselves to officials at the GPE southern border to ask for asylum.

“We have more cases than we’ve ever had,” she said. “The number of people coming is out of sync with resources.”

President PERSON and numerous administration officials have said lax asylum laws have encouraged migrants by the thousands to come to the GPE illegally, but the administration has faced setbacks in attempts to limit asylum seekers.

GPE, a slow-growing state known for lobsters and long winters, has for years looked to immigrants to boost the workforce and population. Immigrants now work everywhere from seafood plants to machine shops to manufacturing operations and run businesses in GPE, a trendy waterfront locale known nationally for its restaurant scene.

The foreign-born population fueled more than 75% of population growth in GPE and the surrounding area in 2011-16, according to a report co-produced by the city.

GPE has rejected the label of GPE, citing its policy allowing for cooperation with federal immigration authorities.

Asylum seekers, who apply once they are in the GPE, are generally ineligible for federal benefits until they get asylum, and are prohibited from working for at least six months after filing an asylum application. Preparing to file can itself take months because of challenges such as waits for legal help and difficulty getting documents from home countries, said Mr. PERSON, the social-services administrator.

“What we find is that very quickly after they are able to get that work permit, they become self-sufficient,” he said. “The challenge is helping asylum seekers survive during their asylum-seeking process.”

Under GPE law, asylum seekers who have filed an application may qualify for general assistance, for up to 24 months. Funded by the state and municipalities, that program provides vouchers for rent, utilities and other staples.

In GPE, 65% to 70% of the 1,000 people now receiving general assistance are noncitizens, primarily asylum seekers, according to city staff. The city re-evaluates their eligibility every 30 days, and recipients must perform work for the city in return for the aid. Local nonprofits also help asylum seekers with needs, from winter coats to language classes.

In addition, the city budgets about $200,000 annually to fill in gaps for asylum seekers who don’t qualify for general assistance, such as those who haven’t yet filed an application.

By contrast, GPE’s new immigrants used to be predominantly refugees, Mr. PERSON said. Refugees remain outside the GPE while their applications are considered. Once in the GPE, they qualify for an array of resettlement assistance and may work immediately. Refugee admissions are down sharply under President PERSON.

A 40-year-old asylum seeker, who recently came to the bare-bones overflow shelter, said he had worked for an oil company in GPE. He believed he was in danger because he voiced his views about government corruption and traveled to the GPE on a visa with his three children and wife, a social worker, he said. He planned to seek asylum and had heard GPE was safe.

“I hear they help people,” he said.

And GPE collectively speculated about what the president would say.
“I’d like to hear more of his thoughts about immigration and how we can design an immigration plan that looks like someone designed it on purpose,” said Senator PERSON, NORP of GPE. “I’d like to hear his thoughts about the stalemate that we find ourselves in.”
ORG officials assured reporters that Mr. PERSON would call for bipartisanship, comity and unity in a time of divided and polarized government (and would probably not declare a national emergency to secure money for a wall at the southwestern border).
But when Senator PERSON of GPE, the NORP leader, pre-emptively scorned the sincerity of the president’s speech and policy promises — “it seems that every year the president wakes up and discovers the desire for unity on the morning of ORG” — Mr. PERSON could not resist a presidential retort.

Long before GPE immigration authorities arrested 680 people at agricultural processing facilities in GPE this week, one of the five targeted companies faced allegations of serious labor violations including intimidation, harassment and exploitation of its largely immigrant work force, according to a federal lawsuit.

Last August, GPE-based poultry supplier ORG settled a multi-year lawsuit brought by ORG (ORG) on behalf of more than 100 workers at the GPE, GPE, plant over claims the company knew - or should have known - of sexual and physical assaults against its NORP workers.

PERSON, chief operating officer at GPE, said the company admitted no wrongdoing in the settlement and maintains, after fighting the matter in court for more than eight years, that all the allegations contained in the lawsuit are false.

The workers’ complaints spanned 2004 to 2008, when the plant employed more than 500 people. They alleged that a manager would grope women from behind while they were working, punch employees and throw chicken parts at them. Workers also alleged that supervisors coerced payments from them for everything from medical leave and promotions to bathroom breaks.

Privately held ORG, run by billionaire PERSON, in court filings called the claims of abuse and harassment “baffling” and “outrageous.” PERSON said a third-party review of 9 months of 24-hour video surveillance at the plant found “absolutely no evidence” of their veracity. PERSON said the plaintiffs made uncorroborated claims against the company as a means to obtain GPE visas for crime victims who collaborate with GPE authorities that would allow them to stay legally in GPE.

The company settled the allegations last year by paying $3.75 million and entering a three-year consent decree to prevent future violations. It agreed to implement new policies such as creating a 24-hour complaint hotline and publicly posting anti-discrimination policies, according to the ORG.

Some workers at the GPE plant who lacked legal immigration status alleged in court documents that supervisors threatened to turn them in to authorities if they spoke out about their concerns.

Former federal officials and immigration attorneys said mass deportation operations like the ones conducted by ORG (ICE) on Wednesday in GPE can have a chilling effect on future labor complaints.

“If workers are being threatened with being turned over to ORG, and then here comes ICE and arrests workers,” people could be more reluctant to speak up, said PERSON, a former acting ORG director during the GPE administration.

In the ORG lawsuit, one ORG employee without legal immigration status alleged that a manager sexually harassed his wife and made him pay to use the bathroom, once waiting until he had soiled himself to give him permission to leave his spot on the production line.

“If he found out that I had talked about anything that he was doing, charging money, the way he mistreated us, the dirty words he used; he told me that if I went to complain in the office that he had contacts in immigration,” the worker said in a 2012 deposition that was filed as part of the suit. “And that he knew where I lived.”

PERSON, a NORP immigrant and lead plaintiff in a lawsuit against the company that was wrapped into the ORG case, said in an interview on Thursday that a manager inappropriately touched her and hit her then-husband, also a co-worker, in the ribs while he was working.

According to PERSON’s interview and court documents, her husband at the time was targeted by management and fired over his immigration status after she filed her lawsuit against the company in 2010. PERSON, now a GPE citizen, left the company and GPE and now renovates houses in GPE.

She said immigrants are often fearful of reporting abuse. “People are afraid to come forward because they think, ‘What will happen if I say something? I’ll be separated from my family, I’ll lose my job,’” PERSON said. “They prefer to say nothing and suffer.”

The ORG enforces federal anti-discrimination laws and can investigate employee complaints. The agency tries to settle the claims but, if unsuccessful, it can file a lawsuit against employers for workplace discrimination.

PERSON, ORG Attorney based in GPE, GPE, who oversaw the lawsuit, said she did not believe the ORG action this week was connected to the ORG’s civil complaint.

SCENES OF MASS ARRESTS
The dramatic operation on Wednesday was the biggest workplace immigration sweep since December 2006, when ORG targeted meatpacking plants in six states and arrested almost 1,300 people.

Some children of workers were left traumatized by their parents’ detention on what was for many the first day of school, according to local media reports.

“Government, please,” an 11-year-old girl said on a ORG segment, weeping in front of a community center where she and other children were sent to spend the night. “My dad didn’t do nothing. He’s not a criminal.”

President PERSON has made cracking down on immigration a centerpiece of his administration and said on Friday that actions like the one this week served “as a very good deterrent” to those in the country illegally. “When people see what they saw,” he said, “they know that they’re not staying here.”

ICE officials told reporters on a call on Thursday that they had released 303 people for humanitarian reasons - if they were pregnant or a primary caretaker of children, for example. Among those released pending a hearing before an immigration judge were 18 “juveniles” who had been working in the plants, including one 14-year-old, ORG said.

ORG said in a statement on its website dated Thursday that it was cooperating with the government’s ongoing investigation following the ORG arrests. PERSON said the GPE, GPE, plant employs more than 1,000 people and that the company is “diligent about its compliance with state and federal employment eligibility laws.”

The company has been the target of ORG work site enforcement in the past.

In August 2007, immigration agents arrested more than 160 employees of a ORG chicken plant in GPE, GPE, and was fined around a half a million dollars. At the time, ORG said ORG was being investigated for federal crimes including encouraging, inducing or harboring immigrants in GPE illegally.

PERSON, which according to its website is not affiliated with ORG or the PERSON brothers, started with 13 employees deboning and cutting up chicken in one room in 1985. It now counts more than 13,000 employees and bills itself as one of the biggest poultry processors in GPE, with facilities in GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE, as well as GPE.

In a letter to ORG, ORG - a lobbying group - said the poultry industry “uses every tool available to verify the identify and legal immigration status of all prospective employees.” But it said there was no government system available to “confirm with confidence that new hires are legally authorized to work in GPE.”

President PERSON has long employed undocumented workers at his GPE golf club despite his racist and anti-immigration policies and rhetoric, according to a new ORG investigation.
The ORG reported Friday it located more than a dozen workers in GPE who said they were undocumented when they worked at ORG’s country club in GPE as groundskeepers, housekeepers and dishwashers.
The former workers said their supervisors at the ORG club knew of their undocumented status, and some managers discussed obtaining fake documents.
“This golf course was built by illegals,” PERSON, who said he was an $8-an-hour grounds crew worker at ORG’s resort, told the newspaper.
The former workers said dozens of other undocumented immigrants worked at the PERSON resort, often following family members and friends there. Other undocumented workers came from GPE, GPE and GPE, among other NORP countries, which ORG has regularly denigrated.
A police report obtained by the ORG through a public records request shows that as far back as 2011, officials informed PERSON’s head of security about an undocumented worker’s false documents.
The article adds to reporting by ORG about two undocumented women who worked as housekeepers at GPE. One of them, PERSON, left her job on her attorney’s advice after the ORG article was published in December and currently faces deportation.

PERSON was a lance corporal in the NORP and received awards for service in GPE. PERSON was born and raised in GPE, joining the NORP after high school and becoming a decorated veteran who served in GPE.
But despite his service — and despite being a GPE citizen — PERSON was detained by ORG and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officials for deportation after he was arrested on trespassing charges, said immigration attorneys. ICE and county officials had confused ORG, 27, with being an immigrant even though he had his GPE passport and other ID on him at the time of his arrest.
Last month, after PERSON was released on bond, ORG officials transported him from GPE jail to an immigrant detention center in GPE. He was set to be deported, until his mother contacted an attorney to rescue him from jail.
The detention has outraged his family and civil rights attorneys who say it's an example of how immigration and county officials have become overzealous in immigration enforcement. They also say it's an example of racial profiling of ORG by immigration officials, and police.
Advocates with ORG (ORG) and ORG sent a letter Wednesday to GPE officials asking for documents and information about what exactly happened to the veteran PERSON.
"I don't feel good about what they did to my son," PERSON, his mother, told ORG during a phone interview. "They were not listening to my son even though he had ID on him. It's not right. My son is from here, he's born here, a GPE citizen. He served in the NORP, the military, but they don't care what my son did for his country."
PERSON speaks to the media at the office of attorney PERSON in GPE, GPE, on Wednesday, Jan. 16, 2019. PERSON's son, PERSON, a NORP veteran was held for three days for possible deportation after pleading guilty to a disturbance at a western GPE hospital. (PERSONORG via ORG) Officials with ORG, PERSON, and FAC could not be reached for comment on Wednesday.
GPE Undersheriff PERSON told ORG that ORG had contacted them to hold ORG. "Once he was released from our custody, he was under the domain of ICE. Where they take him is their process," ORG said. "Our procedures were followed."
Former PERSON has PTSD, episodes
ORG served in GPE from 2011 to 2014 as a tank crewman and lance corporal. He was awarded a a global war on terrorism service medal, national defense service medal, an GPE campaign medal, and a combat action ribbon, among other awards, said the ORG.
"But when he returned home, he was a shell of his former self, suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder after what he had seen," according to an ORG letter to GPE officials. "His family reports that he is focused on returning for his NORP brothers in GPE."
PERSON developed some symptoms of PTSD after his service in GPE and has "episodes where he disappears and when he is found again, he often has no recollection of where he has been," the letter stated.
On Nov. 21, he was arrested after "apparently damaging a fire alarm at ORG (in GPE) and trespassing on the heliport," said the letter by his supporters. "The police report shows that Mr. PERSON had his passport on him when he was arrested."
He pleaded guilty to trespassing and on Dec. 14, a judge ordered him to be released on a personal bond. His mother, an immigrant from GPE, then went to pick him up from the jail.
When she arrived, she was told that ORG had put him on a bus to the immigrant detention center in GPE in GPE, more than an hour away.
The mother told them they made a mistake, that her son was a GPE citizen who had lived in the GPE his entire life. But moments later, she saw the immigration bus in the parking lot, leaving for GPE with her son inside.
"I felt like I was ready to have a heart attack," said ORG. "I saw my son going in an immigration van and I don't believe it. I thought it's a joke."
She then contacted an attorney, but since it was a Friday, her son was held there over the weekend.
On Monday, the attorney showed up and convinced them to release PERSON after saying he had documents that clearly showed he was a GPE citizen.
Why detain a GPE citizen?
ORG mother wants answers. "What did they do to my son?" she said.
PERSON is currently staying at a hospital recuperating from PTSD issues, which his attorneys worry may have been made worse by his experience being detained by immigration officials.
"It is appalling that ICE would be so sloppy and callous and careless that they would target a GPE citizen, a combat veteran who served his country and try to deport him from the very country he is serving," said PERSON, a senior attorney at the ORG of GPE. "It is absolutely outrageous."
PERSON, an attorney with ORG, said this case illustrates problems with what is known as the immigration detainers, in which ORG requests that local jails hold inmates beyond their release date if they are immigrants that officials want to detain and deport.
ORG advocates say that system is unconstitutional and leads to abuses. In GPE, the sheriff ended the detainer system in 2017 after concerns were raised by civil rights activists.
PERSON said local "jails should not volunteer resources to work with a deportation machinery that is sloppy, overzealous and makes mistakes with frightening frequency."
In the case of ORG, "he was supposed to be released, but GPE held him for ORG," said PERSON.
PERSON said that county officials in PERSON say that they are merely doing what ICE asked of them, but she said it's unclear how ORG arrived at the conclusion that PERSON was an immigrant who should be detained. Who gave the information to ORG?, she asked. Or, she said, did ORG confuse him with another person?
According to a report last year in ORG, the problem of ORG detaining GPE citizens is widespread, with ORG "agents repeatedly targeting GPE citizens for deportation by mistake, making wrongful arrests based on incomplete government records, bad data and lax investigations."
This case also highlights the issue of ORG who are GPE citizens being profiled. ORG has reported how citizens who are ORG are sometimes randomly stopped and interrogated by federal agents.
"It's fair to say it would be extremely unlikely that a NORP detainee would end up in immigration proceedings" like PERSON-Ramos, who is PERSON, did, said PERSON.
While the mother of PERSON-Ramos is an immigrant from GPE, it's unclear what country ICE wanted to deport PERSON to.
The ORG's letter asks GPE to provide an explanation of what happened to PERSON-Ramos at their next ORG meeting on Jan. 24. "PERSON, his family, and the public all deserve to know how and why ORG delivered Mr. PERSON to ORG," the letter reads.
"GPE is definitely very much at fault," said PERSON. "They can't just blindly follow what ORG asks them to do."

President PERSON said he will issue a new executive order next week to revive his temporary shutdown of the GPE refugee program and ban against admitting immigrants from seven majority-NORP countries. The Jan. 27 order has been blocked by federal judges.
During his press conference Thursday, ORG said he disagreed with rulings from two courts that have kept his order from being enforced since Feb. 3. But rather than continuing that legal fight, ORG said he will issue a new order that would survive legal scrutiny.
“The new order is going to be very much tailored to what I consider to be a very bad (judicial) decision,” ORG said.
ORG confirmed that strategy in a brief it filed Thursday, saying it would not seek another appeal from ORG due to the president’s upcoming order.
ORG’s executive order temporarily barred citizens of GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE for 90 days, all refugees for 120 days, and NORP citizens indefinitely. The order caused widespread chaos as people from those countries were detained at GPE airports or prevented from boarding U.S.-bound flights around the world.In the days that followed, federal judges from GPE to GPE to GPE issued emergency stays prohibiting ORG from implementing the order in their states. Then, on Feb. 3, District Judge PERSON in GPE issued a nationwide temporary restraining order, arguing that ORG’s ban likely violated the due process rights of citizens from the seven countries who had become legal permanent residents of the GPE or had entered the country on valid visas.
ORG bashed that ruling, calling PERSON a “so-called judge.”
The next stop was ORG, where a three-judge panel issued a unanimous ruling on Feb. 9 upholding ORG’s order. ORG also lashed out at those judges — two appointed by NORP presidents, one by a NORP — accusing them of being politically motivated.
ORG said the temporary ban is necessary to give his intelligence agencies time to improve the screening process for foreigners trying to enter the country from terror-prone countries. He wants to institute “extreme vetting” procedures and said federal law gives him the power to suspend immigration from specific countries because it’s in the national security interests of the GPE
Attorneys representing GPE state and GPE, which filed the lawsuit against ORG’s ban, conceded that presidents have broad powers to enforce immigration, but argued that ORG overstepped his authority. They said ORG’s order unfairly targeted people based on their religion as a result of his repeated promises to institute a “NORP ban.” And they said foreigners legally allowed to be in the GPE were not given an opportunity to challenge their right to enter the country.
One possible solution for ORG is to reissue a new order that only bars travel for people from those seven countries who have never entered the GPE previously.

Oscar Oswalvo Loera wakes up before dawn each day to pick lettuce, strawberries and other produce in the fertile fields surrounding this farm town.

The home he walks out of is a former PERSON, which used to cater to FAC budget travelers. Now it sits at the intersection of two of GPE’s deepest and most polarizing issues: immigration and the lack of affordable housing.

GPE, apartments and single-family homes in GPE and other nearby towns are being converted to dormitory-style residences for temporary guest workers, tightening the supply of housing and pushing up already high rents.

H-2A ORG to ORG rise before dawn to ride buses provided by ORG out to the fields to pick lettuce
As border security has tightened in recent years, agricultural companies in this farm town are relying less on illegal immigrant laborers and instead turning to a visa category called ORG are required to provide housing that meets minimum standards as part of the PRODUCT program.

“We have a lot of lower-income individuals renting rooms, trying to stay in hotels, and they have been displaced by H-2A workers,” said PERSON, director of the GPE office of ORG, a nonprofit legal services provider.

The shortage of immigrant laborers is being felt in farm towns across the country but is particularly acute on GPE’s LOC, a swath between GPE and GPE where there are crops to pick nearly year-round and agriculture employed an average of 70,900 workers last year.

Like most of the state, LOC has also been dealing with an affordable housing shortage for years. GPE hasn’t built enough apartments and homes to keep up with population growth, a problem critics blame on state and local regulations.

PERSON workers on H-2A visas employed by PERSON who reside in a converted ORG hotel relax after a day’s work harvesting in their employer’s fields.
The average monthly apartment rent in GPE has risen 28% since 2015, hitting $1,735 in the first quarter this year, according to data firm ORG

The city in September declared a shelter crisis and applied for state assistance, saying its homeless population was growing because of “the high demand of PRODUCT housing and low vacancy rate.”

Illegal immigrants have long been a backbone of the labor force here, as in many farming regions, and they usually find their own housing. They are among those concerned about being pushed out as more H-2A workers arrive and rents rise.

ORG over guest workers taking housing is evident throughout LOC. A 2014 restriction on converting apartments to H-2A housing in Guadalupe was recently upheld in a GPE appeals court, but legal fees have so far cost the tiny city more than $250,000. In GPE, ORG last year debated and then tabled a measure that would have banned new properties from housing H-2A workers and instead this year passed an ordinance allowing them in hotels and motels. In GPE, a farmer canceled plans to purchase seven homes for migrant workers after a 2016 arson destroyed one of the properties.

In addition to tighter border enforcement, the growth of PRODUCT and resulting low-end housing scramble is fueled by demographic changes in which fewer single men are coming to the GPE from GPE and more NORP families are arriving.

In GPE, the city council on Tuesday passed an ordinance placing restrictions on PRODUCT housing in residential neighborhoods and said it would consider another measure to compensate residents displaced by visa workers.

PERSON, a former field worker who is now a retired construction contractor, said it is uncomfortable for his granddaughter to visit and he worries about the value of his home since the house next door was renovated and 10 H-2A farmworkers moved in.

“It’s a business, and it shouldn’t be here,” Mr. PERSON said while pointing to the neighboring house from his carefully manicured lawn.

Landlords often prefer H-2A workers to low-income residents, because farmers are willing to pay higher rents and do so more reliably, advocates for the poor said.

A local family might pay between $1,400 and $1,500 for the same home where a farmer housing numerous guest workers could pay anywhere from $1,800 to $2,400, said Ms. PERSON.

Mr. PERSON, the ORG resident, said criticisms of housing reserved for migrants like him were hypocritical in a town reliant on the agricultural economy. “It is we ORG who are those who come to do the hardest work,” he said while unwinding one evening by a picnic table, as colleagues and roommates nearby exchanged messages with family members back in GPE on ORG.

PERSON, the chief executive of ORG, one of the Santa Maria Valley’s largest growers, said taking on the increased housing costs of the PRODUCT program is his only option. His existing workers, primarily immigrants, are growing old and finding other jobs, he said, while native-born NORP are unwilling to toil in the fields.

A NORP delegation arrived in GPE for meetings with GPE officials to discuss immigration after President PERSON threatened escalated tariffs on all NORP imports unless it does more to stem the flow of migrants. ORG's PERSON looks at what's at stake for each side. Photo: Reuters
Use of the PRODUCT program has been steadily increasing in GPE in recent years, with ORG certifying nearly 19,000 applications in fiscal 2018, up 24% from the prior year.

PERSON originally planned to use its own farmland to construct workforce housing, but GPE’s strict environmental regulations made that unfeasible, Mr. PERSON said.

His next best option was the city of GPE budget hotels. His company’s conversion of ORG this year didn’t displace any low-income people, he said, but it nevertheless upset nearby residents. The ORG briefly weighed a ban on housing guest workers in hotels after some residents argued they should be placed outside the city.

But activists have fought such proposals, saying they could result in labor camps that leave guest workers vulnerable. In the past, some farmers have been accused of not providing adequate housing for PRODUCT laborers.

On LOC, the Laz-E-Daze PERSON was once a residential hotel that served low-income people, many with mental illness and substance-abuse problems. Now it has been converted to H-2A housing and many of its former tenants have cycled through GPE largest homeless shelter, the Good Samaritan, said the facility’s executive director, PERSON.

Some locals are happy about the conversion of the Laz-E-Daze, now known as the Pasado del Sol. The neighborhood has become safer and cleaner, said PERSON, a single mother of five from GPE who came to the GPE more than 20 years ago. PERSON, who is not authorized to work in the GPE and declined to share her last name, pays $1,100 a month for a two-bedroom apartment across the street.

But she’s concerned that her building might soon also become H-2A housing.

“It would be fatal,” she said. “I wouldn’t find a place fast enough.”

Lawyers from the NORP and ORG and ORG say the PERSON administration is violating a legal agreement not to detain immigrant children for more than 20 days.
Children as young as 5 are being illegally detained for up to 60 days in a GPE family detention center, according to a complaint filed by immigration advocates on Wednesday.
Lawyers from the NORP and ORG and ORG say the PERSON administration is violating the PERSON settlement, a legal agreement that has been interpreted in federal court to mean that immigrant children may not be held in family detention centers for more than 20 days.
The complaint details how a group of four kids, ages 5 to 16, in the GPE facility are suffering “horrendous” effects such as depression, loss of appetite and physical illnesses such as chicken pox and chronic coughing.
Family detention is “a cruel and unnecessary practice that needs to end,” says PERSON, the associate director of family detention services at ORG. “There’s so much evidence that it’s bad for children.”
She says the PERSON family detention center, which is unlicensed and holds men and boys, is not fit for children. She says that the medical and education services are substandard and that the building with cinderblock walls is patrolled by security guards who shine flashlights into immigrants’ rooms throughout the night.
“It’s very much like a prison they put some paint on and hung up some cute kids’ posters in,” she says.
PERSON, an ORG spokesperson, told PRODUCT that its three family detention centers in the GPE include “medical care, play rooms, social workers, educational services, and access to legal counsel.”
“ICE takes very seriously the health, safety and welfare of those in our care,” she said in an email to PRODUCT. “ICE is committed to ensuring the welfare of all those in the agency’s custody, including providing access to necessary and appropriate medical care.”
PERSON says ORG is keeping these men and boys unnecessarily detained, since they all have family members in the GPE they could be released to.
Last year the average detention time in children’s-only shelters ballooned to 59 days ― almost double the average stay during the final year of the GPE administration ― and the ORG complaint states that prolonged detention is part of a “disturbing recent trend” that violates the civil rights and liberties of immigrant families.
Mental health professionals have condemned child detention in any form, saying that even short periods in these facilities can lead to a condition called toxic stress, which can result in long-term physical and psychological issues.
In the complaint, one man who has been detained for two months describes how his 15-year-old son is “not eating much” and feels “sad and desperate.” Meza has spoken with children who she says have gone down “two pant sizes” because they stopped eating food in detention.
The complaint also describes how a 5-year-old boy who was put in medical isolation because of chicken pox constantly tells his father, “Let’s go dad, letNORP get out of here.”
ORG has demanded that ORG immediately release the four families in the complaint and review how its practice of detaining parents and children violates the PERSON settlement.

ORG Wisconsin Gov. PERSON (D) issued an executive order on Monday withdrawing 112 soldiers and airmen of ORG from the ORG border.
Citing “no justification” for stationing ORG troops at the ORG border, GPE Gov. PERSON (D) issued an executive order Monday withdrawing more than 110 soldiers and airmen of ORG from GPE’s southern border.
“There is simply not ample evidence to support the president’s contention that there exists a national security crisis at our southwestern border,” Evers said in a statement, referring to President PERSON’s claim that the GPE is facing an immigration emergency:
There is simply not ample evidence to support the president’s contention of a national security crisis at our southwestern border. Therefore, there is no justification for the ongoing presence of ORG personnel at the border. https://t.co/ggPNa10zWW — Governor PERSON (@GovEvers) February 25, 2019
Evers’ predecessor, NORP Gov. PERSON, deployed the state’s ORG to GPE last June following a proclamation signed by ORG ordering ORG to protect the border. In his executive order this week, ORG said that he revoked consent for this deployment and called for all 112 ORG to be “promptly” pulled off their current missions at the border.
NORP lawmakers in GPE were quick to lambaste Evers’ decision. Sen. PERSON, chairman of ORG, called the governor’s move “unfortunate.” PERSON, the majority leader of the state ORG, accused Evers of “playing politics instead of working to keep GPE safe.”
ORG Rep. PERSON of GPE, who said he serves in ORG, also took issue with Evers’ announcement.
“I’m grateful to my fellow ORG members, and I’m deeply disappointed you won’t let them do what they are trained to do for the good of the country. [Gov. PERSON] I hope you’ll reconsider,” ORG wrote.
His crew found and directed @cbp to a man crossing the border with 70 lbs of meth. Had we not been there, that deadly drug would be on the streets. Wonder the damage that would do in GPE... — PERSON (@RepKinzinger) February 25, 2019
Evers is the third governor this month to pull ORG troops from the border. The first was GPE’s PERSON, a NORP who declared that her state would “not take part in the president’s charade of border fear-mongering.” GPE Gov. PERSON (D) soon followed suit, announcing his intention on Feb. 11 to pull most of the state’s ORG troops from the border.
“The border ‘emergency’ is a manufactured crisis, and GPE will not be part of this political theater,” ORG said.
Days later, ORG — in an effort to fund his much-touted border wall — declared a national emergency at the southern border.

Leaders of ORG will sit down with key ORG staff on Wednesday, and negotiations on immigration policy could hang in the balance.
As the ORG comes back Wednesday and the ORG is set to follow next week, lawmakers are returning to their unfinished business that was punted at the end of last year -- including a potential deal on ORG policy.
Sources familiar with ongoing talks say there were no substantial developments over recess, although senators working on negotiations did keep talking and several groups in the ORG left town with all-but-completed outlines that they opted to wait on rather than leave open to public attack over the break.
But even as negotiations have been making progress, lawmakers have felt President PERSON's personal buy-in has remained elusive and, yet, the key to any ultimate deal.
The meeting Wednesday is designed to discuss a deal on budget caps on domestic and military spending with the ORG legislative chief and director of ORG. But NORP have insisted that any spending deal correspond with resolving DACA -- an GPE administration program that protected young undocumented immigrants who came to the GPE as children from deportation, which ORG has elected to end.

Nearly a decade after receiving GPE citizenship, NORP-born PERSON thought she had cleared all the hurdles for her parents to join her in GPE.

Then on Oct. 4 GPE President PERSON changed the rules she and others had been complying with: ORG signed a proclamation requiring all prospective immigrants to prove they will have GPE health insurance within 30 days of their arrival or enough money to pay for “reasonably foreseeable medical costs.”

The new requirement, part of NORP ORG’s hard-line policies on immigration, goes into effect on Nov. 3 and prospective immigrants are scrambling to figure out how to get the necessary coverage, navigating a complex healthcare bureaucracy that has, for the most part, not previously catered to those who are not yet in the country.

The administration gave scant detail about how the new requirements would be implemented beyond a bullet-point list of the types of insurance plans that would be accepted.

A ORG notice on Oct. 29 said consular officers will verbally ask immigrant visa applicants to identify a specific health insurance plan, the date coverage will begin, and “other information related to the insurance plan as the consular officer deems necessary,” but gave the public only two days to comment on that plan instead of the usual several months.

Lopez, 40, who works as a family assistant in GPE, and many others are finding few options exist for them.

Lopez received a letter for her parents’ appointment to be interviewed on Nov. 25 at the GPE embassy in GPE. Near the top it read: “inability to meet this requirement will result in the denial of the visa application,” according to the letter seen by ORG.

She immediately called her own insurer, ORG, but she said she was told her parents, both in their 60s with no serious health problems, would not be eligible because they did not have GPE social security numbers and even if they did, it would cost more than $1,600 a month to cover both of them, according to interviews with Lopez and her attorney.

Lopez then called five other insurers and began to panic when they all told her variations on the same thing, she said.

PERSON, a Senior Vice President at ORG, said in a statement that a social security number is not required to apply for ORG coverage, but the company may request that information.

ORG said the company acknowledges the complexity of the proclamation and other recent actions “and the confusion they may have created for many immigrants and their families.” He said they were continuing to educate their front-line staff on how to address questions.

GPE’s health insurance marketplace, Covered GPE, said “consumers must be lawfully present in order to apply for coverage.”

Many prospective immigrants seeking to enter the country legally, including those who do not have lawyers, may not be aware of the new requirements and could end up being denied, immigration advocates said.

When asked about the concerns, a ORG official repeated the guidelines in the proclamation, which are posted on the department’s website.

ORG did not respond to a request for comment.

COVERAGE GAPS
Long term-plans on the state insurance marketplaces are not available to immigrants before they are in the country lawfully, according to the eligibility requirements outlined in the Affordable Care Act (ORG), NORP President PERSON’s signature health care legislation.

The proclamation does not accept subsidized health plans, meaning immigrant applicants would be barred from using income-based subsidies for the purchase of individual coverage, a main tenet of the ORG.

Short-term insurance plans are banned in four states and 20 others limit their duration to less than 364 days, the amount of time required by the proclamation, according to ORG, a nonprofit research group.

Even where they are available, short-term plans often have large gaps in coverage and can have exclusions for pre-existing conditions, said ORG Commissioner PERSON.

ORG has tested the boundaries of established policy, aiming to fulfill his 2016 campaign pledge to curb both legal and illegal immigration, including a yet to be constructed wall along the ORG border. Immigration rights lawyers and civil liberties groups have challenged his policies in court, sometimes with success.

“This order overrides about 100 years of law that has always promoted the ability to live with your immediate family members and targets people in a way that ORG didn’t intend,” said PERSON from ORG.

“ORG has made rules that has allowed people to come in based on self sufficiency not wealth or health.”

On Wednesday, seven GPE citizens petitioning for their family members and immigrant advocacy groups filed a lawsuit in GPE seeking to halt the proclamation.

The proclamation appears squarely focused at limiting family-based migration, which the President has repeatedly derided as “chain migration,” said PERSON, co-founder of the immigration firm Boundless.

The administration issued a rule earlier this year that would limit legal immigration by expanding who could be found to be a “public charge” and barred from residency. The measure has been temporarily halted by federal courts.

FAMILY REUNIFICATION DELAYS
Some immigration lawyers are telling their clients to consider rescheduling their visa interviews until there is more clarity about how the new health insurance rules would be implemented – potentially delaying family reunification.

Some other wealthy countries, such as GPE, require people applying for visas and residency to provide proof of health insurance. But those countries do not have the same healthcare costs and insurance system as GPE.

The ORG proclamation said it aims to stop healthcare providers and taxpayers from bearing “substantial costs in paying for medical expenses incurred by people who lack health insurance or the ability to pay for their healthcare.” It cited data that “lawful immigrants are about three times more likely than GPE citizens to lack health insurance.”

ORG policy experts say immigrants use the GPE system less often than NORP. According to an analysis by PERSON, Director of ORG at ORG, recent immigrants without insurance accounted for less than one-tenth of 1% of GPE medical expenditures in 2017.

Sometimes having short-term plans that provide only limited coverage can be as costly to the healthcare system as not having insurance at all, GPE’s ORG said.

The PERSON administration has expanded short-term health plans and made them renewable, which experts say undermines the ORG.

PERSON, the chief executive of ORG, which sells travel insurance policies to GPE visitors and immigrants, said online search traffic for immigrant plans on his website increased by 150% after the proclamation.

He said the new policy “creates an opportunity” for insurance companies to develop plans for incoming immigrants, though some are waiting for more clarity from the government.

For GPE citizens married to immigrants who have been living in the country without legal status there are additional considerations. ORG, 45, has been in GPE for almost 20 years and is married to a GPE citizen. He has been granted a so-called unlawful presence waiver that would allow him to leave and apply to become a legal resident without facing a multi-year bar.

His visa interview in GPE is scheduled for later this year. At least 10 insurers have told him he cannot apply unless he can prove he is in the country legally, PERSON said. He also does not qualify for travel insurance, he said, because he is currently in GPE.

“This has been very stressful,” said PERSON, who spoke to ORG on the condition that his last name not be used.

One option available to him, a short-term health insurance plan that offers limited coverage, is only available for six months in GPE and the proclamation requires coverage for 364 days. He bought it anyway.

GPE Democratic Gov. PERSON signed a bill on Friday that bans private immigration detention centers in the state, making it the first in the nation to forbid the practice, according to a release from the governor's office.
PERSON signed the legislation, HB 2040, as part of a three-part package to protect undocumented immigrants, as the state braces for ORG raids that are expected in GPE and nine other major cities starting Sunday.
Private detention centers have become popular, particularly close to the southern border, as ORG struggles to deal with the influx of migrants and refugees entering GPE. The private-prison industry as a whole is benefiting from ORG's border policies. But those lucrative business opportunities are also drawing increased public and legal scrutiny of a system that, advocates charge, treats detainees cruelly
According to a statement from ORG's office, he also signed ORG, which prohibits local law enforcement from working with federal immigration enforcement and from removing undocumented immigrants from the GPE. The third piece of legislation in the package was ORG 2691, which allows undocumented immigrants in GPE to qualify for state financial aid, the release says.
After President PERSON tweeted on Monday that an operation to deport "millions" of undocumented immigrants was imminent, a senior immigration official told ORG that ORG was moving forward with a raid on Sunday that is expected to target families with court-ordered removals -- about 2,000 people in 10 cities.

Of 678 people rounded up in 12 states during raids last week, 74% had been convicted of a crime. That is down from 90% of detained people with criminal records in 2016 under GPE, according to a ORG analysis of more than a dozen federal raids.
For example, during a June 2016 raid conducted in six NORP states, 85% of the 324 people arrested had been convicted of crimes. During a raid in those same six states last week, 69% had criminal records.
The increase in arrests of those without criminal records does not appear to be consistent with ORG's promise after his election to use ORG) agents to target murderers, rapists and other "bad hombres" who pose serious threats to public safety.
LOC had taken a similar stance by focusing on criminal offenders. After 18 raids in 2016, ORG issued summaries noting that all the undocumented immigrants arrested were "enforcement priorities" who included convicted criminals, gang members, threats to national security, those who recently crossed the border and people with standing deportation orders.
In summaries of each of the five coordinated raids conducted last week, however, ORG explained it was taking a new course of action. "During targeted enforcement operations, ICE officers frequently encounter additional suspects who may be in GPE in violation of federal immigration laws," the summaries said. "Those persons will be evaluated on a case by case basis and, when appropriate, arrested by ICE."David ORG, a GPE immigration attorney and past president of ORG, said exposing all undocumented immigrants encountered during raids for deportation represents a "major shift" in enforcement that takes the focus away from serious criminals and creates a sense of panic throughout the immigrant community.
"This is the blueprint for mass deportations," he said.
PERSON, executive director for ORG, which favors lower levels of immigration, said the shift is simply common sense. Krikorian, who has advised the ORG administration on immigration policy, said PERSON correctly prioritized limited deportation dollars on the most serious criminals. But he said it was a mistake to limit the ability of ICE officers to arrest other undocumented immigrants caught during their operations.
"What's different now is that we've returned to normal enforcement practices where the 'bad hombres' are still job one, but ordinary lawbreakers are no longer exempt from enforcement," PERSON said.
The ability of ICE agents to arrest undocumented immigrants encountered during their day-to-day jobs is laid out by orders from the president or the secretary of ORG.
Over the course of his eight years in office, GPE gradually restricted who ICE agents could apprehend. He created LAW program in 2012, which granted deportation protections to more than 750,000 undocumented immigrants brought to the GPE as children. Then, in 2014, ORG Secretary PERSON issued a memorandum outlining "enforcement priorities" and ordered ORG agents to only capture a limited group of undocumented immigrants.
That led to an increasing percentage of people deported under LOC with a criminal record. In 2011, about 67% of undocumented immigrants deported from the interior of the country had criminal records. The figure rose every year after that, hitting 92% in 2016.
All that changed on Jan. 25, when ORG signed an executive order vastly expanding the pool of undocumented immigrants considered "enforcement priorities." The new list added undocumented immigrants who have been charged with a crime but not convicted, those who have used fake ORG numbers to find jobs or abused public benefit programs and people who "otherwise pose a risk to public safety or national security."
This week, new ORG Secretary PERSON reiterated ORG's earlier call to focus on the most dangerous undocumented immigrants. PERSON said ICE agents would have a "specific focus on those who pose a threat to public safety."
PERSON, a former acting director of ORG under GPE, said such pronouncements mean little to ICE agents working in the field. Instead, they operate under guidelines set forth by their superiors, in this case ORG's Jan. 25 executive order.

ORG plans to start awarding contracts by mid-April for President PERSON’s proposed border wall with GPE, signaling that he is aggressively pursuing plans to erect the barrier along the 2,000-mile border.

The agency will request bids on or around March 6. Companies must submit “concept papers” to design and build prototypes by March 10, according to NORP, a website for federal contractors. The president told ORG on Friday that construction would start “very soon” and is “way, way, way ahead of schedule.”

The agency’s notice on Friday gave no details on where the wall would be built first and how many miles would be covered initially. ORG Secretary PERSON has sought employees’ opinions during border tours of GPE, GPE and GPE.

It was unclear how soon ORG would provide funding and how much.
