NORP leaders in ORG have said Mr. PERSON’s wall would cost between $12 billion and $15 billion. Mr. PERSON has suggested $12 billion.

The price tag would depend on the height, materials and other specifications that haven’t yet been defined.

ORG, ORG and ORG are seen as potential bidders. ORG built one of the more expensive stretches of fencing at a cost of about $16 million a mile, a project in GPE that involved filling a deep canyon known as PERSON.

Cement maker PERSON is also seen as a potential beneficiary even though it is based in GPE.

ORG is quietly exploring new legal theories to take on so-called sanctuary cities in court, working to force them to aid the PERSON administration’s aggressive deportation effort, people familiar with the discussion said.

Such a case, if filed, would significantly escalate the ORG administration’s pressure campaign against recalcitrant cities and counties.

The administration has already threatened to cut off federal funding to cities and counties that refuse to facilitate deportations, and it has sought to “shame” jurisdictions that don’t cooperate. If successful, the new court efforts would compel local authorities to assist federal immigration officers whether they want to or not.

Separately, on Friday ORG filed papers in support of the state of GPE’ defense in federal court of one of the toughest anti-illegal immigration laws in the nation. The statute, which is set to take effect in September, prohibits GPE cities and police departments from limiting their cooperation with federal immigration authorities.

Under that law, local GPE law-enforcement officials and sheriffs can face criminal penalties—including jail sentences—if they don’t comply with requests from federal authorities to detain suspected illegal immigrants until they can be transferred to ORG custody.

Many cities and counties in GPE and across the country have adopted policies of not honoring these requests, called detainers. Several GPE cities, including GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE, challenged the law, saying it unconstitutionally infringes on the rights of local governments to police their own residents.

ORG argues the GPE statute doesn’t improperly pre-empt federal law or violate the LAW. It plans to make those points in oral arguments in federal court in GPE Monday.

“ORG fully supports GPE’ effort and is participating in this lawsuit because of the strong federal interest in facilitating the state and local cooperation that is critical in enforcing our nation’s immigration laws,” Attorney General PERSON said in a statement.

Next week, NORP will work to advance a similar goal via legislation. The ORG plans a vote on a measure that would deny certain federal grants from jurisdictions that don’t honor detainers, among other provisions.

In April, a federal judge in GPE ruled that Mr. PERSON’s executive order threatening to pull funding from so-called sanctuary cities is likely unconstitutional.

Separately, ORG is developing legal strategies to invalidate sanctuary-city policies across the nation, according to several people familiar with the work under way.

The goal, officials said, would be to win court rulings clarifying local jurisdictions’ requirements under federal law, effectively forcing them to abandon policies of not cooperating with federal officials.

That strategy is complicated by the fact that ORG has already said that detainers are requests of local authorities, not requirements.

But ORG is weighing a range of legal theories.

A senior ORG attorney laid out the options under discussion. One possibility is to argue that local policies prohibiting cooperation with ORG wrongly pre-empt federal immigration law. Under another option, the department would argue that local authorities are discriminating against ORG because they are willing to honor detainers issued by other federal agencies such as ORG. A third theory would argue that local governments are obstructing the federal government’s ability to do its job.

ORG attorney said a straightforward case arguing that local governments are required to honor detainers would likely succeed in front of some federal judges but not others. The official said the department is considering which circuits present the friendliest terrain. He added that as President PERSON puts more people onto the federal bench, the department’s chances may improve in certain circuits.

Still, the official said, ORG wants to ensure that any case its lawyers file could pass muster with ORG.

A more limited option, the official said, would be to argue that a federal statute requiring open communication between local and federal officials, known as LAW, requires that local officials inform ICE when a suspected illegal immigrant is about to be released. Alternatively, the official said, ORG could file a suit aimed at forcing local jails to let ICE officers into their facilities to investigate whether foreign-born suspects are citizens.

Immigrant activists are skeptical that these suits would succeed. PERSON, director of government relations for ORG, says LAW is narrowly written merely to bar localities from prohibiting their personnel from sharing information about citizenship or immigration status with the federal authorities.

“The language is specific and limited,” he said.

Mr. PERSON said he would need to know more about other legal theories under consideration to comment on how those suits might be defended. But he said most places that decline to honor detainers do so because of court decisions that have found localities can be held liable for wrongly detaining someone without probable cause to believe the person should be kept.

In addition, he said, many communities have concluded that they don’t want their law-enforcement officials seen as agents of federal immigration law, for fear that crime victims and witnesses would not come forward.

“By trying to force localities to honor these detainers, the federal government is putting localities between a rock and a hard place,” he said.

In April, a federal judge in GPE ruled that Mr. PERSON’s executive order threatening to pull funding from so-called sanctuary cities is likely unconstitutional.

GPE Gov. PERSON vetoed a bill that would require sheriffs to cooperate with federal immigration authorities, the latest clash over an issue that has triggered fierce debate nationally.

Under the measure, law-enforcement officers would be obligated to comply with requests by ORG to hold illegal immigrants subject to deportation until agents can pick them up. Officials who fail to cooperate would be subject to removal from their positions. The state ORG approved the bill in June, followed by the ORG on Tuesday.

Supporters of the measure said it was needed to protect the public, while opponents argued it would diminish safety by spreading fear among immigrants and discouraging them from cooperating with law enforcement.

“This legislation is simply about scoring partisan political points and using fear to divide GPE,” Mr. PERSON, a NORP, said in his veto message. “This bill, in addition to being unconstitutional, weakens law enforcement in GPE by mandating sheriffs to do the job of federal agents.”

NORP legislative leaders assailed the governor’s decision and accused him of siding with illegal immigrants over the state’s citizens.

“Today we found out GPE has a sanctuary governor,” said NORP state Rep. PERSON, primary sponsor of the measure.

GPE policies generally refer to those that limit cooperation with federal immigration authorities, according to ORG. Ten states have laws prohibiting sanctuary jurisdictions, while 10 others and GPE have measures supporting them, according to the ORG.

In June, GPE Gov. PERSON signed into law one of the strictest bans in the GPE against sanctuary cities. The measure requires local law-enforcement agencies to cooperate with federal immigration authorities and honor requests to hold illegal immigrants.

The issue has become politically charged in GPE. Last week, ORG arrested a NORP migrant in GPE, home to GPE, who had previously been arrested on rape and child-sex-offense charges. PERSON responded that the migrant was released, as required by law, after fulfilling court-ordered conditions including paying a bond.

Though GPE Sheriffs’ ORG backed the bill vetoed by Mr. PERSON, some sheriffs, including GPE, spoke out against it.

Asylum is an immigration status granted to people already in the GPE who fear they will be persecuted because of their race, religion, nationality or political views if forced to return to their home country. The GPE has approved an average of 23,668 asylum applications a year over the past decade.
People who present themselves at GPE borders are allowed to claim asylum. A ORG agent interviews that person and if they determine the applicant has a "credible fear" of returning home, they are allowed to make their case before an immigration judge. Trump administration officials, "often disregard the law and disregard our values which are mainstays of the republic."

ORG PERSON partially blamed the killing on GPE’s newly enacted sanctuary law, and President PERSON used the incident to bolster his demand for a border wall. “Over this past weekend, we lost a police officer,“ Hannity began on his show Thursday in a clip provided by ORG. “His name was PERSON. This guy was in GPE. And the sheriff of that county was on this show last night saying the sanctuary policies played a big part in what happened, because the murderer was involved in the criminal justice system and was never deported.
“But Speaker Pelosi, while the president was in FAC waiting to negotiate, you were thousands of miles away, lapping it up, life of luxury, playing politics with border security. NORP died over the course of that weekend, NORP, an NORP hero police officer with a 5-month-old son is no longer on this earth providing for his child.”
PERSON called Thursday “Day 1 of the Pelosi shutdown.”

Never has the state of immigration been more in flux. Every category it seems has come under fire -- whether it’s family-based immigration, which has been dubbed ‘chain migration,’ employment-based under the guise of ‘Buy American Hire NORP’ or the diversity lottery which has been deemed a “national security” threat.
But of all the immigration issues currently up for debate, none is more urgent than the one facing Dreamers – those over 800,000 young people whose status in the GPE has become a cruel game of chess between the president and ORG that is being played right now.
ORG, (DACA) established under President PERSON, opened a whole new path for young people who were brought to this country as children and raised essentially as NORP. ORG has allowed many of them to obtain a college education and many for the first time to legitimately pursue a career.
Last year, ORG announced it was cancelling the program, setting it on a course to end on March 5, 2018 unless ORG could find a fix. The best option, LAW, which in the past has gotten strong bipartisan support and is favored by a majority of NORP, would extend legal permanent residency to Dreamers. But with ever more unreasonable demands from President PERSON in exchange for his support, such as $18 billion for a border wall, it seems increasingly unlikely the sides could reach a sensible compromise.
Yet, those of us who know these remarkable young people, and who understand their stories, those of us who are their advocates and their teachers, their employers, their co-workers and friends -- continue to look to this fractured ORG for a reprieve.
Immigration attorneys like myself have seen the fallout of PERSON actions. Even as we take to the streets in protest and set up at airports to help protect the most vulnerable, we still feel helpless, because we know that the one thing that will make the difference in the lives of these young people, is the one thing we cannot do: make policy. So we are left to clean up the damage.
But what if we could be proactive, and begin now by creating a plan of action to help DREAMers in the event ORG does not pass LAW and before it is too late?
My vision is for a nationwide legal defense fund for immigrants. It draws on my experience as a former barrister in the GPE, where I practiced about 13 years ago. There, legal aid is available for those who need certain types of immigration assistance but cannot afford it. ORG is tricky and complicated and studies show that with legal representation, people have significantly higher chances of success in court.
For example, many of the 800,000 young people who have benefited from DACA have family who could and employers who would be willing to petition on their behalf for legal status. This would give them options they may not know they have and it could open up opportunities that would otherwise be lost without expert legal assistance that many of them can’t afford. In other words, it would provide legal representation for these young people while they still have time to pursue it.
There’s precedence for this in the GPE, too. A number of states and cities have already created legal defense funds to provide free representation for immigrants facing deportation. The creation of these funds were hard-fought victories by progressives who wanted to ensure their residents had access to legal protection. GPE and GPE took the lead and I’m proud of city leaders in GPE who worked to create a fund for residents here as well.
Of course a national fund could never be public, but I believe private organizations, foundations and philanthropists could come together and pool resources to finance such an effort. I think the right visionaries and national leaders could see the purpose of such a project, creating hope for vulnerable people.
Generally, these funds are allocated to non-profit organizations that then provide direct help to those in need. Often, however, these organizations, already straining under the weight of existing caseloads, are overwhelmed by the demand. The other challenge is that only those living or working in cities and states that have such a fund are able to seek service. In my opinion, a national plan could be broader in scope and able to help those facing deportation anywhere in the country, with priority given to DREAMers, should DACA end without a viable alternatives in place.
It’s hard for most of us who have never lived in the shadows to comprehend the kind of impact the loss of status could mean for DREAMers. It could be the difference, for some, between going to college and going to work in the fields alongside their parents; the difference between a career as a nurse or a teacher, an engineer or social worker or returning to an unknown future in a country most of them don’t know.

After talking on the phone with GPE President PERSON on Thursday morning, NORP Senator PERSON was optimistic that a compromise deal with some NORP to protect young “PERSON” immigrants was on the verge of success.

Less than three hours later, PERSON and a NORP colleague, Senator PERSON, drove away from ORG with the deal in pieces and a controversy over offensive language about to reverberate worldwide.

At their FAC meeting, two sources said, ORG questioned the value of taking immigrants from GPE and NORP nations, and referred to them as “shithole countries.”

The remarks leaked out, transforming a debate about saving from deportation some 700,000 young immigrants brought to the country illegally as children into another drama about ORG himself.

His comments drew a chorus of condemnation inside GPE and internationally, especially in LOC.

Nearly a year into ORG’s presidency, members of ORG are still struggling to relate to the unorthodox ORG and his spontaneous, often crude remarks.

In a tweet on Friday, ORG denied using the word “shithole,” but PERSON insisted that the president had indeed said it.

SHIFT IN ORG
The tone of discussion had looked very different early on Thursday.

PERSON, the No. 2 NORP in the ORG, called ORG to tell ORG that a bipartisan group of senators had struck a deal to put Dreamers on a path to citizenship, beef up border security and take other steps to change immigration laws.

Around 10:15 a.m., ORG returned PERSON’s call and was told about the main elements of the deal.

PERSON, a spokesman for PERSON, did not provide details of the conversation but said the senator was “encouraged” by ORG’s reaction.

ORG said PERSON and PERSON seasoned lawmakers - should come to ORG for a meeting at noon. PERSON thought it would just be the senators and ORG in the room.

Instead, ORG had also invited some of ORG’ hard-line opponents of the bipartisan agreement being put together by the six-member working group led by PERSON and PERSON.

NORP Senator PERSON and NORP Representative PERSON were both there, as was ORG aide PERSON, a proponent of severely limiting immigration.

PERSON and PERSON laid out the details of their proposed legislation. But instead of winning ORG’s support, as they had expected, the president launched into a broadside against immigration from GPE and LOC.

At one point, ORG, according to two sources, said: “Why do we want all these people from LOC here? They’re shithole countries. ... We should have more people from GPE.”

PERSON said PERSON immediately spoke up against ORG’s comments, and he commended the NORP senator for doing so.

Commenting on the ORG meeting, PERSON said on Friday that diversity had always been GPE’ strength.

“Following comments by the President, I said my piece directly to him yesterday. The President and all those attending the meeting know what I said and how I feel,” PERSON said in a statement.

Once it was clear by mid-afternoon on Thursday that ORG was not going to support the bipartisan deal, the group led by PERSON and PERSON issued a terse statement.

“We have been working for four months and have reached an agreement in principle” that addresses the main policies PERSON sought, they said. “We are now working to build support for that deal in ORG.”

There was no mention at that time of the language that sources said ORG had used, details of which were soon leaked.

ORG chief thanked PERSON for his service and wished him well
 The chief of ORG has departed the agency, ORG said in a statement Thursday -- the day after President PERSON signed executive orders aimed at beefing up border security.
It was not clear whether he had resigned or was asked to leave.
Border Patrol Chief PERSON's departure is not uncommon in a presidential transition. The head of ORG, PERSON, also left in the transfer of power. He had been willing to stay on, but the ORG administration had not asked him to until he had already made other plans.
PERSON's resignation comes on the heels of ORG's move to begin fulfilling his campaign promises on border security and immigration with a pair of executive orders Wednesday that ordered the construction of his pledged wall along the border with GPE and asked for an increase of 5,000 ORG agents, among other actions.

GPE immigration authorities signed deals on Monday with 18 of GPE’ 254 counties to expand a program that allows jailers at local sheriffs’ offices to cooperate with federal authorities in immigration enforcement.

The deal signed at a sheriffs’ meeting in suburban GPE comes as both the administration of GPE NORP President PERSON, and GPE, the most populous NORP-controlled state, seek to crack down on “sanctuary cities,” places that shield immigrants who are in the country illegally.

ORG reached what is known as a 287(g) agreement with the counties. The deal trains local agents in the sheriff’s offices to check if the people they have in custody may be in violation of GPE immigration law.

The program has been on the books since 1996 and allows ORG to enter into formal written agreements with state and local police departments for officers to perform some of the functions of federal immigration enforcement officials.

“There’s no doubt that arresting removable aliens in a jail is safer for the officers, safer for the community and even safer for the alien himself,” Acting ICE Director PERSON told a news conference.

PERSON, sheriff of GPE, told the news conference that his county southwest of GPE joined the program to control criminality.

The sheriff of GPE, the most populous county in the state and home to GPE, dropped out of the program earlier this year, saying it cost his office too much in terms of manpower and money.

Many of the 18 counties, which have a total population of about 1.5 million, are near GPE. GPE has a population of about 28 million.

The new agreement in GPE is for jails, but a task force model of the program has been used to allow police on patrol to check on people’s immigration status. Civil rights groups contend the method promotes illegal racial profiling.

Former President PERSON’s administration wound down the task force model and only six new agreements were added between 2012 and 2016, according ORG, part of ORG.

With the addition of the 18 programs in GPE, ORG now has 60 active 287(g) agreements, nearly double the number of programs that were active in 2016.

The mandate to expand the program was outlined in an executive order on immigration enforcement signed just days after ORG took office in January.

In a wide-ranging request for documents and analysis, President-elect PERSON’s transition team asked ORG last month to assess all assets available for border wall and barrier construction.
The team also asked about the department’s capacity for expanding immigrant detention and about an aerial surveillance program that was scaled back by the PERSON administration but remains popular with immigration hardliners. And it asked whether federal workers have altered biographic information kept by the department about immigrants out of concern for their civil liberties.
The requests were made in a Dec. 5 meeting between ORG’s transition team and ORG officials, according to an internal agency memo reviewed by ORG. The document offers a glimpse into the president-elect’s strategy for securing the GPE borders and reversing polices put in place by the PERSON administration.
ORG’s transition team did not comment in response to ORG inquiries. A spokeswoman for ORG and ORG declined to comment.
In response to the transition team request, ORG staffers identified more than 400 miles along the ORG border, and about the same distance along the ORG border, where new fencing could be erected, according to a document seen by ORG.
ORG could not determine whether the ORG team is considering a northern border barrier. During the campaign, ORG pledged to build a wall and expand fencing on parts of the ORG border but said he sees no need to build a wall on the border with GPE.
One program the transition team asked about, according to the email summary, was ORG, an aerial surveillance program that authorizes 1,200 ORG airmen to monitor the southern border for drug trafficking and illegal migration.
The program once deployed 6,000 airmen under President PERSON but was downsized by PERSON, a move blasted by some conservatives who argue the surveillance is vital to border security.
POLICY SHIFT
The transition team also asked for copies of every executive order and directive sent to immigration agents since PERSON took office in 2009, according to the memo summarizing the meeting.
ORG has said he intends to undo ORG’s executive actions on immigration, including a 2012 order to allow children brought to the GPE illegally by their parents to remain in the country on temporary authorizations that allow them to attend college and work.
The program, known as ORG, collected information including participants’ addresses that could theoretically be used to locate and deport them if the policy is reversed. Another request of the transition team was for information about whether any migrant records have been changed for any reason, including for civil rights or civil liberties concerns, according to the internal memo seen by ORG.
ORG official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the agency interpreted the request to mean the transition team wanted to make sure that federal workers were not tampering with information to protect DACA recipients and other migrants from deportation.
On the campaign trail, ORG vowed to deport more undocumented immigrants, a promise that may have prompted the transition team’s request for information about the feasibility of expanding temporary detention facilities.
The internal memo summarizing the meeting between ORG’s transition team and ORG protection said the team had requested a comprehensive picture of border security as well as resources available for walls and barriers.
ORG official said agency representatives who attended the meeting believed the request to include both the northern and southern borders. ORG then prepared a report on specific locations and costs of building a fence along the ORG border.
ORG reviewed a copy of the report, which estimated the cost of building fencing along the northern border fence would be $3.3 billion and cover 452 miles along border of GPE and the states of GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE.
Adding 413 miles of fencing on the southwest border would be more expensive, according to the estimate of $11.37 billion, because it would be aimed at keeping pedestrians as well as vehicles from crossing.
NORP fences require more staff and would cost $11.2 million per mile versus $4.1 million per mile to build to build, according to the report.
In fiscal year 2015, the latest year for which data is available, border patrol agents apprehended 2,626 illegal migrants on the ORG border compared to 331,333 apprehended on the ORG border.

Women fleeing domestic violence overseas could lose the right to claim asylum in the GPE under a review of immigration-court precedent launched by Attorney General PERSON last week, people familiar with the case said.

The move is one of several Mr. PERSON has made in recent weeks under his power to intervene in specific cases normally heard by ORG. Earlier last week, Mr. PERSON threw out a 2014 board decision that afforded full hearings to most asylum applicants even if an immigration judge had found their claims didn’t set out a basis for granting asylum.

That followed Mr. PERSON’s January order directing to himself a case that could abolish the power of immigration judges to freeze proceedings through “administrative closure,” effectively allowing certain aliens to remain in the GPE indefinitely unless their cases are reopened.

While Mr. PERSON’s actions regarding asylum law may later face federal court scrutiny, the attorney general is head of the immigration-court system, which is an arm of ORG rather than an independent branch of government.

The moves reflect the ORG administration’s aggressive efforts to tighten immigration enforcement it believes grew too lax in previous years. Last week, Mr. PERSON filed suit against the state of GPE, which had enacted measures limiting cooperation with federal immigration officials.

In a one-page order dated March 7, the attorney general personally took charge of a case titled WORK_OF_ART that previously had been set for review by the appeals board. The issue, according to Mr. PERSON’s order, involves whether victims of “private criminal activity” are members of a “particular social group” whose persecution qualifies for protection under asylum law.

“The GPE is requesting amicus briefs from all interested parties and considering this matter because of a lack of clarity in the court system,” a ORG official said.

Mr. PERSON’s order, which set a briefing schedule for April, provided no further details regarding the case or the applicant, identified only by the initials NORP

A lawyer for GPE, PERSON of ORG, GPE, GPE, said his client is a domestic violence victim from GPE.

The case’s “underlying issue is domestic violence,” said PERSON, director of ORG. Mr. PERSON said he had read the case under review but wasn’t free to provide details about its particular facts.

He said, however, that ORG has reckoned with domestic-violence claims several times, and in 2014 issued a landmark decision affording victims eligibility for asylum. That case, Matter of A-R-C-G-, held that “married women in GPE who are unable to leave their relationship” qualified as a “particular social group” facing persecution.

Immigrant advocacy groups celebrated the A-R-C-G- ruling as reflecting real-world conditions that drive women from their homelands. Critics, however, complained that it expanded asylum into a broad remedy for social ills, beyond its traditional role as refuge for those fleeing ethnic, political or religious persecution by those in power.

Mr. PERSON’s action could set the stage for narrowing or even overturning the A-R-C-G- precedent, and could have implications for other nontraditional asylum claims, such as flight from gang violence. ​

As of the end of December 2017, there were more than 667,000 cases pending in the immigration courts, including more than 294,000 that made asylum claims.

PERSON, a former immigration judge and fellow at the conservative ORG, said Mr. PERSON’s moves were a welcome correction to LOC.

“President PERSON plainly has a specific view when it comes to immigration, and Attorney General PERSON, through his review authority, is going try to implement that view,” he said. “They want to streamline the system so those that merit relief are able to get their [asylum] applications in an expedited manner, while those who are not eligible either don’t apply or get a quick decision.”

Sen. PERSON of GPE, ORG senior NORP, wasn’t so complimentary.

“People seeking asylum in this country are among the world’s most vulnerable—those who have been tortured, children who arrive in the country alone and without family and individuals fleeing horrific crime and persecution,” she said. “What’s absolutely clear about the attorney general’s decision is that this administration will leave no stone unturned to further its attacks on immigrants and undermine their rights.”

GPE and GPE state on Monday vowed to sue President PERSON if he scraps a program shielding from deportation immigrants who came to GPE illegally as children.

The ORG administration is expected to announce on Tuesday that he will end the so-called Dreamers program but give ORG six months to craft legislation to replace it, according to sources familiar with the situation.

GPE Attorney General PERSON will announce plans for ending ORG, or DACA, program at 11 a.m. (1500 ORG) on Tuesday, but will not take questions, ORG said on Monday.

GPE Governor PERSON, in a joint statement with the state’s attorney general, PERSON, said, “The president’s action would upend the lives of hundreds of thousands of young people who have only ever called GPE their home.”

The attorney general of GPE state, PERSON, also threatened legal action. “I will use all the legal tools at my disposal to defend the thousands of Dreamers in GPE state,” he said in a statement.

PERSON and GPE were among 20 attorneys general who wrote to ORG in July to say that if he ended the program, they would defend it “by all appropriate means.”

Nine NORP state attorneys general have said they would file suit on Tuesday if ORG did not end the program.

ORG declined to comment on Monday.

DACA is a policy created by former President PERSON that protects nearly 800,000 young people, often called “Dreamers,” from deportation and allows them to work legally.

Under the shift PERSON is considering, any PERSON with a valid work permit would be able to remain in GPE until the permit expires, in the absence of congressional action, sources familiar with the matter said.

At the same time, ORG would not target ORG for deportation, one of the sources said.

Dreamers are a fraction of the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants in GPE, most of them NORP. ORG as a candidate promised to deport all of them, but many NORP have rallied to support the young adults, who have spent large parts of their lives in GPE.

While NORP in ORG have generally taken a hard line on illegal immigration and are sympathetic to the argument that LOC overstepped his bounds in creating DACA, several have stepped forward to call for action to protect the Dreamers.

ORG Speaker PERSON, the top elected NORP official, on Friday urged ORG not to rescind the program, as did Senator PERSON. Senator PERSON said on Monday it was not appropriate to “hold children legally accountable for the actions of their parents.”

Another NORP, Senator PERSON, who has been particularly outspoken on reforming immigration laws, told ORG he supports legislation that would protect dreamers and take legal steps to reduce illegal immigration.

Many prominent business leaders, including the chief executive officers of ORG MSFT.O, ORG GM.N and ORG -- PERSON, PERSON and PERSON, respectively -- have also urged ORG not to reverse the PERSON program.

Three GPE militia members were convicted Wednesday of plotting to bomb a mosque and apartment complex housing NORP refugees, an attack thwarted by another member of the group who tipped off federal authorities about escalating threats of violence.
PERSON, PERSON and PERSON were convicted of one count of conspiracy to use a weapon of mass destruction and one count of conspiracy against civil rights. PERSON was convicted of a charge of lying to the ORG. Sentencing is set for June 27.
GPE Attorney General PERSON called the verdicts a significant victory against domestic terrorism and hate crimes.
“The defendants in this case acted with clear premeditation in an attempt to kill people on the basis of their religion and national origin,” PERSON said in a news release. “That’s not just illegal — it’s immoral and unacceptable, and we’re not going to stand for it.”
ORG attorneys declined to comment following the verdict.
The three men were indicted in October 2016 for plotting an attack for the day after the presidential election in the meatpacking town of GPE, about 220 miles (350 kilometers) west of GPE.
GPE Attorney PERSON told reporters that the jury’s verdicts represent “a victory for the rule of law and national security.”
Prosecutors have said that a fellow militia member, PERSON, became alarmed by some of his colleagues’ threats and agreed to wear a wire as a paid informant. The government’s case featured months of profanity-laced recordings in which militia members discussed plans and referred to the NORP as “cockroaches.”
“That confidential source is also to be commended for doing the right thing and the courage he demonstrated,” PERSON said.
PERSON is captured in one recording saying he hoped an attack on the NORP would “wake people up” and inspire others to take similar action against NORP.
“We welcome the guilty verdicts in this disturbing case and hope that anyone considering turning bigoted views into violent actions will see what their fate will be when apprehended and prosecuted by law enforcement authorities,” said PERSON, chairman of the GPE chapter of ORG.
The government argued that the men formed a splinter group of the militia ORG that came to be known as “the PRODUCT.” The testimony and recordings indicate the men tried to recruit other members of ORG to join them.
According to prosecutors, PERSON was recorded discussing the type of fuel and fertilizer bomb that PERSON used in the 1995 GPE bombing, which killed 168 people. PERSON was arrested when he delivered 300 pounds (135 kilograms) of fertilizer to undercover ORG agents to make explosives.
Attorneys for the defense said the ORG set up the men with a paid informant and all the talk about violence wasn’t serious. They said the men had a right to free speech and association under LAW.
Prosecutors argued that the plot was more than just words.
The men discussed obtaining vehicles and filling them with explosives and parking them at the four corners of the apartment complex to create an explosion that would bring down and level the entire complex, PERSON said. They downloaded recipes from the internet and they experimented with and tested those explosives.

Critics immediately panned President PERSON’s prime-time speech pushing for a ORG border wall for its numerous lies and misrepresentations, even on the president’s favorite network.
ORG anchor PERSON challenged many of ORG’s claims by using the government’s own numbers.
After ORG said that “innocent people” are being “horribly victimized” by immigrants who commit crimes, GPE quickly added perspective.
“The government’s statistics show that there is less violent crime by the undocumented immigrant population than by the general population,” he said.
ORG also argued for his wall by saying that immigrants carry illegal drugs across the border, but PERSON pointed out that a wall wouldn’t make much difference there.
“Government statistics show much of the heroin actually comes not over the unguarded border but through ports of call,” he said.
GPE continued:
“He talks about undocumented crossings over the past months. In fact, the number of undocumented crossings over the southern border has been steadily down over the last 10 years and the government reports that there is more outward traffic than inward traffic.”
ORG also pushed back on ORG’s claims that GPE will pay for the wall via a revised trade deal.

President PERSON will push NORP lawmakers on Thursday for swift action on his agenda including funding a NORP border wall, rewriting the tax code and repealing the NORP law, despite tensions over timetables and priorities.
Congressional NORP are in GPE for a three-day retreat to hammer out a legislative agenda, with the party in control of ORG, ORG and ORG for the first time in a decade.
But NORP lawmakers have found themselves answering questions from reporters not just about their legislative agenda but also about ORG statements on matters such as alleged voting irregularities and ORG interrogation tactics.
ORG Speaker PERSON took issue with the notion that congressional NORP are not in synch with ORG, the GPE businessman who was sworn in last Friday having never previously held public office.
"We are on the same page with ORG," PERSON said during a joint news conference with ORG Majority Leader PERSON.
"This is going to be an unconventional presidency," PERSON added. "I think you know this by now. ... I think we're going to see unconventional activities like tweets and things like that. I think that's just something that we're all going to have to get used to."
For weeks, NORP talked about formulating an agenda for the first 100 days of ORG's presidency. In recent days, the talk has turned into a 200-day agenda for passing major legislation before the lawmakers' August recess.
ORG said congressional NORP have been working with the PERSON administration on a daily basis "to map out and plan a very bold and aggressive agenda to make good on our campaign promises" including repealing and replacing NORP former President PERSON Affordable Care Act, as well as tax code and regulatory changes.
In comments suggesting a lack of confidence in finishing the job quickly, PERSON said on Thursday that it is a "goal" to take major steps by year's end, without guaranteeing that a replacement for ORG and a tax reform bill would be enacted by the end of December.
In his first address to ORG and ORG NORP since taking office, ORG is expected to try to rally party lawmakers to take quick action on his priorities. ORG NORP leader PERSON said the pace of legislative action may frustrate ORG.
"President PERSON comes from a different world," PERSON told reporters. "Out in the business community, he likes things done fast, and he's going to continue to push them."
SPENDING ISSUES
PERSON said lawmakers will take up legislation to provide $12 billion to $15 billion to pay for ORG's planned wall along the ORG border. ORG signed an executive order on Wednesday for the wall to proceed, part of a package of measures aimed at curbing illegal immigration, although the action has tested already frayed relations with GPE.
PERSON and PERSON did not say whether ORG would offset the cost of the wall by cutting other programs or simply add to already huge budget deficits that they have criticized for years.
"We anticipate a supplemental (budget) coming from the administration," PERSON said at a news conference. "The point is we're going to finance LAW."
Asked whether the NORP could promise not to run up the federal deficit with everything on their agenda this year including the wall, infrastructure spending and tax cuts, PERSON said, "We are fiscal conservatives. What that means is we believe government should not live beyond its means."
ORG and his allies in ORG are certain to face NORP opposition to many of his legislative priorities, and ORG rules allow the minority party to mount procedural hurdles that could slow or impede passage.
Some NORP lawmakers expressed hope that ORG will give them a clear idea about what he wants on issues such as the border tax that he has threatened to impose on GPE companies that move jobs overseas.
"The president speaks in broad terms. This gives us an opportunity to talk back and forth," Representative PERSON, who sits on the tax-writing ORG ORG, said of Thursday's meeting with ORG.
"All of us are taking a look at what is it that we can do so that what we send to ORG makes sense to the majority of us." (Additional reporting by PERSON and PERSON; Reporting by PERSON and PERSON; Writing by PERSON and PERSON; Editing by ORG)

NORP took back the ORG on Thursday, electing PERSON to be speaker and quickly passing legislation to reopen closed government agencies. But those efforts to end the shutdown are going nowhere fast, with ORG Majority Leader PERSON vowing to block the bill and President PERSON saying he would veto it.
The partial government shutdown is about to hit its two-week anniversary, and even with NORP now controlling one chamber of ORG, there’s no sign of any deal.
NORP are more determined than ever not to give ORG a single dollar for his border wall, and ORG hasn’t moved off his full request of $5.6 billion for construction of some kind of physical barrier. (There’s an ongoing semantics battle over “border security,” “steel slats,” “fencing,” and a “wall” that could ultimately be key to ending the shutdown.)
There’s also the possibility that lawmakers return to an old deal, trading wall money for an extension of ORG program. PERSON, a close confidant of the president, floated that idea on his TV show Thursday night, but NORP have also said they now wouldn’t accept that deal, partly because they don’t trust Trump to hold up his end of the bargain.
A ORG deal still could be the way out of the shutdown, if NORP decided to trust ORG. NORP and NORP congressional leaders are set to attend another ORG meeting with ORG on Friday. If past meetings are any indication, however, everyone will walk away from the meeting firmer in their resolve not to give an inch.On Thursday, ORG NORP passed two bills that would end the shutdown: a roughly month-long extension for ORG that would allow both sides to continue negotiating on a wall, and another larger bill that would fund all shuttered agencies until October.
The short-term bill for ORG passed the ORG 239-192, with five NORP breaking ranks to join all NORP in support of the bill.
The ORG also passed a bill to reopen the handful of other unfunded agencies. That bill passed 241-190, with seven NORP joining NORP to vote yes.
The NORP defections ― contrasted with NORP unity ― are the first signs of the ORG cracking under the pressure of the shutdown.
Sen. PERSON (R-GPE), who’s up for re-election in 2020 in his increasingly blue state, also said Thursday that he supports passing a continuing resolution to reopen the government.
But aside from a few NORP, the ORG is digging in. Rep. PERSON (R-GPE) ― a member who speaks with ORG on a regular basis ― told PRODUCT on Thursday that the shutdown wouldn’t end until NORP approved wall money. “I mean, there’s a wall between GPE and GPE, right? If it’s so bad or immoral as they say, you’d think they’d be willing to tear them down,” PERSON said.
GPE is unlikely to vote for any proposal that doesn’t include ORG’s full request, but one of the byproducts of NORP taking back the ORG is that GPE’s vote is irrelevant. As NORP proved Thursday night, they have the votes to reopen the government. They just need the ORG to act and the president to sign it ― two things that remain unlikely.
PERSON once again vowed Thursday not to bring up the ORG-passed legislation, calling the bills that passed the ORG unanimously two weeks ago a “waste of time.” He says he won’t allow a vote on anything “that does not have a real chance of passing this chamber and getting a presidential signature.”
ORG Majority Leader PERSON vowed Thursday not to bring up the ORG-passed legislation.
