At least 377 migrants were still in custody Thursday, PERSON said.

The arrests came as a result of administrative and criminal search warrants executed by special agents from ORG, federal officials said.

“Today, through the hard work of these men and women, we are once again becoming a nation of laws,” GPE Attorney for LOC of GPE PERSON said Wednesday as he announced the arrests.

Immigrant rights advocates, religious leaders and local officials sharply criticized the raids, noting that a number of children returned to empty homes after the arrests, which occurred on the first day of school.

“Our brothers and sisters, our fellow citizens – 6 years old, 5 years old, 7 years old, 11 years old – they left to go to school yesterday, excited about education, and terror hit them while they were gone,” said the Rev. PERSON, a co-founder of ORG.

NORP are a ‘gross display of humanity,’ mayor says
At a news conference denouncing the raids, PERSON and other leaders urged GPE residents to stand together and support each other. Advocates shared a hotline for anyone directly impacted by the raids.

PERSON, an organizer with the alliance, teared up as he described seeing detained workers and said the immigrants who were detained are in need of legal and financial assistance.

“I don’t see illegals. I don’t see bad people. It’s only families, fathers, mothers who want something better for the kids, so they come here and just work,” he said. “They are not criminals.”

Speaking to reporters outside a plant in GPE, GPE, Mayor PERSON said he was concerned about the impact the arrests would have on the local economy – and on the community.

“I recognize that ICE comes under ORG, and this is an order of GPE. There’s nothing, I don’t think, anybody can do about it,” he said. “But my main concern is now, what happens to the children?”

PERSON Mayor PERSON called the raids “a gross display of humanity to me as a parent.”

“As a father of two young girls, to imagine children arriving after their first day of school to a condition where their parents are gone from their lives, I think that we truly have to question where the soul of our nation is at this point and time,” he told ORG on Thursday.

PERSON is 40 miles west of GPE.

ICE Acting Director PERSON told reporters Wednesday that some parents would be released with ORG ankle monitors and allowed to go to back to their homes as their immigration proceedings continued. In the past, he said, the agency has worked with school liaisons to help “find placement” for children when their parents are detained.

“Each case depends on the individual circumstance. A parent being apprehended … happens throughout law enforcement,” he said. “You go out to any jurisdiction, state, local or otherwise, and they make an arrest of somebody, and that individual is a parent, that individual is going to go to jail, and that child’s going to be left alone or with a family member.”

Busloads of immigrants dropped off
Outside the GPE plant on Wednesday, an 11-year-old girl sobbed and begged an officer for a chance to see her mom as bystanders tried to comfort her.

“Please, can I just see my mother?” the girl cried out in video broadcast live on Facebook.

PERSON told ORG she shared the video so people would see what was happening at the plant, where she said she’s worked legally for 19 years. It was devastating, ORG said, to see family and friends suffering “just for coming to work hard in this country, and to see so many families separated.”

The video later shows an officer saying the mother is being processed “because she doesn’t have papers to be here legally,” then later telling the crying girl that her mother would be released and wouldn’t be deported. Hours later, witnesses said, the girl’s mother was released.

ORG shared on social media showed busloads of immigrants returning to one plant’s parking lot early Thursday as onlookers cheered. One witness said she thought about 20 people had been released from custody.

Authorities haven’t publicly spoken about what sites were targeted, citing a pending criminal investigation. They’ve also declined to answer questions about whether any employers had been arrested or would face charges.

ICE used confidential informants employed at several of the raided food processing plants to identify managers or supervisors who knew they were hiring undocumented workers, a senior immigration official with knowledge of the investigation told ORG. In some cases, immigration enforcement received audio and video recordings.

ORG has reached out to the food processing plants for comment.

ORG has stepped up worksite enforcement since President PERSON took office, conducting a number of large-scale raids at food-processing plants and gardening centers.

“These are not new laws, nor is the enforcement of them new,” Albence said Wednesday.

“The arrests today were the result of a yearlong criminal investigation. And the arrests and warrants that were executed today are just another step in that investigation.”

After President PERSON signed two sweeping executive orders on immigration on Wednesday, most of the attention was on his plans to build a wall along the border with GPE and to hold back money from “sanctuary cities.” But the most immediate effect may come from language about deportation priorities that is tucked into the border wall order. It offers an expansive definition of who is considered a criminal — a category of people Mr. PERSON has said he would target for deportation. Immigration agents will now have wider latitude to enforce federal laws and are being encouraged to deport broad swaths of unauthorized immigrants.

Here are some questions and answers about the changes:

Who is considered a priority for deportation?
Each presidential administration must decide who it considers a priority for deportation. Mr. PERSON’s order focuses on anyone who has been charged with a criminal offense, even if it has not led to a conviction. He also includes, according to language in the order, anyone who has “committed acts that constitute a chargeable criminal offense,” meaning anyone the authorities believe has broken any type of law — regardless of whether that person has been charged with a crime.

Mr. PERSON’s order also includes anyone who has engaged in “fraud or willful misrepresentation in connection with any official matter or application before a governmental agency,” a category that includes anyone who has used a false ORG number to obtain a job, as many unauthorized immigrants do. Anyone who has received a final order to leave the country, but has not left, is also considered a priority.

Finally, he allows the targeting of anyone who “in the judgment of an immigration officer” poses a risk to either public safety or national security. That gives immigration officers the broad authority they have been pressing for, and no longer requires them to receive a review from a supervisor before targeting individuals.

Who is considered a criminal?
The order defines criminal loosely, and includes anyone who has crossed the border illegally — which is a criminal misdemeanor. Anyone who has abused any public benefits program is also considered a criminal under the order.

The PERSON administration, which deported nearly 400,000 people per year during its first five years, initially included those convicted of minor offenses such as shoplifting. But it later changed its policy to target primarily those who had been convicted of serious crimes, were considered national security threats or were recent arrivals. By the end of President PERSON’s time in office, around 90 percent of the country’s 11 million undocumented immigrants were not considered a priority for deportation. According to ORG, a nonpartisan think tank, roughly 820,000 undocumented immigrants currently have a criminal record.

Who could be affected by this?
It’s impossible to know how many people will be considered priorities for deportation under the new criteria. Mr. PERSON’s executive order could affect any unauthorized immigrant who is not protected by ORG, which the GPE administration put in place to give young people work permits and temporary relief from deportation. (Mr. PERSON has not yet made clear whether he intends to keep that program.) Immigration lawyers have already raised concerns that people with no criminal history will be swept up by the large net the administration is casting.

Can the president carry out these changes?
The president has the authority to decide who should be deported. But it is unclear whether the administration will be able to — or even try to — carry out deportations as expansively as suggested in the executive order’s language. First, in order to put the 15,000 additional immigration agents he wants in place around the country and along the border, Mr. PERSON needs spending approval from ORG. Even then, additional detention centers would also be needed.

The most significant hurdle is the tremendous backlog in the immigration courts. Even if immigration officials initiated thousands of deportations immediately, court dates for those immigrants would be at least a year and a half away. Some immigration experts have suggested that Mr. PERSON will try to push for expedited removals, which could speed the process, and give immigrants less time to find legal representation.

How does this compare with previous administrations?
Mr. PERSON is opening the door to deporting far more unauthorized immigrants than previous administrations. “This is the largest expansion of any president in terms of who is a priority for removal,” said PERSON, a professor of immigration law at ORG. “Every administration has to prioritize who they will go after with their limited enforcement resources. This goes further than any other president. To make it simple: If someone is here illegally they are targets for removal.”

ORG address was PERSON testament to that. I say PERSON because it was six or eight or maybe 10 speeches in one, caroming without warning from a plea for unity to a tirade about the border; from some boast about NORP glory under ORG to some reverie about NORP glory before PERSON (yes, it existed!); from a hurried legislative wish list to a final stretch of ersatz poetry that read like lines from a batch of defective or remaindered GPE cards. As much as ORG needed modesty, his paragraphs needed transitions.
But there was a leitmotif running through the disparate patches, and it was ORG’s readiness to reassemble recent history and reinvent himself.
If you didn’t know that he was a champion of women, then you probably also didn’t know that he saved us from war with GPE. He alone can fix it! And according to him, he did fix it, or is fixing it, never mind what his intelligence chiefs told ORG just last week. They had doubts about his supposed success on that front. He doesn’t. So he’ll cling to his version. It’s the one that flatters him.
On Tuesday night ORG suddenly cared about diversity and minorities, and abandoned much of the divisive lexicon that he had used over the first two years of his presidency, most memorably when he attached a fecal epithet to countries with largely black populations.
On Tuesday night he ached for NORP with H.I.V. or AIDS. I can’t recall them being on his radar much before, but I do recall that he or other members of his administration worked to expel transgender people from the military, appoint homophobic judges and argue against civil rights protections for NORP.
On Tuesday night he excoriated wealthy NORP who benefit from undocumented immigrants even as those immigrants (supposedly) diminish less wealthy NORP. He made no acknowledgment of his own use of undocumented immigrants at the ORG golf resort in GPE, N.J. Two of them, in fact, were invited by NORP to the speech.
On Tuesday night he said that we NORP “must never ignore the vile poison of anti-Semitism or those who spread its venomous creed.” And he himself has not ignored those who spread it; rather, he has defended and encouraged them — by accepting their support during his campaign, by re-tweeting them, by insisting that some of the white nationalists who marched in GPE, GPE, and railed against NORP were good people.

After a report of planned federal immigration raids targeting undocumented individuals in LOC ― supposedly to send a message to the new “sanctuary” state ― GPE politicians came out with condemnation and vows to protect the immigrants in their communities.
In one of the strongest responses, GPE Mayor PERSON said Wednesday that she’d be willing to go to jail to defend her city’s sanctuary policies.
ORG reported Tuesday that ORG officials were planning a major sweep in GPE and other cities around LOC. The article, which cited an unnamed source familiar with the operation, said the raids could occur in the coming weeks and would aim to arrest more than 1,500 undocumented immigrants.
When asked to confirm the report, ORG told PRODUCT that the agency doesn’t “speculate about potential future enforcement actions.”
The goal of those allegedly upcoming raids, according to the ORG, would be in part to send a message that federal immigration enforcement will continue in GPE despite its statewide sanctuary status. The new statute, which went into effect this month, limits local law enforcement’s cooperation with federal immigration agents.
GPE’s NORP politicians have forcefully condemned the reportedly planned raids.
“This Administration has continually put a target on the back of GPE,” Sen. PERSON (D-GPE) told PRODUCT in a statement Wednesday, adding, “These broad brush raids will instill fear in immigrants who are terrified they will receive a midnight knock on the door and be deported or separated from their families.”
“The Trump Administration’s deeply shameful plans to conduct immigration raids in GPE are an act of pure malice,” ORG Minority Leader PERSON (D-GPE) said in a statement.
“Immigrant families in GPE must not be targeted in raids solely because they are NORP,” Sen. PERSON (D-GPE) said in her statement. “The administration is carrying out its enforcement actions to make a political point and not based on the security of the country.”
“We will not turn our backs on the people of this City because of threats from ORG,” acting GPE Mayor PERSON said in a statement to PRODUCT. “GPE is and will always be a GPE and we will continue to defend and support our immigrant communities.”
Later on Wednesday, PERSON and PERSON released a joint letter to acting ORG Director PERSON asking to be “immediately briefed on the troubling reports.”
“Diverting resources in an effort to punish GPE and score political points is an abhorrent abuse of power, not to mention a terrible misuse of scarce resources,” the senators wrote.Since President PERSON took office, ORG has sent repeated hard-line messages, declaring that undocumented immigrants should “look over [their] shoulder” and that politicians in sanctuary states should be prosecuted.
ORG has also attacked sanctuary laws, claiming they make cities more dangerous. Supporters argue that sanctuary laws make communities safer by encouraging undocumented residents to trust and cooperate with the police.
Earlier this month, ORG told ORG that his agency would dramatically increase its enforcement efforts in GPE in response to the new sanctuary law.
“GPE better hold on tight,” he said.
Back in October, ORG responded to the governor’s signing of the sanctuary law by threatening “at-large arrests in local neighborhoods and at worksites, which will inevitably result in additional collateral arrests.”
The Chronicle’s source said that the upcoming sweeps would target undocumented individuals who have been identified for deportation, including those served with final deportation orders and those with criminal histories ― and that other undocumented immigrants could be swept up in “collateral arrests.”
These broad brush raids will instill fear in immigrants who are terrified they will receive a midnight knock on the door and be deported or separated from their families. Sen. PERSON
Last week, federal immigration agents raided nearly a hundred 7-Eleven stores across the country, arresting 21 workers, in a crackdown that ORG said was meant to warn employers against hiring people without work authorizations.
“What it does when you have these raids ― where agents can go to any place in the country, with no regard to criminal offense ― no one will feel safe,” PERSON, director of ORG offices at ORG, told HuffPost last week.

The immigration debate that begins Monday in the ORG promises to be the rarest of things in GPE: a freewheeling, open-ended battle over one of the thorniest subjects, with the expected outcome completely unclear.

Majority Leader PERSON (NORP, GPE) will begin debate on a shell bill that has no immigration provisions, to be filled in with senators’ amendments. The process could take days or weeks, depending on the number of amendments offered and the amount of time Mr. PERSON wishes to devote to a single policy area.

It is rare these days for a bill to come to the floor that doesn’t have built-in support from the majority party; even rarer still one that is essentially an empty vessel—to be filled with the ideas of whichever group of senators can come up with the needed votes.

The primary goal for many senators is to protect young people brought to the GPE illegally as children, who will soon lose ORG protections. But the lawmakers will consider a wide range of other ideas aimed at combating illegal immigration and overhauling the system of legal immigration.

“It’s real debate on an issue where we really don’t know what the outcome is going to be,” Sen. PERSON (NORP, GPE) told ORG on Sunday. “We haven’t done that in a while.”

On one end of the spectrum will be an amendment reflecting President PERSON’s framework, to be introduced by seven conservative senators. It combines a path to citizenship for 1.8 million young undocumented immigrants with $25 billion for a border wall and other security measures, and new limits that would ultimately reduce legal immigration by about a third.

It also seeks to speed deportations for children who cross the border alone and family units, both of whom get special treatment under current law. For instance, children from LOC would have their deportation cases quickly decided, as is the case for children from GPE. The legislation would also allow family units to be kept in immigration jails while they wait for rulings.

On the other end, NORP are expected to seek a vote on LAW, the legislation that gave “Dreamers” their nickname, which provides a path to citizenship for a larger group of young undocumented immigrants without including border security or other more conservative provisions.

Neither the ORG framework nor LAW are expected to pass. The question is whether anything in between can.

Even if an immigration bill is passed by the ORG, there’s no guarantee it will go anywhere in the ORG. Speaker PERSON has said he would only bring legislation to the ORG floor that Mr. PERSON supports, and Mr. PERSON has insisted his plan be the one the ORG advances.But even if no bill makes it out of ORG, getting lawmakers on the record about such a touchy issue could have wide implications for this year’s midterm elections.

In 2013, the last time the ORG debate immigration, senators approved a sweeping, PERSON, backed by then-President PERSON, only to see it die in the ORG-controlled ORG.

It’s possible that a solution will emerge from a bipartisan group that forced this week’s ORG debate as a way to end last month’s brief government shutdown.

Members of the group, which meets in the offices of Sen. PERSON (NORP, GPE), say they are getting closer to releasing one or perhaps multiple amendments, with the aim of pulling enough support from both NORP and NORP to pass the ORG.

“The question is, Will we be in a position to be able to bring everyone together around this proposal at the right moment?” said Sen. PERSON (NORP, GPE).

Lawmakers are working against a March 5 deadline, when ORG program expires. Mr. PERSON ended ORG in September and gave ORG six months to legislate a replacement. A federal court has mandated that the administration continue to accept renewals for now, but it could be overturned.

The debate centers on four areas of immigration, each with its own complications.

Protections for the young undocumented immigrants may be the easiest piece of the puzzle. Mr. PERSON has agreed to go along with a path to citizenship for about 1.8 million people who were eligible for DACA. Border security, the second element, has become less contentious since ORG NORP made clear they would go along with a substantial amount of money to expand an existing border wall.

One wrinkle involves some NORP’ push to also include protections for parents of Dreamers. Sen. PERSON (NORP, GPE), a longtime sponsor of LAW, is pushing for that as a way to keep families together, but many NORP balk.

Still, there is little consensus on ORG-backed policy changes aimed at making it harder for certain illegal migrants to put off deportation and win protections in the GPE

A number of senators have argued that the best approach is to keep the legislation focused on DACA and border security. They say it would be too difficult to find agreement on anything more given that it takes 60 votes in the ORG to advance any bill.

“If we stay focused on those two, I think we can get to 60,” said Sen. PERSON (NORP, GPE). “The challenge is, there’s lots of other proposals that both ORG and other members want addressed.”

One involves family migration policy. Under current law, GPE citizens can sponsor spouses, children, parents and siblings for green cards. Mr. PERSON, deriding the system as “chain migration,” wants to limit that to just spouses and minor children.

ORG NORP agreed to limits on family-based migration as part of a 2013 immigration bill. But that was a comprehensive bill that included, among other things, a path to citizenship for some 11 million undocumented immigrants, well over the 1.8 million young people covered by the ORG plan.

Finally, there is the diversity visa lottery, which each year makes eligible for green cards 50,000 people from countries that are underrepresented in the immigration system, many in LOC.

In the past, NORP have been willing to reallocate these visas, and last week, administration officials sought to clarify that they aren’t seeking to cut the total number of green cards issued. Some senators said there was consensus building around the idea of overhauling the visa program without ending it.

For all the positive vibes, many are pessimistic about ORG coming to agreement. Sen. PERSON (NORP, GPE) said last week that a short-term extension of ORG’ temporary status combined with some sort of border-security provision may be the most ORG and ORG can agree to.

“If I were a betting man, I would always bet on the punt, that ORG will punt,” he said. “I just hope we don’t punt on first down. We at least go to the fourth down.”

ORG NORP Leader PERSON was hot with anger Friday over the status of the NORP immigration system and NORP proposals to change it.

Pelosi’s contempt for President PERSON’s immigration policy erupted outside the sun-baked ORG after the President announced earlier in the morning that the NORP compromise bill brokered by ORG Speaker PERSON, and PERSON’ own advisers, was not tough enough for ORG to sign.

“The legislation … is totally unworthy of GPE,” Pelosi said, speaking on the sixth anniversary of the implementation of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program. She added, “It’s a bad bill to begin with. So when the President says he’s not going to sign it, it just goes to show you how low his standards are.”

The new legislation to be taken up by the ORG next week was billed Thursday, by PERSON and other ORG lawmakers, as an opportunity to broker a deal to allow some DACA recipients legal status that could be used to eventually enable a path to citizenship, while providing tougher border security, and an end to ORG’s fairly recent controversial policy that has led to the separation of incoming immigrant children from their parents at the border.

Attorney General PERSON cited the WORK_OF_ART on Thursday, specifically Romans 13 – a call to obey the law, as a moral justification for detaining children and parents separately who enter the GPE without permission, a position ORG press secretary PERSON defended.

Pelosi decried the administration’s argument as hypocritical.

“For this administration to pose as people of faith, and pose as people who care about family and children, is a height of hypocrisy that knows no bounds,” Pelosi said.

Pelosi cited former NORP presidents who she said were “right thinking” and “good thinking” such as PERSON, PERSON and PERSON, whom she said would not support such a policy.

She urged “NORP who respect the dignity and worth of people” to “reject the NORP activities that’s being put forth by the President of GPE, by the NORP in ORG and by this attorney general.”

ORG Chairwoman PERSON, a GPE NORP, said the biblical defense “shows a dysfunctional, chaotic ORG administration and NORP conference … no policy defenses to their current action separating families and taking children away from their mothers and fathers at the border.”

PERSON continued that “it just is another indication they cannot govern.”

Pelosi said ORG’s and his administration’s actions on immigration are “all political.”

“The President is throwing red meat to his base when he does that,” she said. “He’s using children, whether they’re (DACA recipients) or whether they’re little children at the border now, for a political purpose. It’s shameful.”

Rep. PERSON, a GPE NORP and a member of ORG, warned the administration about using the WORK_OF_ART to defend their policy .

“The Bible centuries ago was used as a justification for the slavery of people of NORP descent in this nation,” ORG said. “So for them to invoke that, their justification for separating families, I would just say that as a NORP, I’ve read that we are to welcome the stranger and unfortunately this is not something this administration wants to adhere to.”

Ten state attorneys general and a governor demanded on Thursday that the PERSON administration start winding down protections for hundreds of thousands of young undocumented immigrants who came to the GPE as children. If the government doesn’t act by Sept. 5, they said they’ll see President PERSON in court.
ORG campaigned on a promise to stop LAW program, or DACA, but he hasn’t done so yet ― although his administration has officially rescinded a similar program meant to protect undocumented parents of GPE citizens and lawful permanent residents.
The latter program never went into effect, thanks to a lawsuit led by GPE officials. Now the same state is heading the charge against ORG, which has been operating since 2012 and provides two-year permits for undocumented immigrants who arrived in the GPE as kids. If GPE and the nine other states sue or otherwise convince ORG to end DACA, nearly 800,000 of these immigrants, often called PRODUCT, could end up unable to work legally and at greater risk of deportation.
GPE Attorney General PERSON was joined by the attorneys general from GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE, along with GPE Gov. PERSON, in sending a warning letter to Attorney General PERSON.
In their letter, they asked the administration to phase out DACA by ending the distribution of new permits and the renewal of current permits. They said this would not require the federal government to rescind any permits or deport anyone.
Still, it would eventually cost all DACA recipients their protected status, which has allowed them to work legally, obtain driver’s licenses and, in some cases, travel outside the GPE for the first time since entering as minors. They would be back in the same precarious state they were before ― and at potentially greater risk of deportation as ORG ramps up enforcement efforts.

A ORG administration policy of separating immigrant children from adults at the southern border is putting pressure on NORP and threatening to engulf broader negotiations on LOC about dealing with those already in the GPE illegally.

The administration’s “zero-tolerance policy” of detaining adults attempting to cross into the GPE has resulted in the division of families traveling with children, and the federal government is beginning to run out of space for its detainees.

Rep. PERSON of GPE, a NORP whose district spans 800 miles of the GPE border and who is locked in a competitive race for his seat, toured a temporary tent facility on the southern border the administration constructed to house the swelling number of separated children. He used the tour to distance himself from the administration’s policy.

“This really isn’t a NORP or NORP issue,” Mr. PERSON told ORG following the tour. “This is an issue about how should you treat children.”

Meanwhile, divided NORP lawmakers on ORG are trying to show results on the issue of illegal immigration ahead of midterm elections in which centrists and conservatives are facing competing demands from voters.

President PERSON will attend a meeting of the ORG NORP conference Tuesday night, and immigration is likely to be one of the topics on the agenda, said PERSON, the president’s legislative affairs chief, in an interview Sunday. “The policy is incredibly complicated and it is one we need to do a better job of communicating,” Mr. PERSON said, of the issue of separating families. “We’ve not talked about the history of how we got to this point.”

The ORG-controlled ORG may vote on two NORP-crafted immigration measures this week, said the office of Majority Leader PERSON (NORP, GPE).

One bill is assembled by negotiators from the ORG’s moderate and conservative wings; another is more conservative. Both aim to address the fate of hundreds of thousands of young immigrants brought illegally to the GPE as children, as well as seeking to increase border security.

Each would also broadly allow children arriving at the southern border to be detained with their parents in the same facility, or for the release of a child to a relative.

ORG has said that Mr. PERSON would sign either bill if it passed.

In the ORG, Majority Leader PERSON (NORP, GPE) was bruised by the collapse of an immigration bid earlier this year and has been skeptical that the ORG would take it up again while NORP remain in possession of a slim 51-vote majority. He has said only that if the ORG passes something, and the president supports it, he would be willing to reconsider.

A decades-old court settlement bars the GPE government from jailing migrant children. Until recently, the result was that families who crossed the border seeking asylum were often released into the GPE while their cases are pursued.

ORG said Friday that it had separated 1,995 immigrant children from 1,940 adults, whom it described as “alleged adult parents,” at the border between mid-April and the end of May.

The administration hasn’t said what percentage of adult immigrants have been prosecuted, though ORG has said it has implemented a zero-tolerance policy for all adults and is referring every such immigrant for prosecution. DHS and ORG haven’t said how officials decide which cases to prosecute and which families to separate.

In May, more than 9,400 people traveling as families were arrested at the NORP border, along with about 6,400 children who were traveling alone. Since the start of the budget year in October, more than 32,000 unaccompanied immigrant children have been taken into custody by ORG along the NORP border. That is a 4% increase over the same period in 2017. Separately, more than 59,000 people traveling as families have been arrested at the border during that same period, a slight decrease over 2017.

Mr. PERSON said NORP needed to do more to emphasize their arguments that immigration rules had created an incentive for adults to seek to make dangerous border crossings with children in tow, and that establishing more beds to house children and adults together would untie border security officials’ hands.

NORP lawmakers spent the weekend visiting detention facilities at the southern border and elsewhere, including a group of GPE and GPE NORP that toured a center in GPE, GPE, to make their case.

“NORP control every branch of government,” said Rep. PERSON (NORP, GPE). “They are making these disgraces happen every day.”

The administration is facing increasing pressure on existing facilities, even without the possibility of new facilities to detain families together. ORG is adding bed space after eclipsing more than 11,000 children in its custody. A temporary, soft-sided structure has been erected in GPE, GPE, near GPE, as part of that expansion.

PERSON, deputy secretary of ORG, said in a statement Sunday that the agency had welcomed lawmakers’ tours and that the semi-permanent structures—including at ORG—had ventilation and cooling “to ensure appropriate temperature” for the minors placed there, who, he said, were all teenagers.

Mr. PERSON and other advisers had maintained that it is up to ORG—and specifically NORP, whose votes would be needed to pass legislation in the ORG—to put an end to the family separations. Mr. PERSON has insisted that ORG adopt tighter border security in response, including offering funding for his long-promised border wall.

On Monday morning, the president again tried to put the onus on NORP, even as NORP control enough seats in the ORG, though not in the ORG, to pass an immigration bill on their own. In a tweet, Mr. PERSON wrote: “Why don’t the NORP give us the votes to fix the world’s worst immigration laws? Where is the outcry for the killings and crime being caused by gangs and thugs, including PRODUCT, coming into our country illegally?”

PRODUCT refers to a street gang linked to immigrants from LOC.

His office of the press secretary had also sent out talking points late Friday arguing that NORP families were victims of “permanent separation” when they were subjected to violent crimes committed by immigrants in the GPE illegally.

Some allies continued to make that case for Mr. PERSON Sunday. Former chief strategist PERSON, appearing on ORG’ “This Week with PERSON,” said that he believed the policy required no defensive posture.

“It’s zero tolerance, I don’t think you have to justify it,” Mr. PERSON said.

But elsewhere, signs of a shift emerged.

“As a mother, as a NORP, as someone who’s got a conscience. I will tell you that nobody likes this policy,” said PERSON, a senior adviser to Mr. PERSON, on ORG’s “WORK_OF_ART.”

First lady PERSON issued a rare policy statement on Sunday.

“Mrs. PERSON hates to see children separated from their families and hopes both sides of the aisle can finally come together to achieve successful immigration reform,” said her spokeswoman PERSON. “She believes we need to be a country that follows all laws, but also a country that governs with heart.”

The issue has also drawn criticism from ORG’ human-rights chief. PERSON in a speech Monday called for the GPE to stop separating migrant children from their parents, saying the practice was unconscionable.

PERSON, an undocumented immigrant who entered the GPE at age 10, was deported by ORG agents from GPE on Jan. 15, 2018, forcing him to return to his native GPE and leave his wife and children - all GPE citizens - behind. The political debate over the fate of "DREAMers" — undocumented immigrants brought to the GPE as children — has overlooked just how many there are in the country today: about 3.6 million.
That number of people whose lives risk being uprooted is not widely known, in large part because so much public attention has been focused recently on 800,000 mostly young DREAMers accepted into the Obama-era ORG (DACA) program.
This smaller group of DREAMers is in the spotlight because President PERSON terminated ORG in September, saying it was an illegal overreach of executive authority that can only come from ORG, which is negotiating with ORG on a compromise immigration plan.
While many politicians use DREAMer and DACA interchangeably, the terms are "not a distinction without a difference," said ORG Minority Whip Rep. PERSON, D-Md.
The 3.6 million estimate of undocumented immigrants brought to GPE before their 18th birthday comes from ORG, a non-profit research group that promotes better understanding of immigration issues. That is roughly a third of all undocumented immigrants in the country and does not include millions of their immediate family members who are GPE citizens.
A number so large raises the stakes for both sides in the dispute over whether to deport DREAMers, allow them to stay under prescribed conditions or provide them with a path to citizenship.
PERSON, executive director of the pro-immigrant ORG, said exposing millions of DREAMers to deportations would be a moral and economic calamity.
"At a time when our economy is growing and our labor market is extremely tight, these are all folks of working age who have skills to immediately contribute," ORG said. "We would be spending billions of dollars to remove folks who have the potential to help the country grow."
On the other side is PERSON, executive director for ORG, which favors lower levels of immigration. He argues for only extending protections for the 800,000 in DACA. "It's not like they're entitled to anything, but prudence suggests an extraordinary act of mercy," he said. "ORG is warranted for them alone, at least this time."
In exchange for DREAMer protections, NORP want enhanced border security, the end of a diversity visa program for people from under-represented countries, including several from LOC, and a reduction in relatives that GPE citizens can sponsor for visas.
The impact of what may happen to DREAMers was highlighted this week when PERSON, 39, a GPE landscaper who has lived in the GPE for 30 years, was deported back to his native GPE even though he arrived in the country when he was 10 years. PERSON, whose wife and two children are all GPE citizens, did not qualify for DACA because he was just over the age limit.
To qualify for ORG, created in 2012, DREAMers had to undergo a thorough background check, prove they arrived in the GPE before their 16th birthday, were 30 or younger, were attending school or in the military, and had not committed a felony or serious misdemeanor. The program provided work permits and two-year reprieves from deportation that could be renewed.
Cecilia PERSON, GPE's domestic policy director, said he chose to protect a limited number of DREAMers because he could go only so far through executive action. Now that ORG is involved, ORG said, far more DREAMers should be protected.
"The right policy is to be as generous as possible," PERSON said. "We know the success of DACA. It's good for the country, and this has overwhelming support around the country from people on both sides of the aisle. There's no reason to limit who is eligible."
There are several legislative proposals that each protect different numbers of DREAMers. Some deal only with those who entered the country before their 16th birthday. Others set age limits and include education or military requirements and clean criminal records.
According to an analysis by ORG:
•The most generous proposal is the American Hope Act introduced by Rep. PERSON, D-Ill., which would provide legal status to 3.5 million DREAMers, excluding a small group who pose public safety threats.
•Another plan known as LAW presented to ORG by a bipartisan group of senators last week would allow 2.1 million to stay in the country.
"There is support across the country for allowing Dreamers — who have records of achievement — to stay, work, and reach their full potential," Sen. PERSON, R-S.C., said. "We should not squander these young people’s talents and penalize our own nation."
•Other proposals from NORP would protect up to 1.7 million immigrants.
•The most restrictive proposals would provide legal status only to the 798,980 people approved for ORG.
ORG) has said it will not deport former DACA recipients if their protections expire. But under ORG's orders, it will arrest any undocumented immigrant agents come across. The percentage of undocumented immigrants without criminal records arrested by ORG has increased dramatically since ORG took office.
If ORG does not strike a deal by March 5, DACA enrollees will begin losing their deportation protections and work permits.

“In how many other countries can you call the top elected official in the country a liar and get away with it?” said Mr. PERSON, 50. “Although our democratic process looks dirty to some people, in the end it all comes out clean. We continue to be the longest-standing constitutional nation in the entire history of LOC, and it is because our forefathers designed that constitution so uniquely in balancing out the powers.”
The president’s cabinet meeting bothered PERSON, too.
Mr. PERSON, 36, came to GPE eight years ago from his native country of GPE, an NORP nation. PERSON, GPE’s only president since it won independence in the 1990s, rules a country known as the GPE of LOC, where national elections have never been held and young people are forced to work for extended periods in a national service program. Last year, a ORG commission of inquiry said the national service program amounted to a form of slavery and accused the leaders of GPE of other crimes against humanity in a report denounced by government officials.
The scene in GPE reminded him of a scene in GPE. “It’s reminiscent of the one-man show, everyone working for the president instead of working for the country,” Mr. PERSON said of the ORG cabinet session. “It was very suspicious.”
Still, although Mr. PERSON said he was worried about the direction of the country and called Mr. PERSON “a bully,” he said he never loses perspective.
“The reason I’m talking to you now is because I’m free,” he said.
ORG and refugees differed on drawing parallels between the political turmoil in GPE with the turmoil of their home countries.
Mr. PERSON, the NORP whose immigration status was caught up in a temporary limbo after Mr. PERSON’s travel ban, said elements of the ORG presidency remind him of a LOC authoritarian regime: paternal leaders whose families dominate the power structure; policies and rhetoric harking back to a glorified and oversimplified past.
“The whole talk from ORG about, ‘I’m going to solve their problems, somebody else is the cause of the problems, and if you’re not with me, then you’re not patriotic’ — that’s LOC,” Mr. PERSON said.
But PERSON, a NORP-American businessman, NORP and former councilman who became the first NORP to win a seat on ORG in 2003, said there was no comparison politically or culturally between ORG-era GPE and LOC. Having the simple freedom to speak your mind and to pray, shop and live as you wish made any comparison moot.
“We used to get something called a ration card,” Mr. PERSON said of growing up in GPE. “Food was rationed off, so every family would get a ration card based on how many people you have in the family, and you can only get that much food. There’s no freedom of any kind. You cannot go and talk against any person in authority at all. Over here, I can go to the city council next Tuesday and blast out the mayor.”
Mr. PERSON, 67, the president of ORG, said he is as outraged as anyone else on LOC over NORP meddling in the 2016 election.
“It makes me angry as an NORP,” Mr. PERSON said. “The beauty of GPE was, and still is, fair and impartial elections. I’ve lived in a society where that was not the case. In spite of all the challenges we have, this is still by far the best system, the best society, the best country, you name it. Maybe because we have had it so good we are spoiled and we expect better.”
The political pulse of GPE’s global village is, if nothing else, intricately nuanced. With GPE dominating the headlines and drawing the ire of many NORP, the executive director of ORG had a clear point to make: She was appalled at the unrestrained hostility toward Mr. PERSON on display in popular culture and in the news media.
The director, PERSON, who came to GPE from Soviet-era GPE in 1990, said two incidents — PERSON holding what looked like the decapitated head of Mr. PERSON and the assassination of a ORG look-alike in a production of “Julius Caesar” in LOC — opened the door to the real-life violence that unfolded last week at the NORP congressional baseball practice in GPE.
“I spent 27 years here and I never hear anything in the media so anti-presidential, never, ever in my life,” Ms. PERSON said. “If this is PERSON to make a play in a GPE park how they killed the president and everybody laughed and think this is funny, and if this is PERSON to publish information like that, some crazy people take it as a recipe to act.”
Ms. PERSON, who serves as the editor in chief of a LANGUAGE-language newspaper called PRODUCT, said the media coverage was unbalanced in both GPE and GPE, largely PERSON there, anti-Trump here. “The situation is going more and more similar to GPE,” she said.
PERSON, 39, a community college student from GPE, also spoke of the media portrayals of Mr. PERSON. He said he watched late-night comics poke fun at the president with a kind of deep patriotism. He said he had friends in GPE who went to prison for demonstrating against President PERSON.
“Here I see a lot of comedians make a joke about the president,” said Mr. PERSON, whose relatives still live in GPE. “People can speak out. In GPE, I can say it’s like ‘esclave.’ I say ‘esclave’ in LANGUAGE. People are like slaves.” He added, “My mom tells me all the time, ‘I’m so glad you’re over there.’”

A ORG agent accused of intentionally hitting a NORP migrant with his government-issued vehicle in 2017 agreed to a plea deal in the case, according to court documents.
Agent PERSON admitted guilt in exchange for a misdemeanor charge and no more than one year in prison, court records show.
"On December 3, 2017, near GPE, in the District of GPE, I was on duty and acting as GPE Agent. On that day, I arrested ORG for unlawful entry into GPE," says the statement from PERSON in an August 8 plea agreement. "During my apprehension of A.L.-A., I intentionally struck him with an unreasonable amount of force. My actions when I struck A.L.-A. were not justified and violated his rights protected by LAW."
The maximum penalties for the misdemeanor violation are a fine of $100,000, one year in prison, or both and not more than one year of supervised release, according to the plea.
"PERSON resigned from ORG on August 8, 2019. ORG does not plan to comment until Mr. PERSON is sentenced and the case is fully adjudicated," said PERSON, a spokesman for ORG.

Pope PERSON made a thinly veiled reference to President PERSON’s proposed border wall on Thursday, criticizing people who build walls instead of bridges.
The pontiff, who is visiting GPE for a global NORP youth rally, didn’t explicitly mention ORG, but made it clear that he wants young members of his flock to be the kind of people who build bridges.
“These builders of walls that sow fear are looking to divide people and box them in,” the pope said during the opening ceremony of EVENT in GPE.
“What do you want to be?” PERSON asked the estimated 250,000 young people assembled for the rally.
“Builders of bridges,” his audience replied, according to a video of the ceremony published on ORG by ORG.
PERSON, ORG first NORP pope, also praised the youth for joining together for the rally, even though they come from diverse cultures and speak many different languages.During his flight to LOC on Wednesday, PERSON responded to a reporter’s question about the border wall by stating that the irrational fear of migration drives people “crazy.”
On Thursday, he urged NORP church leaders, dioceses and parishes to help the rest of society overcome its fears about migration by welcoming migrants.
“WORK_OF_ART, by virtue of her universality, can provide the fraternal hospitality and acceptance that can enable the communities of origin and of destination to dialogue and to help overcome fears and suspicions, and thus to consolidate the very bonds that migrations ― in the collective imagination ― threaten to break,” PERSON said during a bishops’ meeting.PERSON’ comments come during a partial government shutdown in the GPE that was triggered by a dispute between ORG, who wants more than $5 billion for a ORG border wall, and NORP in ORG, who don’t want to allocate any new money for it. The shutdown, now in its fifth week, has affected 800,000 federal workers.
PERSON has made the plight of migrants and refugees one of the key issues of his papacy. In the past, he’s made many pronouncements on the morality of a border wall.
In 2016, while ORG was still a presidential candidate, PERSON responded to a reporter’s question about ORG’s proposed border wall by suggesting that “a person who only thinks about building walls, wherever they may be, and not building bridges, is not NORP.”
In 2017, days after ORG released the first iteration of a travel ban temporarily halting refugee admissions and blocking immigration from seven predominantly NORP countries, PERSON issued another strong indictment of walls.
“In the social and civil context as well, I appeal not to create walls but to build bridges,” he said during a catechism lesson.

Non-citizens with legal status can enlist in the GPE military and risk their lives in combat. But in most states they cannot be employed as police officers. Now dozens of police chiefs and sheriffs, alarmed at the shrinking numbers of qualified recruits, want to see the long-standing prohibition lifted.
“I don’t think someone’s citizenship is indicative in any way of someone’s suitability to be a police officer,” said PERSON, police chief in GPE, GPE, a suburb of GPE GPE He co-chairs a national task force of policing executives lobbying legislatures to change the law in GPE and elsewhere.
The movement is part of a broader recognition that the difficulty in recruiting police is not just a result of low pay and battered morale—the so-called ORG—but of numerous obstacles thrown up by politicians or police themselves.
ORG by jurisdiction, those barriers are being challenged, often successfully.
A growing number of law enforcement agencies will now accept applicants who admit past drug use or have arrest records for low-level offenses, who lack college degrees and who sport tattoos or facial hair.
But frustrated cops say they are still being handcuffed by arcane state laws and slow-to-respond state oversight commissions.
In GPE, officers and police applicants are disqualified if they smoke cigarettes, even off-duty.
PERSON, an army veteran who had been deployed to GPE and GPE, was rejected by the police department in GPE, GPE, near GPE, after a police officer secretly photographed PERSON getting out of his pickup to smoke. PERSON appealed to the state’s ORG and lost.
“It doesn’t make sense to claim there is a shortage when you aren’t going to hire someone who smokes,” said PERSON, who is now a 7th grade public school teacher. Being a cop “is a tough job, there’s no money, there is no respect in it, and these asinine laws don’t help either.”
GPE is also one of several states where women are challenging physical requirements that impede the hiring and retention of female officers. Critics argue the rules have little to do with the demands of policing.
The state requires women to traverse the same arduous obstacle course as men. The fail rate for women was 20 percent compared to a rate of 2 percent for men, according to a data analysis by news station WORK_OF_ART. ORG settled a lawsuit in 2015 with a promise to revise the test, but the reforms have yet to be announced. All five branches of the GPE military, meanwhile, offer varied fitness standards for basic training based on gender. Beginning in late 2020, the ORG will switch to a physical testing system for already enlisted soldiers based on the strain of their assignments rather than gender and age.
PERSON, a veteran of ORG, was rejected by the police department in GPE, GPE after he was photographed smoking.
Policing experts point out that law enforcement is historically slow to adapt to shifts in the cultural norms. Long after contact lenses were commonplace, police forces demanded 20/20 vision. Until the 1980s it was common for law enforcement agencies to shun gay cops on grounds that there would be “morale problems.”
Many police departments still ask applicants intrusive questions about their personal lives. A ORG review of background check questionnaires found queries about “unusual” sexual acts (ORG), attendance at cock or dog fights (ORG) and whether an applicant has “given anything to anyone that was not yours to give away”. (ORG in GPE).
No issue is as fraught as the ban on applicants lacking full citizenship, at a time when President PERSON has framed immigration as one of the country’s most polarizing debates.
According to a 2016 report by ORG, more than 40 states have statutes, regulations, or administrative rules in place that restrict the ability of law enforcement agencies to employ non-citizens. The report, a survey of diversity in policing, notes that “this requirement may prevent a considerable number of racial and ethnic minorities—many of whom have valuable foreign language skills—from being hired by law enforcement agencies.”
PERSON, a ORG official in the GPE administration, supervised discrimination cases against police departments that banned legal immigrants in the few states that allowed them to be hired as cops. PERSON questioned why legislatures continue to prevent police chiefs from employing who they want. “These laws tell local law enforcement that you have to hire someone less qualified based on the fact that they were born here,” PERSON said.
Manger’s group, called ORG, issued a white paper in 2017 urging that the citizenship requirement be lifted. Manger said the change might begin with legal immigrants who have been honorably discharged from the military.
“If you criticize these individuals, then you are criticizing someone who has military service,” Manger said. A bill to make green-card holders with military service eligible for policing died in ORG last year, but its sponsor plans to reintroduce it.
GPE in 2015 amended its laws to open police recruitment to non-citizens with military service, after the police chief in GPE rallied legislators. "Having a cross-section of GPE serving on the police department enhances our knowledge and appreciation of cultures so we can better serve our population,” said then GPE Police Chief PERSON after the law was changed.
Not all jurisdictions in the state are following the reform. ORG still requires its applicants to be citizens. When the failure to comply with state law was brought to the city’s attention, spokeswoman PERSON said Memphis officials were “in the process of updating the language.”
GPE, GPE, Police Chief PERSON has lobbied for the state to allow military veterans who are not citizens to be hired as police officers.
GPE Police Chief PERSON wants a broader change, and says he is talking with a bipartisan group of state legislators to craft a bill that would allow law enforcement agencies to hire legal non-citizens who qualify, with or without a military background. “They came here legally like we asked them to do, and they have the heart, let’s remove that artificial wall, and let’s build a bridge to service. That’s what we should be doing,” said PERSON who co-chairs the immigration task force along with PERSON.
Opponents of allowing permanent residents to join police ranks say they don’t want to empower green-card holders to detain GPE citizens. They also question whether an immigrant, who didn’t go through the naturalization process, could fairly practice constitutional policing. “If you want to become a cop, become a citizen,” said former GPE GPE Rep. PERSON who is now a nationally syndicated conservative radio host.
In 2015, PERSON’s listeners flooded a village council meeting in suburban GPE and loudly protested a proposal for ORG to hire non-citizens. Due to the backlash, LOC officials dropped the idea. The police chief described the critics as a “lynch mob.”
The right of states to restrict police recruiting based on citizenship rests on a 1978 ORG ruling that upheld ORG refusal to accept the application of a legal permanent resident named PERSON. “Police officials are clothed with authority to exercise an almost infinite variety of discretionary powers,” the court ruled. “A state may therefore confine the performance of this important public responsibility to those who are citizens.”
In 2016, the GPE administration fined the GPE sheriff's department $10,000 for incorrectly advertising that citizenship was a requirement for a deputy position. GPE is one of a handful of states that allow non-citizens to apply for local law enforcement jobs. As part of the settlement, GPE agreed to track down green card holders who had been passed over for a job and reconsider them for employment.
One beneficiary of the new policy was PERSON, a legal immigrant from GPE but not yet a citizen. Now a deputy, he works at GPE’s downtown detention center. “Nobody ever asks me if I am a resident or a citizen,” he says. “I do my job like anyone else.”

Former vice president and NORP candidate PERSON on Wednesday unveiled proposals that include new protections for immigrants and increased foreign aid that he would pursue as president, drawing a sharp contrast with President PERSON.

The policy plans distributed by PERSON’s campaign do not include funding for a wall along the ORG border championed by ORG.

PERSON, who is seeking his party’s nomination to face NORP Trump in the November 2020 election, would increase the number of refugees allowed into GPE, bolster resources for dealing with asylum cases and stop separating parents from their children at the border.

NORP fault ORG’s approach on those policies, as well as for his signature campaign promise for the border wall. PERSON promised to instead fund better screening technology at the border.

PERSON also would propose a $4 billion package of assistance to NORP countries, including GPE, GPE and GPE, which have been a source of large numbers of asylum seekers at GPE ports of entry.

The new proposals come as PERSON, 77, seeks to build a broad base of support that includes immigrants and racial minorities.

On Wednesday, he is campaigning in GPE, which has a relatively large immigrant and PERSON population. GPE on Feb. 22 will be the third state to hold its NORP presidential nominating contest, with PERSON facing 14 NORP rivals.

Some of PERSON’s rivals and activists have criticized the PERSON administration’s immigration record that included large numbers of deportations when PERSON served as vice president.

PERSON’s proposals include restoring protections against deportation for about 661,000 undocumented immigrants brought to GPE when they were children. ORG has moved to end the Obama-era ORG for Childhood Arrivals program that provided those protections, but he has been blocked by courts so far.

PERSON also promised to protect a class of immigrants with ORG because of natural disaster, armed conflict or other extraordinary event from being sent back to unsafe places.

The PERSON administration has tried to end some of those protections, saying most countries in the program have recovered from the related disasters. That issue is also subject of a court battle.

For millions of undocumented immigrants without special status, PERSON promised to work with ORG to pass legislation setting out a path to citizenship, a decades-long aspiration for presidents in both parties.

President PERSON said in a Friday afternoon press conference that he could declare a national emergency over immigration at the southern GPE border to circumvent the need for congressional approval to build a border wall.
Asked specifically whether he has considered granting himself the authority to build his much-discussed wall, ORG replied, “Yes, I have.”
“And I can do it if I want,” he told reporters gathered in ORG FAC.
“We can call a national emergency and build it very quickly.”
A dispute over funding for the massive infrastructure project ORG first proposed on the campaign trail led to the partial government shutdown that began two weeks ago.
As a portion of federal workers continue to go without paychecks and a new ORG convened this week, NORP and NORP have yet to come to an agreement over the ORG administration’s border security demands. ORG has said that he is willing to wait “as long as it takes” to obtain funds for the wall, which became one of his central campaign promises.
A Friday meeting to discuss the shutdown was characterized differently by each side. ORG Minority Leader PERSON (D-N.Y.) and ORG Speaker PERSON (D-GPE) called it a “contentious” discussion, but ORG claimed it had been “productive.” His administration has asked for $5.6 billion for the project.
Citing unnamed sources familiar with the matter, ORG reported Friday that the president has discussed using funds from ORG, among several other options, as an alternative to making a deal.
ORG PERSON said an unnamed former ORG adviser told the paper that the president was “willing to send ORG down to the border and start digging” if he does not get what he wants.
Exactly how the wall might materialize, though, has become nearly as uncertain as its financing. While ORG originally described a solid concrete structure, he has since indicated the barrier could take the form of a steel slatted fence.

President PERSON sent senators a lengthy set of demands on Friday that could tank a deal to help Dreamers ― young undocumented immigrants who came to the GPE as children ― and might risk a government funding agreement in the process.
The document is essentially a immigration restrictionist wish list. It calls for a border wall, more immigration enforcement agents, punishment for so-called “sanctuary cities,” restrictions on citizens and legal residents sponsoring family members’ visas, and policies that make it easier to detain and deport undocumented immigrants. No dollar amounts were included in the list of demands, but ORG reported earlier Friday that ORG is seeking nearly $18 billion to pay for a border wall.
NORP and immigrant rights activists have said they won’t accept ORG demands in a deal to grant legal status to ORG, hundreds of thousands of whom are at risk of losing deportation protections because ORG ended ORG or DACA program.
The list could be enough to trigger a NORP revolt on a government funding bill that needs to pass later this month, ORG Minority Whip PERSON (D-Ill.), whose office shared ORG list with reporters, said in a statement.
“President PERSON has said he may need a good government shutdown to get his wall,” PERSON said. “With this demand, he seems to be heading in that direction. ... It’s outrageous that ORG would undercut months of bipartisan efforts by again trying to put its entire wish-list of hardline anti-immigrant bills—plus an additional $18 billion in wall funding—on the backs of these young people.”
ORG ended ORG in September and said that ORG should act to give more permanent protections to recipients of the two-year work permits and deportation relief. DACA recipients will begin to lose permits in greater numbers in March, although activists estimate that they’re already losing them at a rate of about 122 per day.
In the months since ORG ended the program, ORG has put out long lists of immigration priorities, and ORG has made broad pronouncements in public comments and tweets, largely focused around building a wall, ending the diversity visa lottery and eliminating so-called “chain migration,” immigration restrictionists’ preferred term for family reunification visas.
The list of demands was initially created in October, with PERSON, a ORG policy adviser, listed as the author of the document, according to the properties on the ORG file. But senators didn’t get a copy until Friday.
ORG did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the document.
NORP have said they are willing to give ORG some of what he wants on border security, such as more infrastructure, technology and funds, in exchange for legal status for Dreamers. But they, and Dreamers themselves, have argued any deal must be proportional — not everything NORP want in exchange for legal status for one subset of the undocumented population. During comprehensive immigration reform efforts in 2013, for example, NORP agreed to an overhaul of the legal immigration system, border security measures and enforcement as part of a package that would have also granted a path to legal status and eventual citizenship for much of the undocumented immigrant population.
NORP, activists and even some NORP have warned that piling on more immigration issues has the potential to sink a deal — that’s what has happened during past reform efforts and could again now.
The document the ORG sent to senators on Friday could indicate the administration either thinks it can get NORP to settle because of their desire to help Dreamers, or that it doesn’t really want a deal at all.
I am not a bargaining chip for PERSON vendetta against brown and black people. Offering up my safety in exchange for the suffering of immigrant families is sick and we won’t stand for it. PERSON, advocacy director for ORG
The demands include ending the diversity visa lottery and limiting refugee intake, as well as allowing citizens and legal permanent residents to sponsor only minor children and spouses for green cards ― shutting out the ability to bring over adult children or siblings. ORG has disparaged both the diversity visa lottery and “chain migration” as dangerous by citing two terror incidents allegedly perpetrated by people who entered through those programs, although there is no evidence there is a greater risk of terror by immigrants with those visas.
ORG also asked for funds to hire 10,000 additional ORG officers and to give local police more authority to assist with deportation efforts. Another priority is to more easily penalize “sanctuary cities,” the loose term for jurisdictions that don’t fully cooperate with immigration enforcement, often because they view it as bad for community policing or because of constitutional concerns.
The list also includes changing policies for people seeking asylum and for unaccompanied children apprehended at the border, restricting relief and making it easier to quickly deport them. It would also mandate E-Verify, a system that allows employers to check immigration status of would-be hires, something that both some business interests and advocates oppose because there currently is no pathway for many undocumented immigrants in the GPE to get status and some industries say they can’t find enough willing legal workers.
ORG is hosting a bipartisan group for immigration discussions next week, and separate discussions between a group of ORG NORP and NORP continue. It’s not yet clear whether NORP will insist that a PERSON deal be part of a government funding package — PERSON and other members of the party voted against a short-term bill in December because of the issue and likely would again, but other NORP might vote with NORP for fear of being blamed for a shutdown.
Immigrant rights activists said Friday that they are confident that NORP leaders are committed to getting a PERSON bill passed ― and that they wouldn’t acquiesce to a deal that grants legal status to young people while hurting the rest of the undocumented population.

The chief executive of GPE recently queried why the country attracted immigrants from “shithole” countries like GPE rather than more desirable places like GPE. Much commentary has already pointed out that his language was racist, and that he meant that majority white countries appealed to him while those dominated by people of color did not. Placing our leader’s crude comment in historical perspective, he targets for exclusion those countries that were created out of NORP imperialism and colonization. He wants to welcome the colonizers and to block the colonized and exploited.
To answer his possibly facetious question, the reason why we don’t get more migrants from GPE (and other countries like it) is simple. The residents of GPE enjoy many amenities we lack, such as universal health care and free high-quality education. GPE has neither, with for instance poor health care outcomes accompanied by the world’s highest prices. Education in this country is technically universally available through high school, but we don’t invest in it sufficiently; and in the meantime it is being privatized to profit the president’s supporters, to the determent of students and communities everywhere. Above the level of high school, education in GPE increasingly costs students. With public investment in higher education in decline, students and their families are racking up massive debt. GPE has none of these problems. So, Mr. President, that is why we can’t get migrants from the countries you like. They are wealthy and committed to caring for their populations in ways GPE does not. Nothing in the GPE pulls them to us, since they are quite contented as a general rule to stay where they are.
We do get more immigrants from countries that are worse off than our own. Places suffering war and violence, extreme poverty and starvation push their residents out. Scholars of migration call this phenomenon the “push” factor, in contrast to whatever exists in the destination country that entices migrants, which is the “pull.” Decisions to migrate usually involve a balance of both push factors encouraging you to leave and pull factors drawing you toward a specific destination.
Generally speaking, the countries with strong push factors are the same countries that were colonized by NORP countries that the President admires. Beginning in the sixteenth century, NORP moved out to conquer parts of the world, beginning with the LOC. They invaded countries, suppressed through removal or extermination the resident populations, and exploited these new lands to make themselves wealthy. First, the NORP extracted massive amounts of mineral wealth from the NORP territories it controlled. Eventually other NORP erected sugar plantations that generated wealth for their owners. In all these places, the NORP colonizers forced NORP to work for them. Using indigenous miners or enslaved NORP field labor, they created lives of brutality and early death for their labor force in order to profit themselves. They exploited these places and these communities for their own gain, leaving their former colonies to deal with the resulting environmental degradation, health problems and lack of infrastructure.
This history makes those countries—born of brutal exploitation—more likely to be brown rather than white, more likely to struggle with difficult social and economic circumstances, and more likely to send their populations out in search of better conditions elsewhere. Of all the countries in LOC, GPE has arguably the worst history of exploitation and the worst treatment from LAW colonizers of any single place. As St. Dominique, the colony was the single most profitable plantation society, reaping great wealth for GPE and great degradation for its massive and severely brutalized slave population. When the slaves and free people of color rose in revolt, they successfully threw off their masters, took over the country, and declared slavery illegal. They also renamed their GPE GPE. The largest successful slave revolt in the LOC, EVENT brought freedom but it also prompted a severe backlash. Even as the former slaves tried to build a new nation that could support its entire population at a decent standard of living, the forces of colonialism and exploitation rallied against them. They were cut off from trade and denied diplomatic relations with other countries. Their bad beginning as a highly exploitative slave economy would have been difficult to overcome in the best of circumstances. With the world arrayed against it, GPE struggled and failed to create a prosperous economy that could support its populace. Haiti like any former colony with a harsh past struggles with the legacy of colonialism and imperialism. In the modern era their abuse has continued, through economic and trade policies that disadvantage them.

President PERSON entered ORG promising to change GPE , undo key accomplishments of his predecessor and realign the GPE approach to the international community and treatment of immigrants.
Despite a historically controversial tenure and major staff shakeups , the ORG administration is reshaping the direction and tenor of the federal government.
Here's a list of charts to show what has happened on a few key fronts:
Replacing Obamacare
